data:
A 43-year-old man presented with a progressive deterioration of visual function for the previous seven years. The patient had no other ocular symptoms such as nystagmus or photophobia. His past history showed stable vision of 20 / 40 since trauma to his right eye when he was approximately 14 years of age. No other systemic abnormalities or malformations were recorded. His best-corrected vision was 20 / 400 in the right eye and 20 / 20 in the left, and his intraocular pressures were 25 mmHg in the right eye and 23 mmHg in the left eye at the time of his initial visit. Under slit lamp examination, a diffuse haze composed of a flaky pattern of stroma was noted throughout the entire cornea. The right eye had decreased vision and exhibited relatively denser homogenous opacities than the left ().
The family members stated that corneal changes had been detected only in the patient's mother at 69 years of age, and no specific issues had arisen in any other family member or relative. The patient's father had reported no ophthalmic abnormalities before his death, and his mother had been diagnosed with diffuse corneal opacities of unknown etiology in both eyes three years previously (). She explained that she had experienced decreased vision since childhood, but these deficiencies produced no difficulties in her daily life. The patient's brother and sister had no symptoms at all and no ophthalmic or systemic abnormalities. As far as the family knew, no one in the paternal or maternal lineage or offspring of the patient had experienced any eye problems except for the patient's mother ().
The endothelium and Descemet's membrane of the right eye were identified as normal following slit lamp examination. No gross abnormalities, such as Haab's striae or features of posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy, were detected in the right eye. The patient's past medical records from another hospital demonstrated that his endothelial cells of both eyes presented with a normal shape and numbers under a specular microscope about six years ago. However, endothelial cells were found as indeterminate forms
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?

Patient: Hi, I've been having some trouble with my vision for the past seven years.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?

Patient: Well, my vision has been getting progressively worse. But I don't have any other symptoms like nystagmus or photophobia.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. Can you tell me about your past history with your eyes?

Patient: I had a trauma to my right eye when I was 14, and my vision has been stable at 20/40 since then.

Doctor: And have you had any other systemic abnormalities or malformations recorded?

Patient: No, not that I know of.

Doctor: All right. Let me take a look at your eyes. Your best-corrected vision was 20/400 in your right eye and 20/20 in your left, and your intraocular pressures were 25 mmHg in your right eye and 23 mmHg in your left eye at the time of your initial visit, is that correct?

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: Okay. I'm going to perform a slit lamp examination now. [pause] I've noticed a diffuse haze throughout the entire cornea composed of a flaky pattern of stroma. The right eye has decreased vision and relatively denser homogenous opacities than the left.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: Have you or anyone in your family been diagnosed with any eye problems?

Patient: Yes, my mother was diagnosed with diffuse corneal opacities of unknown etiology in both eyes three years ago. She's had decreased vision since childhood, but it hasn't caused any difficulties in her daily life.

Doctor: I see. And what about your father, brother, and sister?

Patient: My father had no ophthalmic abnormalities before his death, and my brother and sister have no symptoms or ophthalmic or systemic abnormalities.

Doctor: Okay, that's good to know. [pause] I've identified the endothelium and Descemet's membrane of your right eye as normal. I haven't detected any gross abnormalities like Haab's striae or features of posterior polymorphous corneal dystrophy.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: Your past medical records from another hospital demonstrated that your endothelial cells of both eyes presented with a normal shape and numbers under a specular microscope about six years ago. However, I've found some indeterminate forms.

Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: It means that we need to do some further testing to determine the cause of your vision problems. I'll schedule some follow-up appointments for you.

data:
As home care doctors and general practitioners, we encountered a 37-year-old woman with ASD who lived with her parents in Japan. Her mother had end-stage breast cancer. We visited her house regularly to care for her mother. The woman with ASD was the main caregiver and a key person for her mother because her father was visually impaired. There were some obstacles we need to overcome together, but in the end, she was able to fulfill the role of the main caregiver for her mother.
When we started home care for the mother, we did not have any knowledge that the daughter was a person with ASD. However, we occasionally heard about her from home visit nurses and home care staff because they worried about whether the mother could continue to stay at home due to the lack of care provided by family members. According to home care staff members, the woman with ASD was usually not present when the home care staff visited the home for her mother's care. They could not contact her or talk with her about her mother's condition. She focused on dishwashing and did not appear concerned about how her mother's medications or clothes were organized or whether the room was clean or not. She could not communicate well with home care staff even when she talked with them. Thus, we did not initially recognize that she was a person with ASD or another developmental disorder. We were wondering why she was having trouble managing the home care schedule and chores even though she worked as an engineer. The home care staff's distrust of the daughter caused irritation and stress in the daughter and the home care staff.
After a few home care visits, with the daughter's consent, the mother's care manager informed us that she had been diagnosed with ASD in adulthood. Her parents had not been informed of the diagnosis. The daughter did not want to let her parents know about the diagnosis. The home care staff started to feel strongly that it was too difficult for the
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you today?
Patient: I'm fine, thank you.
Doctor: I understand that you live with your mother and you're the main caregiver for her.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I've encountered some information about your mother's condition. She has end-stage breast cancer, right?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: How has the home care been going for her?
Patient: It's been okay. There have been some obstacles, but I've been able to fulfill my role as the main caregiver.
Doctor: That's great to hear. I understand that the home care staff has been worried about whether your mother could continue to stay at home due to the lack of care provided by family members.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And I heard that you were not present when the home care staff visited your home for your mother's care.
Patient: Yes, that's right. I was usually focused on dishwashing and didn't appear concerned about how my mother's medications or clothes were organized or whether the room was clean or not.
Doctor: I see. And the home care staff couldn't communicate well with you even when they talked with you.
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I have trouble communicating with people.
Doctor: After a few home care visits, your mother's care manager informed us that you have been diagnosed with ASD.
Patient: Yes, that's correct. I didn't want to let my parents know about the diagnosis.
Doctor: I understand. The home care staff started to feel strongly that it was too difficult for you to manage the home care schedule and chores.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I'm sorry to hear that. But I think it's important for you to know that you're not alone. There are many people who have been diagnosed with ASD and are able to live a fulfilling life.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: Is there anything you would like to talk about or ask me today?
Patient: No, I think that's all.
Doctor: Okay. If you have any concerns or questions in the future, don't hesitate to contact me.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: And I would like to check in with you in a few weeks to see how things are going.
Patient: Okay, I'll make sure to schedule an appointment.
Doctor: Great. Take care of yourself and your mother.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.

conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hmm, I'm okay, just a little tired.
Doctor: I see from your medical records that you have been a caregiver for your mother who had end-stage breast cancer. How has that been for you?
Patient: It was difficult, but I was able to fulfill the role of the main caregiver for my mother.
Doctor: That's great to hear. We encountered some obstacles during home care, but together we were able to provide the care your mother needed.
Patient: Yes, the home care staff was worried about whether my mother could continue to stay at home due to the lack of care provided by family members.
Doctor: They also mentioned that you were usually not present during their visits. Why was that?
Patient: I was usually doing the dishes or other chores.
Doctor: I see. Were you aware of your mother's medications or how her clothes were organized?
Patient: Not really, I was focused on the dishes.
Doctor: I understand. The home care staff had some distrust towards you, causing you stress. Did you feel that?
Patient: Yes, it was difficult to communicate with them even when we talked.
Doctor: That's understandable. After a few home care visits, we learned that you were diagnosed with ASD in adulthood. Did you know about this?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed, but I didn't want to let my parents know about it.
Doctor: I understand. It must have been difficult for you to manage the home care schedule and chores while also dealing with your disorder.
Patient: Yes, it was difficult at times.
Doctor: Now that we know about your diagnosis, we can work together to make sure you have the support you need. How do you feel about that?
Patient: Okay, that sounds good.
Doctor: Great. We will need to inform your family about your diagnosis and plan for your follow-up care.

data:
A 81-year old woman was referred to our department to evaluate a wound dehiscence on her left knee with hardware exposure. The patient did not have any relevant comorbidities and her general status was good. The patient underwent a total left hip arthroplasty at the age of seventy four due to severe osteoarthritis pain that hindered baseline activities. Eight years later, the patient presented to the orthopedics department with a progressive pain in the affected hip, particularly when walking, causing difficulties in deambulation.
An X ray examination revealed an extensive femoral bone loss with displacement of the femoral component, and an MRI showed a femoral pseudo-tumor (bone proliferation). With this finding, a revision total hip arthroplasty was performed with the insertion of a reconstruction ring with cemented dual mobility cups. Three weeks after this last surgery, the patient started with early symptoms of infection (high fever, suppuration, no wound healing and laboratory abnormalities); an attempt at conservative management with intravenous antibiotic, irrigation and suction drainages was unsuccessful and a replacement of the endoprosthesis femur in two stages was planned.
In the first stage, the previous prosthesis was removed with enlarged osteotomy of the anterior tuberosity and a cement spacer with antibiotic was placed. Two months later, the spacer was removed and a new coated silver total femoral prosthesis was placed. The patient was referred to our unit four weeks after the last surgery for the assessment of wound dehiscence to the lateral knee with hardware exposure. The patient was taken to the operating room for retention debridement and wound coverage with a flap. Our first decision was to cover the defect with a lateral gastrocnemius flap, however, the surrounding area was highly scarred, and the gastrocnemius muscle was found to be very atrophic and no suitable to fit the large defect. shows no other local flaps to be large enough to cover the whole defect, so we opted for a free flap.
A lack of receptor vessels was evidenced, descending genicular artery was dissected, but small caliber and calcified plaques in the lumen discarded
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hmm, not too good, my knee wound hurts.
Doctor: I see. You were referred to our department to evaluate the wound dehiscence on your left knee with hardware exposure. Can you tell me more about the wound?
Patient: Yes, it's been bothering me for a while now. It's painful and there's some hardware showing.
Doctor: I understand. Do you have any other medical issues or comorbidities that we should know about?
Patient: No, I don't have any other medical problems.
Doctor: That's good to hear. Your general status is good, but I see that you underwent a total left hip arthroplasty before. Can you tell me more about that?
Patient: Yes, I had severe osteoarthritis pain that hindered baseline activities, so I had the surgery when I was seventy-four.
Doctor: I see. Eight years later, you presented to the orthopedics department with a progressive pain in the affected hip, particularly when walking, causing difficulties in deambulation. An X-ray examination revealed an extensive femoral bone loss with displacement of the femoral component. Did you experience any other symptoms?
Patient: No, just the pain when walking.
Doctor: Okay. An MRI showed a femoral pseudo-tumor (bone proliferation), and with this finding, a revision total hip arthroplasty was performed with the insertion of a reconstruction ring with cemented dual mobility cups. How did you feel after the surgery?
Patient: I felt okay at first, but then I started experiencing early symptoms of infection about three weeks after the surgery.
Doctor: I see. The symptoms included high fever, suppuration, no wound healing, and laboratory abnormalities. An attempt at conservative management with intravenous antibiotic, irrigation, and suction drainages was unsuccessful, and a replacement of the endoprosthesis femur in two stages was planned. Do you remember this?
Patient: Yes, I remember the surgeries.
Doctor: In the first stage, the previous prosthesis was removed with enlarged osteotomy of the anterior tuberosity, and a cement spacer with antibiotic was placed. Two months later, the spacer was removed, and a new coated silver total femoral prosthesis was placed. You were referred to our unit four weeks after the last surgery for the assessment of wound dehiscence to the lateral knee with hardware exposure. Do you remember this?
Patient: Yes, that's why I'm here.
Doctor: I see. The patient was taken to the operating room for retention debridement and wound coverage with a flap. Our first decision was to cover the defect with a lateral gastrocnemius flap, however, the surrounding area was highly scarred, and the gastrocnemius muscle was found to be very atrophic and not suitable to fit the large defect. There were no other local flaps large enough to cover the whole defect, so we opted for a free flap. We evidenced a lack of receptor vessels, and the descending genicular artery was dissected, but small caliber and calcified plaques in the lumen discarded.
Patient's Family: Excuse me, doctor. We are the patient's family. We are very concerned about her condition. Can you tell us more about what's going on?

data:
This is a 39-year-old male with a past medical history of coronary artery disease requiring coronary artery bypass graft in 2009 and percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting in 2008 to the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery. Patient also has hypercholesterolemia and hypothyroidism. He presented to the emergency department complaining of substernal chest pain associated with dizziness and shortness of breath. This occurred once to two times a week. His last stress test was in 2013 which was insignificant. One month ago he saw his cardiologist who recommended using nitroglycerin more frequently. His chest pain initially improved but for the past week his pain was increasing in severity and radiating to the left shoulder. Patient denied any nausea, vomiting, sweating, or loss of consciousness. The chest pain was not aggravated or alleviated by position or medication. Vital signs were within normal limits. Physical examination was normal including cardiac and neurological exam. The patient was seen by the cardiac team and was scheduled for a cardiac catheterization.
A cardiac catheterization was performed which did not show any narrowing or disease of vessels. His ejection fraction was 65% and the previous grafts and stent were patent. The cardiac team cleared the patient for discharge. The patient was scheduled for discharge, however he suddenly developed left-sided weakness and facial droop. NIH stroke scale was 9. The rapid response team was called and the patient underwent a CT scan with no contrast which showed no evidence of any acute or significant intracranial abnormality and no bleeding. Patient was transferred to the ICU and the neurology team was consulted. Neurology recommended the use of tPA as the patient was within the window period for use. While reviewing the guidelines and contraindications, it was discovered that the patient's aPTT was higher than the upper normal limit due to the recent use of unfractionated heparin for cardiac catheterization. At this time, the primary team made the decision to recheck the aPTT after one hour since the patient was still within the therapeutic window for tPA. The repeat aPTT was
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. I'm Dr. Smith. Can you tell me what brings you to the emergency department today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I came here because I have been experiencing chest pain and shortness of breath for the past week.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your chest pain? Where exactly is it located and what does it feel like?
Patient: It's a substernal chest pain and it's associated with dizziness. It's been happening once to two times a week.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a past medical history of coronary artery disease and I underwent coronary artery bypass graft in 2009 and also had percutaneous coronary intervention and stenting in 2008 to the left anterior descending artery and right coronary artery.
Doctor: Okay. And do you have any other medical conditions?
Patient: Yes, I have hypercholesterolemia and hypothyroidism.
Doctor: I see. And have you seen a cardiologist recently?
Patient: Yes, I saw my cardiologist one month ago. He recommended using nitroglycerin more frequently.
Doctor: Okay. And did your chest pain improve after using nitroglycerin?
Patient: Yes, it improved initially but for the past week, the pain has been increasing in severity and radiating to my left shoulder.
Doctor: I see. Have you experienced any nausea, vomiting, sweating, or loss of consciousness?
Patient: No, I haven't.
Doctor: Okay. And does your chest pain get worse or better with position or medication?
Patient: No, it doesn't get worse or better with position or medication.
Doctor: Okay. Let's take a look at your vital signs. Your vital signs are within normal limits. That's good. Can you tell me about your physical examination?
Patient: The physical examination was normal, including the cardiac and neurological exam.
Doctor: Okay. I see that you underwent a cardiac catheterization. Can you tell me about the results?
Patient: The cardiac catheterization did not show any narrowing or disease of vessels. My ejection fraction was 65% and the previous grafts and stent were patent.
Doctor: Great. And were you scheduled for discharge?
Patient: Yes, I was scheduled for discharge but then I suddenly developed left-sided weakness and facial droop.
Doctor: I see. We called the rapid response team and you underwent a CT scan with no contrast. The CT scan showed no evidence of any acute or significant intracranial abnormality and no bleeding.
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And the neurology team was consulted. They recommended the use of tPA. However, we discovered that your aPTT was higher than the upper normal limit due to the recent use of unfractionated heparin for cardiac catheterization.
Patient: Yes, I understand.
Doctor: At this time, the primary team made the decision to recheck your aPTT after one hour since you were still within the therapeutic window for tPA. And the repeat aPTT was within the normal limit.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We will keep you in the ICU for observation and we will monitor your condition closely. Please let us know if you experience any changes or discomfort.
Patient: Okay, I will. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: Okay, I will. Thank you.

data: A 40-year-old dominant right-handed male working in private insurance company with no significant medical history suffered a distal radius fracture of the left hand due to road traffic accident (). On clinical examination, he could move the fingers of the hand and there was no evidence of any neurovascular deficit distal to the injury. Crepitus could be felt in the distal part of the radius just proximal to wrist joint and movements around the wrist were painful and limited. There were no other associated injuries, and medical history was not significant for any medical illness. A clinical diagnosis of the fracture of lower end radius was made and radiographs were consistent with the clinical diagnosis. Radiographs showed a comminuted fracture of the distal third radius with intra-articular extension for which open reduction and internal fixation through a volar FCR approach was planned. He underwent the definitive treatment of open reduction and internal fixation of the fractures distal radius under regional anesthesia. We had planned to fix the distal radius fracture using the usual FCR approach using 3.5 mm distal end radius locking plate. We could not identify the absence of the FCR tendon preoperatively because of severe swelling of the distal forearm. The incision was made at its usual location and we identified one tendon in the superficial plane which we thought was FCR, but when we traced the tendon proximally it started thinning without any muscle belly and when traced distally to its attachment, it was confirmed to be tendon of palmaris longus (PL). We could not find any tendon between PL and the traced radial artery. At that stage, we realized that FCRL was absent in that patient. We wrongly identified the PL tendon as the FCR because it was the tendinous structure at the most radial location of the volar distal forearm. When we found the median nerve just radial to the PL tendon, we were then able to identify the anatomical abnormality described in this case and immediate post-operative X-ray (-). conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?

Patient: Hi doctor, I suffered a distal radius fracture in my left hand due to a road traffic accident.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a bit more about the accident?

Patient: Yes, I was hit by a car while crossing the road.

Doctor: Okay. And what happened to your hand then?

Patient: I couldn't move my fingers and it was painful.

Doctor: I understand. During the clinical examination, did you experience any neurovascular deficit distal to the injury?

Patient: No, I could move my fingers.

Doctor: That's good to hear. And did you feel crepitus in the distal part of the radius just proximal to wrist joint?

Patient: Yes, I did. And movements around the wrist were painful and limited.

Patient: No, there were no other injuries.

Doctor: And what about your medical history? Is there anything significant for any medical illness?

Patient: No, it's not significant for any medical illness.

Doctor: Okay. Based on the clinical examination and radiographs, we made a clinical diagnosis of a fracture of the lower end radius.

Patient: Yes, I heard that.

Doctor: The radiographs showed a comminuted fracture of the distal third radius with intra-articular extension. That's why we planned for open reduction and internal fixation through a volar FCR approach.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We had planned to fix the distal radius fracture using a 3.5 mm distal end radius locking plate. But when we made the incision, we couldn't identify the absence of the FCR tendon because of the severe swelling of the distal forearm.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: We identified one tendon in the superficial plane which we thought was FCR, but when we traced it proximally, it started thinning without any muscle belly. And when traced distally to its attachment, it was confirmed to be the tendon of palmaris longus.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We couldn't find any tendon between the PL and the traced radial artery. At that stage, we realized that FCRL was absent in you. We wrongly identified the PL tendon as the FCR because it was the tendinous structure at the most radial location of the volar distal forearm.

Patient: I see.

Doctor: When we found the median nerve just radial to the PL tendon, we were then able to identify the anatomical abnormality described in this case and immediate post-operative X-ray.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: Therefore, we changed the approach to the classic Hen.

Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining it to me.

Doctor: You're welcome. We'll need to keep an eye on your hand's progress and schedule follow-up appointments.

data: A fourty-year-old man with DEB diagnosed at the age of eight was admitted to the department of gastroenterology because of the dysphagia for two previous months. The diagnosis of DEB was established due to the presence of single blisters on the whole body since the sixth month of life. His sister was also diagnosed with DEB and had similar symptoms of the disease. To our knowledge, the presented patient and his sister are the oldest diagnosed with EB living in Poland. At the age of four the patient started experiencing heartburn occasionally. Five years later dysphagia appeared for the first time. It was an episodal and periodical ailment. He reported a deterioration of dysphagia at the age of nineteen; he mostly consumed liquids and soft consistency meals during that time. Nonetheless, the patient admitted that this esophageal discomfort still was not a constant one and there were time intervals without this ailment. In the past there were also episodes of mild esophageal bleeding. The only one endoscopic esophageal dilatation in this patient took place in 1997; a stenosis was located then approximately 18 cm from incisors. The performed procedure ameliorated swallowing difficulty. A barium swallow test obtained one year after the endoscopic dilatation of the esophagus also revealed esophageal constriction on the same level. In 2014 the patient was diagnosed because of hematochezia and pain in hypogastrium. Tissue samples obtained in colonoscopy revealed the presence of nonspecific inflammatory infiltration in the ascending colon and terminal part of the ileum. Interestingly, 3 years ago he complained of hemoptysis and there was a suspicion of bleeding to pulmonary alveoli in the course of DEB. However, a CT scan did not confirm bleeding. On admission to our department the patient was complaining of painful swallowing of solids. Two months earlier he was diagnosed in the cardiology unit because of the chest pain and elevated level of troponin I. An electrocardiogram did not show any abnormalities. The patient refused to undergo coronarography and no more cardiological diagnostic procedures were performed Additional file . On admission to our unit
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you today?

Patient: Not so good, doctor. I have been experiencing some painful swallowing of solids.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?

Patient: Sure. I was diagnosed with DEB when I was eight years old. I have had single blisters on my body since I was six months old. My sister also has DEB and has similar symptoms.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. And why were you admitted to the department of gastroenterology?

Patient: I have been having dysphagia for the past two months.

Doctor: I understand. Have you ever had any other symptoms related to your esophagus?

Patient: Yes, I have had heartburn occasionally since I was four. And I started experiencing dysphagia for the first time when I was nine. It was episodal and periodical.

Doctor: Okay. And did you notice any deterioration in your dysphagia over the years?

Patient: Yes, I did. At the age of nineteen, my dysphagia got worse and I mostly consumed liquids and soft consistency meals. But it was not a constant ailment and there were time intervals without this ailment.

Doctor: I see. Have you ever had any episodes of esophageal bleeding?

Patient: Yes, I have had mild esophageal bleeding in the past.

Doctor: Okay. Did you have any endoscopic esophageal dilatation procedures in the past?

Patient: Yes, I did. I had one endoscopic esophageal dilatation in 1997 and it helped improve my swallowing difficulty. A barium swallow test obtained one year after the procedure revealed esophageal constriction on the same level.

Doctor: I see. And have you had any other medical issues in the past?

Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with hematochezia and pain in the hypogastrium in 2014. And tissue samples obtained in colonoscopy revealed the presence of nonspecific inflammatory infiltration in the ascending colon and terminal part of the ileum.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And have you had any issues with hemoptysis in the past?

Patient: Yes, I have. 3 years ago I complained of hemoptysis and there was a suspicion of bleeding to pulmonary alveoli in the course of DEB. But a CT scan did not confirm the bleeding.

Doctor: I see. And were you diagnosed with any other medical conditions recently?

Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with chest pain and elevated level of troponin I in the cardiology unit two months ago. But an electrocardiogram did not show any abnormalities.

Doctor: Okay. And did you undergo any other diagnostic procedures for your chest pain?

Patient: No, I refused to undergo coronarography.

Doctor: I understand. Well, I will have to examine you and run some tests to see what's causing your painful swallowing. In the meantime, try to avoid solid foods and stick to liquids and soft consistency meals.

Patient: Okay, doctor.

data:
An 88-year-old man was transferred from a referring hospital for descending thoracic aortic injury after attempted pacemaker placement; 3 days prior he was admitted with a transient ischemic attack. He had new onset atrial fibrillation and sinus bradycardia that prompted pacemaker placement. Left subclavian access was attempted after a pocket was created. After placement of a five French sheath, arterial blood return was noted. The sheath was left in place and the procedure was aborted. The patient was hemodynamically stable and taken to computed tomography (CT) scanner for evaluation of arterial injury. The CT scan revealed direct cannulation of the aortic knob with the sheath. The patient was directly transferred by helicopter to our institution for higher level of vascular surgery care. The patient arrived intubated and sedated with the sheath in place in the left chest covered with a dressing and a left chest tube in place with 100cc of sanguinous output.
The patient was taken to the hybrid operating room in our facility. Bilateral percutaneous femoral access was obtained and a five French sheath was placed in the right common femoral artery, and initially, a seven French sheath was placed in the left common femoral artery. We placed two proglide devices in the left access in standard preclose technique as this was our anticipated side of device deployment. At this point, a pigtail catheter was advanced into the ascending aorta and an arch aortogram was performed which demonstrated a direct cannulation of the aortic knob (). We elected to proceed to with stent graft placement to manage this injury as the patient’s comorbidities and advanced age were prohibitive risks for open repair. Prior to the placement of an endoprosthesis, a cerebral angiogram was performed to identify cerebrovascular dominance. This demonstrated a dominant right vertebral artery and left vertebral atresia. There was adequate distance from the site of sheath insertion to the left subclavian artery, such that we felt we could achieve a seal without covering the left subclavian artery. Based on our preoperative measurement of our anticipated proximal and distal seal zones,

data:
A 40-year-old Asian woman who had been in her usual state of good health was incidentally found to have a small nodule in the lower lobe of her right lung during a regular medical checkup. The patient was seen in the department of medicine of our hospital for further evaluation. The patient’s family history was noncontributory, and a physical examination revealed no abnormalities. The results of laboratory studies were either within normal limits or negative. A computed tomographic (CT) scan revealed a lytic lesion of the fifth lumbar vertebral bone, as well as a small nodule (1.2 cm in diameter) in the lower lobe of the right lung (Fig. ). The vertebral lesion was situated on the left transverse process and was separated from the spinal canal (Fig. ). Biopsy specimens of both lesions were histologically similar and showed spindle cell neoplasms with a bland appearance; however, we could not make a definitive diagnosis, owing to the small size of the samples. The patient was placed under close observation with suspicion of multiple metastases from an unknown primary tumor.
Five years later, a CT scan indicated that the pulmonary nodule had slightly increased in size. Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging also revealed an increase in the size of the lytic lesion in the left transverse process of the fifth lumbar vertebra. To evaluate both the pulmonary and vertebral lesions, video-assisted thoracic surgery for the pulmonary lesion and curettage of the lytic bone lesion were performed. The orthopedic surgeons found that the tumor of the fifth left transverse process was exposed on the posterior surface but not on the anterior surface. They also found that the vertebral lesion was completely confined within the vertebral bone and was not connected to the spinal canal. During the clinical course (105 months), no significant findings other than the pulmonary and vertebral lesions were found, even with imaging examinations, including CT and MR imaging. The patient made good postoperative progress and remained free of disease at 41 months after the operation.
The resected specimen of the lung contained a well-

Patient: I'm good, thank you.
Doctor: I see here that you came in for a regular checkup, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: During your checkup, we found a small nodule in your right lung. We'll need to evaluate it further to determine what it is.
Patient: Okay, what do I need to do?
Doctor: We'll need to perform a CT scan to get a better look at the nodule.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: The results of your laboratory studies were within normal limits and negative, which is good. We also didn't find any abnormalities during your physical examination.
Patient: That's a relief.
Doctor: However, the CT scan revealed a lytic lesion in your fifth lumbar vertebral bone and a small nodule in your right lung. We'll need to biopsy both to determine what they are.
Patient: I understand.
Doctor: Unfortunately, the biopsy samples were too small to make a definitive diagnosis. We suspect that there may be multiple metastases from an unknown primary tumor, so we'll need to observe you closely.
Patient: Okay, I'll do whatever I need to do.
Doctor: Five years later, your CT scan indicated that the pulmonary nodule had slightly increased in size. We also found an increase in the size of the lytic lesion in the left transverse process of the fifth lumbar vertebra.
Patient: That doesn't sound good.
Doctor: We'll need to perform video-assisted thoracic surgery for the pulmonary lesion and curettage of the lytic bone lesion to evaluate both.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: During the surgery, the orthopedic surgeons found that the tumor of the fifth left transverse process was exposed on the posterior surface but not on the anterior surface. They also found that the vertebral lesion was completely confined within the vertebral bone and was not connected to the spinal canal.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the tumor is contained and hasn't spread to other areas.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: During your clinical course, we didn't find any significant findings other than the pulmonary and vertebral lesions, even with imaging examinations such as CT and MR imaging.
Patient: So, what does that mean for me?
Doctor: It means that you made good postoperative progress and have remained free of disease at 41 months after the operation.
Patient: Thank you so much for your help and for taking care of me.
Doctor: Of course, it's our pleasure. If you have any concerns or questions, please don't hesitate to contact us.

data:
A 81-year old woman was referred to our department to evaluate a wound dehiscence on her left knee with hardware exposure. The patient did not have any relevant comorbidities and her general status was good. The patient underwent a total left hip arthroplasty at the age of seventy four due to severe osteoarthritis pain that hindered baseline activities. Eight years later, the patient presented to the orthopedics department with a progressive pain in the affected hip, particularly when walking, causing difficulties in deambulation.
An X ray examination revealed an extensive femoral bone loss with displacement of the femoral component, and an MRI showed a femoral pseudo-tumor (bone proliferation). With this finding, a revision total hip arthroplasty was performed with the insertion of a reconstruction ring with cemented dual mobility cups. Three weeks after this last surgery, the patient started with early symptoms of infection (high fever, suppuration, no wound healing and laboratory abnormalities); an attempt at conservative management with intravenous antibiotic, irrigation and suction drainages was unsuccessful and a replacement of the endoprosthesis femur in two stages was planned.
In the first stage, the previous prosthesis was removed with enlarged osteotomy of the anterior tuberosity and a cement spacer with antibiotic was placed. Two months later, the spacer was removed and a new coated silver total femoral prosthesis was placed. The patient was referred to our unit four weeks after the last surgery for the assessment of wound dehiscence to the lateral knee with hardware exposure. The patient was taken to the operating room for retention debridement and wound coverage with a flap. Our first decision was to cover the defect with a lateral gastrocnemius flap, however, the surrounding area was highly scarred, and the gastrocnemius muscle was found to be very atrophic and no suitable to fit the large defect. shows no other local flaps to be large enough to cover the whole defect, so we opted for a free flap.
A lack of receptor vessels was evidenced, descending genicular artery was dissected, but small caliber and calcified plaques in the lumen discarded

data: A 84-year-old female was scheduled for bilateral total hip replacement due to osteoarthritis of both hips (). Medical history included chronic Hepatitis C virus infection with no other medical conditions reported. The patient was allowed to decide which hip would be performed first. 5 months after scheduling, the patient was admitted for surgery arriving in a wheelchair, and new pelvis radiographs were taken (). Other causes of the rapid destruction of the hip joint were ruled out, and the patient was diagnosed of bilateral RDO. Keeping in mind a possible septic etiology, despite there was no history of septicemia and inflammatory markers were elevated due to chronic hepatitis, we decided to take samples for microbiology and histology during the procedures. The right hip was performed through an anterior approach by a senior surgeon following standard antibiotic prophylaxis with 2 g of cefazolin 20 min before skin incision. An uncemented prosthesis was implanted with no complications. Femoral head destruction led to an important defect in the posterior and superior wall of the acetabulum. This conditioned high and medial implantation of the cup to achieve stability. 4 days after the first procedure was performed, one out of six cultures was positive for Enterococcus faecium with no local and systemic signs of infection or pain. Synovial biopsy revealed fibrosis, chronic inflammation, calcifications, macrophages, and osteoclast giant cells with no signs of acute inflammation. Urine cultures were negative. The Musculoskeletal Infection Society criteria [] were not met and the patient did not receive antibiotic treatment. 6 days later, after a favorable post-operative evolution, the left hip was performed through a posterior approach by a different senior surgeon with the same hip system but with a cemented stem (). In the left hip, the acetabulum was also affected by the bone destruction, but the cup was able to be placed at a correct height. This ended up with a leg length discrepancy that is well tolerated by the patient taking into account her previous functional status. 5 days after the second procedure and following a post-operative period without complications

data:
A 60 year old male presented with Staphylococcus aureous infection of his endocardial pacing system. His past medical history was remarkable for mild dilated cardiomyopathy, ventricular tachycardia, a biventricular endocardial pacing for cardiac resynchronization therapy, and several previous percutaneous endocardial pacing system implantations via the right and the left subclavian veins. The pacing leads and box were removed and the infection was treated with antibiotics. Due to subclavian vein stenosis and pacing box pocket infection, transvenous approach for implantation of a new pacing system proved not to be feasible. Therefore he was referred for surgical implantation of a new epicardial pacing system.
A lower half limited median sternotomy was performed starting from the xiphoid process, up to the level of the third intercostal space. A second limited transverse sternotomy was performed starting from the left third intercostal space and joining the midline sternotomy (Figure ). The pericardium was opened in the midline, providing excellent exposure and easy access to both the right atrial appendage and the right ventricle. The right atrial leads were sutured to the surface of the right atrial appendage, while the right ventricular bipolar leads were sutured to the anterior muscular part of the right ventricle. Access to the left ventricle was achieved by gently lifting up the heart, using an epicardial tissue stabilizing system and exposing the lateral wall of the left ventricle with no hemodynamic compromise. The left ventricular lead was screwed into the proximal part of the lateral wall between the obtuse marginal arteries and then the defibrillator patch was sutured to the distal lateral wall. It was made sure that there was a good orientation between the patch and the pacing box which was subsequently inserted in the sheath of the right rectus muscle. The thresholds on the pacing leads were checked and the defibrillating patch was tested. A right subcostal incision was made and a pocket was created in the lateral side of the right rectus muscle. The pacing wires were tunneled between the right hemi-diaphragm and the lateral edge of the right rectus muscle, into
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

Patient: I'm feeling okay, a little bit tired.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me why you're here today?

Patient: I was presented with a Staphylococcus aureous infection of my endocardial pacing system.

Doctor: I see. And what is your past medical history like?

Patient: I have mild dilated cardiomyopathy and ventricular tachycardia. I also have a biventricular endocardial pacing for cardiac resynchronization therapy. And I've had several previous percutaneous endocardial pacing system implantations via the right and the left subclavian veins.

Doctor: That's quite a history. So, what was done to treat the infection?

Patient: The pacing leads and box were removed and I was treated with antibiotics.

Doctor: I see. And why wasn't a new transvenous pacing system implanted?

Patient: Due to subclavian vein stenosis and pacing box pocket infection, a transvenous approach wasn't feasible. So I was referred for a surgical implantation of a new epicardial pacing system.

Doctor: I understand. Can you describe the procedure that was performed?

Patient: I had a lower half limited median sternotomy starting from the xiphoid process, up to the level of the third intercostal space. And then a second limited transverse sternotomy was performed starting from the left third intercostal space and joining the midline sternotomy. The pericardium was opened in the midline, providing excellent exposure and easy access to both the right atrial appendage and the right ventricle.

Doctor: I see. And what was done with the leads?

Patient: The right atrial leads were sutured to the surface of the right atrial appendage, while the right ventricular bipolar leads were sutured to the anterior muscular part of the right ventricle.

Doctor: And what about the left ventricle?

Patient: Access to the left ventricle was achieved by gently lifting up the heart, using an epicardial tissue stabilizing system and exposing the lateral wall of the left ventricle with no hemodynamic compromise. The left ventricular lead was screwed into the proximal part of the lateral wall between the obtuse marginal arteries and then the defibrillator patch was sutured to the distal lateral wall.

Doctor: I see. And where was the pacing box inserted?

Patient: It was made sure that there was a good orientation between the patch and the pacing box, which was subsequently inserted in the sheath of the right rectus muscle.

Doctor: And what was done after that?

Patient: The thresholds on the pacing leads were checked and the defibrillating patch was tested. A right subcostal incision was made and a pocket was created in the lateral side of the right rectus muscle. The pacing wires were tunneled between the right hemi-diaphragm and the lateral edge of the right rectus muscle, into the pocket.

Doctor: That's a lot of information. Is there anything else you'd like to add?

Patient: No, I think that's everything.

Doctor: Alright. I'll make sure to include all of this information in your file. Do you have any questions or concerns?

Patient: No, I think I'm good.

Doctor: Great. I'll see you at your follow-up appointment. Take care.

data:
At the time of diagnosis this patient was a 9 year-old female with a one year history of pain and swelling about her left knee. She had experienced a fall and related all symptoms to the fall. She was seen in her local emergency room by her family physician; there was no diagnosis or treatment. Approximately one month prior to her representation, she was struck in the left knee by a basketball and developed worsening pain. She was seen by an orthopedic surgeon (December 1999) and was noted to have a valgus posture of both lower extremities, exaggerated on the left by external rotation and she walked with a mild limp. The left knee had no effusion but was hypersensitive to light touch over the lateral aspect where there was soft tissue swelling just below the knee. There was no obvious mass in the area, although firm palpation was difficult because of patient discomfort. Plain films were normal and an MR was ordered that revealed an apparent meniscal cyst in the lateral aspect of the left knee [Figure ]. Biopsy of the cystic structure was performed (November 1999) that revealed a high-grade synovial cell sarcoma. Metastatic work-up consisting of nuclear bone scan and CT of the chest were negative. Amputation was offered by the local care team that included a radiation oncologist because of their concern about possible contamination of the joint space and uncertain functional outcome. The patient was referred to St. Jude Children's Hospital for further evaluation and treatment.
At the time of her evaluation after referral (January 2000), there was a well healed scar with no excessive swelling. There was mild tenderness on the lateral aspect of her left knee. Additional imaging studies showed abnormality at the site of prior surgery equivocal for residual tumor. There was no evidence of abnormality in the joint space. The tumor bed was explored. There was no physical evidence of compromise at the level of the joint space. She underwent wide local excision with placement of afterloading catheters. Six catheters were placed in a parallel
conversation:
Doctor: Hi, I'm Dr. Smith. Can you tell me about your history of pain and swelling about your left knee?

Patient: Yes, I had a fall a year ago and related all my symptoms to that fall. I was seen by my family physician in the emergency room, but there was no diagnosis or treatment.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And what happened prior to that?

Patient: About a month before that, I was struck in the left knee by a basketball and developed worsening pain.

Doctor: I see. And what did the orthopedic surgeon say about your condition?

Patient: They said I had a valgus posture of both my lower extremities, exaggerated on the left by external rotation, and I was walking with a mild limp.

Doctor: Okay. And did they find anything unusual about your knee?

Patient: They said my left knee had no effusion, but it was hypersensitive to light touch over the lateral aspect where there was soft tissue swelling just below the knee. There was no obvious mass in the area, but firm palpation was difficult because of my discomfort.

Doctor: I understand. And what did the plain films show?

Patient: They were normal. But an MR was ordered and it revealed an apparent meniscal cyst in the lateral aspect of my left knee.

Doctor: Okay. And what did the biopsy of the cystic structure reveal?

Patient: It revealed a high-grade synovial cell sarcoma.

Doctor: I see. And what did the metastatic work-up show?

Patient: It consisted of a nuclear bone scan and CT of the chest, and they were both negative.

Doctor: Okay. And what was the local care team's recommendation?

Patient: They offered amputation because of their concern about possible contamination of the joint space and uncertain functional outcome.

Doctor: I see. And that's why you were referred to St. Jude Children's Hospital for further evaluation and treatment?

Patient: Yes.

Doctor: Okay. And what was the situation when you were evaluated after referral?

Patient: There was a well healed scar with no excessive swelling. There was mild tenderness on the lateral aspect of my left knee. The imaging studies showed abnormality at the site of prior surgery, equivocal for residual tumor. There was no evidence of abnormality in the joint space.

Doctor: I see. And what did the tumor bed exploration show?

Patient: There was no physical evidence of compromise at the level of the joint space.

Doctor: Okay. And what was the treatment you underwent?

Patient: I underwent wide local excision with placement of afterloading catheters. Six catheters were placed in a parallel.

Doctor: Okay, I see. I'm going to recommend that you come back for a follow-up appointment in three months to check on your progress.

Patient: Okay, doctor.

data:
A 81-year old woman was referred to our department to evaluate a wound dehiscence on her left knee with hardware exposure. The patient did not have any relevant comorbidities and her general status was good. The patient underwent a total left hip arthroplasty at the age of seventy four due to severe osteoarthritis pain that hindered baseline activities. Eight years later, the patient presented to the orthopedics department with a progressive pain in the affected hip, particularly when walking, causing difficulties in deambulation.
An X ray examination revealed an extensive femoral bone loss with displacement of the femoral component, and an MRI showed a femoral pseudo-tumor (bone proliferation). With this finding, a revision total hip arthroplasty was performed with the insertion of a reconstruction ring with cemented dual mobility cups. Three weeks after this last surgery, the patient started with early symptoms of infection (high fever, suppuration, no wound healing and laboratory abnormalities); an attempt at conservative management with intravenous antibiotic, irrigation and suction drainages was unsuccessful and a replacement of the endoprosthesis femur in two stages was planned.
In the first stage, the previous prosthesis was removed with enlarged osteotomy of the anterior tuberosity and a cement spacer with antibiotic was placed. Two months later, the spacer was removed and a new coated silver total femoral prosthesis was placed. The patient was referred to our unit four weeks after the last surgery for the assessment of wound dehiscence to the lateral knee with hardware exposure. The patient was taken to the operating room for retention debridement and wound coverage with a flap. Our first decision was to cover the defect with a lateral gastrocnemius flap, however, the surrounding area was highly scarred, and the gastrocnemius muscle was found to be very atrophic and no suitable to fit the large defect. shows no other local flaps to be large enough to cover the whole defect, so we opted for a free flap.
A lack of receptor vessels was evidenced, descending genicular artery was dissected, but small caliber and calcified plaques in the lumen discarded

Patient: Yes, it's been bothering me for a while now. It's painful and there's some hardware showing.

Patient: No, I don't have any other medical problems.

Patient: Yes, I had severe osteoarthritis pain that hindered baseline activities, so I had the surgery when I was seventy-four.
Doctor: I see. Eight years later, you presented to the orthopedics department with a progressive pain in the affected hip, particularly when walking, causing difficulties in deambulation. An X-ray examination revealed an extensive femoral bone loss with displacement of the femoral component. Did you experience any other symptoms?
Patient: No, just the pain when walking.
Doctor: Okay. An MRI showed a femoral pseudo-tumor (bone proliferation), and with this finding, a revision total hip arthroplasty was performed with the insertion of a reconstruction ring with cemented dual mobility cups. How did you feel after the surgery?
Patient: I felt okay at first, but then I started experiencing early symptoms of infection about three weeks after the surgery.
Doctor: I see. The symptoms included high fever, suppuration, no wound healing, and laboratory abnormalities. An attempt at conservative management with intravenous antibiotic, irrigation, and suction drainages was unsuccessful, and a replacement of the endoprosthesis femur in two stages was planned. Do you remember this?
Patient: Yes, I remember the surgeries.
Doctor: In the first stage, the previous prosthesis was removed with enlarged osteotomy of the anterior tuberosity, and a cement spacer with antibiotic was placed. Two months later, the spacer was removed, and a new coated silver total femoral prosthesis was placed. You were referred to our unit four weeks after the last surgery for the assessment of wound dehiscence to the lateral knee with hardware exposure. Do you remember this?
Patient: Yes, that's why I'm here.
Doctor: I see. The patient was taken to the operating room for retention debridement and wound coverage with a flap. Our first decision was to cover the defect with a lateral gastrocnemius flap, however, the surrounding area was highly scarred, and the gastrocnemius muscle was found to be very atrophic and not suitable to fit the large defect. There were no other local flaps large enough to cover the whole defect, so we opted for a free flap. We evidenced a lack of receptor vessels, and the descending genicular artery was dissected, but small caliber and calcified plaques in the lumen discarded.

data:
A 54-year-old woman with a history of large goiter and liver function abnormalities was referred by her physician to the CAMC to address her multiple dietary supplement use. She was noted to have moderate liver function abnormalities (ALT 3 times normal range) during a medical evaluation. After extensive evaluation of her liver dysfunction no apparent causes were found. She did not drink alcohol or take any medications, and was of normal body weight. Infectious, obstructive and autoimmune causes were ruled out. She was noted to consume a number of dietary supplements and referred to our clinic to address dietary supplement polyherbacy and its potential affect on her liver function tests. She brought all her supplements for review. At that evaluation, we addressed the purpose of her use of each supplement ().
She reported adding more and more dietary supplements over the years, as she read extensively and frequently researched the internet for information on these products. Ultimately she felt at a loss as to which supplements might be of benefit or which supplements to stop taking. This patient typically would use less than the recommended dose noted on the label, but at times would use a higher than recommended dose. She also would vary which supplement she might use in any given day. She expressed concern that her dietary supplement intake had gotten out of control and felt she may be addicted to using supplements as they gave her a greater sense of control.
After discussing the purpose for using each dietary supplement and concerns with dietary supplement polypharmacy and its potential effect on her liver dysfunction, she agreed to stop all supplements for the time being, with the exception of calcium and vitamin D, and one multivitamin a day. Until her follow-up visit she would increase her dietary intake of antioxidant foods, acidophilus and omega 3 fatty acids in place of her supplements, and practice mind-body techniques and exercise for health and stress reduction. We also offered a referral to counseling for anxiety management. Follow-up liver function tests were normal. We proposed to
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you today?
Patient: I'm okay, thank you.
Doctor: Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of a large goiter and liver function abnormalities.
Doctor: I see. And why were you referred to us?
Patient: My physician referred me to address my multiple dietary supplement use.
Doctor: I understand. And you've had some liver function abnormalities, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I was noted to have moderate liver function abnormalities. My ALT was 3 times the normal range.
Doctor: Okay. And after evaluation, did we find the cause of your liver dysfunction?
Patient: No, after extensive evaluation, no apparent causes were found. I don't drink alcohol or take any medications, and I'm of normal body weight.
Doctor: I see. And have we ruled out infectious, obstructive, and autoimmune causes?
Patient: Yes, those causes were ruled out.
Doctor: And you were referred to our clinic because of your use of dietary supplements?
Patient: Yes, I was referred to address dietary supplement polyherbacy and its potential effect on my liver function tests.
Doctor: Okay. And you brought all your supplements for review, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I did.
Doctor: And you reported adding more and more dietary supplements over the years, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I read extensively and frequently researched the internet for information on these products.
Doctor: And you felt at a loss as to which supplements might be of benefit or which to stop taking?
Patient: Yes, I did. I felt like my dietary supplement intake had gotten out of control and I may be addicted to using supplements as they gave me a greater sense of control.
Doctor: I understand. And after discussing the purpose for using each dietary supplement and concerns with dietary supplement polypharmacy and its potential effect on your liver dysfunction, you agreed to stop all supplements for the time being, with the exception of calcium and vitamin D and one multivitamin a day, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And until your follow-up visit, you'll increase your dietary intake of antioxidant foods, acidophilus, and omega 3 fatty acids in place of your supplements, and practice mind-body techniques and exercise for health and stress reduction, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And we also offered a referral to counseling for anxiety management, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, you did.
Doctor: Great. And your follow-up liver function tests were normal, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, they were.
Doctor: That's great news. And we proposed to keep monitoring your liver function, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for your time today. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to us.
Patient: Thank you, doctor. I appreciate it.

data:
The 32-year-old female was referred to the center for vascular consultation. The patient was a house wife and a mother of two children. She reported having an episode of sudden onset severe headache associated with generalized tonic and clonic fits and loss of consciousness. She regained consciousness after a period of 24 h without any neurological deficit with a complaint of neck rigidity and headache. The patient had a past history of similar episodes dating back 1 year. Upon interview she recalled a long history of trivial headaches, malaise and low grade fever for the past 6 years, whose severity had never warranted any further investigation. She also had a history of intermittent claudication in her bilateral upper limbs. Physical examination revealed no neurological deficit, however, radial and brachial arteries were impalpable bilaterally. Right to left blood pressure discrepancies were detected, measuring at 140/80 from right arm and 160/80 from the left arm.
A CT brain was conducted that revealed subarachnoid hemorrhage with intraventricular extension (). Similar findings were evident in previous CT scan brain which was done 1 year ago at the previous presentation of ictus (). Laboratory investigation showed raised ESR upto 40 mm/h and C Reactive Protein was positive. Cerebral angiography and aortogram showed total occlusion of left common carotid artery from its origin and 90% occlusion of right common carotid artery from its origin with slightly dilated segment prior to its tapering (). The sole arteries supplying the intracranial circulation were bilateral vertebral arteries and showed saccular basilar tip aneurysm of size 7.30 x 5.39 mm (). Additional imaging showed bilateral occlusion of subclavian arteries from their initial segments. There were extensive collateral branches to intercostal arteries supplying both upper arms (). The terminal aorta was irregular but bilateral renal arteries and other branches of aorta were normal (). We started the patient on 20 mg prednisone resulting in a reduction of ESR as well as normalization of C Reactive Protein. Further the patient was referred for endovascular coil embolization as vertebral arteries were relatively straight and easy to access.
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?

Patient: Good morning doctor, I was referred here for a consultation.

Doctor: Okay, let's start with some basic information. Can you please tell me your name and age?

Patient: My name is [Patient's Name], and I am 32 years old.

Doctor: And what do you do for a living?

Patient: I am a housewife and a mother of two children.

Doctor: Okay, I see. Can you tell me what happened that brought you here today?

Patient: I reported having an episode of sudden onset severe headache associated with generalized tonic and clonic fits and loss of consciousness.

Doctor: Hmm, that's serious. Did you regain consciousness after the episode?

Patient: Yes, I regained consciousness after 24 hours without any neurological deficit, but I have a complaint of neck rigidity and headache.

Doctor: I see. Do you have a past history of similar episodes?

Patient: Yes, I have a history of similar episodes dating back 1 year.

Doctor: Okay, and what other symptoms have you been experiencing?

Patient: I recall a long history of trivial headaches, malaise, and low-grade fever for the past 6 years, but their severity never warranted any further investigation.

Doctor: And what about your limbs? Have you been experiencing any problems?

Patient: Yes, I have a history of intermittent claudication in my bilateral upper limbs.

Doctor: Alright, let's examine you now. Can you please remove your clothes and lie down on the bed?

Patient: Sure.

Doctor: (After examining the patient) Physical examination revealed no neurological deficit, however, radial and brachial arteries were impalpable bilaterally.

Doctor: We also detected right to left blood pressure discrepancies, measuring at 140/80 from your right arm and 160/80 from your left arm.

Doctor: To get a better understanding of your condition, we conducted a CT brain scan. The results showed subarachnoid hemorrhage with intraventricular extension.

Patient: Hmm, what does that mean?

Doctor: It means that there was bleeding in the brain and it extended into the ventricles.

Doctor: The previous CT scan brain which was done 1 year ago at the previous presentation of ictus showed similar findings.

Doctor: Our laboratory investigation showed raised ESR up to 40 mm/h and C Reactive Protein was positive.

Patient: What does that mean for me?

Doctor: It means that your body is fighting an infection.

Doctor: The cerebral angiography and aortogram showed total occlusion of your left common carotid artery from its origin and 90% occlusion of your right common carotid artery from its origin with a slightly dilated segment prior to its tapering.

Doctor: The sole arteries supplying the intracranial circulation were bilateral vertebral arteries and showed a saccular basilar tip aneurysm of size 7.30 x 5.39 mm.

Doctor: Additional imaging showed bilateral occlusion of subclavian arteries from their initial segments. There were extensive collateral branches to intercostal arteries supplying both upper arms.

Doctor: The terminal aorta was irregular but bilateral renal arteries and other branches of the aorta were normal.

Doctor: We started you on 20 mg prednisone, which resulted in a reduction of ESR as well as normalization of C Reactive Protein.

Doctor: Further, you were referred for endovascular coil embolization as your vertebral arteries were relatively straight and easy to access.

Doctor: I would like to see you again in a week to check on your progress.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you for explaining everything to me.

data: A 22 years old female patient reported to our department with a complaint of facial disfigurement on the left side of the face which gradually progressed over the past 14 years. Progressive atrophy on the left half of the face was initially noticed at the age of 8 years as an area of hyper pigmentation on the left malar area which gradually progressed with resultant atrophy of the underlying fat and subcutaneous tissue resulting in the present disfigurement (Fig. ). However it was not associated with any other symptoms except for the limited mouth opening which the patient experienced gradually as the condition progressed. The patient had not sought any consultation earlier, for the facial disfigurement. Her medical and family history was non contributory. On general physical examination patient was conscious, oriented, a febrile, general condition was fair and vital signs were stable. Right side of the face appeared normal with marked facial asymmetry noted on left side. Head and neck examination confirmed the asymmetry with flattening, hyperpigmented, parchment like overlying skin. There was an evident loss of underlying fat, muscle and subcutaneous tissue giving a sunken in appearance. Thinning of the lips on the affected side with exposition of the teeth due to the corner of the mouth pulled to left side. Ocular examination and skin examination showed no abnormality with any evidence of lymphadenopathy. There was no evidence of sensory or motor deficits on both sides. On palpation, the skin on the affected side was rigid with signs of sclerosis. TMJ on the affected side was tender with deviation to the left on mouth opening. Intraoral examination revealed normal moist mucosa but tense oral mucosa on the affected side. Tongue on the affected side showed marked atrophy on the left side with shift in the dorsal median fissure (Fig. ). Hard tissue examination revealed crowding of the teeth with shift in midline to the affected side and obliteration of the buccal and vestibular sulcus due to tense oral tissue. Upper and lower arch showed constriction of the arch with multiple carious teeth
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you to the clinic today?

Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have a complaint about my face.

Doctor: Okay, what kind of complaint is it?

Patient: I have a disfigurement on the left side of my face.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about it? How long have you had this problem?

Patient: I've had it for 14 years. It started as a small area of hyper pigmentation on my left cheek when I was 8 years old.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And what happened next?

Patient: It gradually became worse over time. The atrophy of the underlying fat and subcutaneous tissue caused the disfigurement that I have now.

Doctor: I understand. And did you have any other symptoms besides the disfigurement?

Patient: Yes, I have limited mouth opening. It gradually got worse as the condition progressed.

Doctor: Okay, I see. Have you sought any medical consultation for this before?

Patient: No, I haven't. This is my first time.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your medical and family history?

Patient: My medical and family history is not related to this condition.

Doctor: Alright. Let's do a physical examination. Can you lie down on the bed for me?

Patient: Sure.

[Doctor does a physical examination]

Doctor: Okay, you can sit up now. You are conscious and oriented. Your vital signs are stable. But I noticed some asymmetry on your face, particularly on the left side.

Patient: Yes, I know.

Doctor: I confirmed the asymmetry with flattening, hyperpigmented, parchment-like overlying skin. There is an evident loss of underlying fat, muscle, and subcutaneous tissue, giving a sunken-in appearance.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: And there is thinning of your lips on the affected side, with exposure of your teeth due to the corner of your mouth being pulled to the left side.

Patient: Yes, I noticed that too.

Doctor: Your ocular examination and skin examination showed no abnormality with any evidence of lymphadenopathy. There is no evidence of sensory or motor deficits on both sides.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: On palpation, the skin on the affected side is rigid with signs of sclerosis. Your TMJ on the affected side is tender with deviation to the left on mouth opening.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: Your intraoral examination revealed normal moist mucosa but tense oral mucosa on the affected side. Your tongue on the affected side showed marked atrophy on the left side with a shift in the dorsal median fissure.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Your hard tissue examination revealed crowding of your teeth with a shift in midline to the affected side and obliteration of your buccal and vestibular sulcus due to tense oral tissue. Your upper and lower arch showed constriction of the arch with multiple carious teeth.

Patient: Hmm, I see.

Doctor: Based on the examination, I think you have a condition that needs to be treated. I will refer you to a specialist for further evaluation and treatment.

Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.

Doctor: You're welcome. Please come back for a follow-up appointment in two weeks.

Patient: Alright, I will. Thank you, doctor.

data:
A 35 year old obese African American male, a mechanic by profession and no significant previous medical problems, came to the emergency room with left sided chest pain that started the night before and slowly got worse. By the time he reached the emergency room, the pain had reached 8 out of a maximum of10 in intensity. The pain was precipitated and aggravated by a stressful situation at home. It radiated to his left shoulder and was not relieved by rest. Patient had a five pack-year history of smoking but quit 10 years ago. He would occasionally drink alcohol. On further questioning, the patient revealed that he had been having mild left sided chest pains, sharp in nature and similar to the current episode, for the last few months. The pain would occur either with stress or exertion. He did not seek medical attention before because the pain would be transient and go away on its own after a few minutes. He was not on any medications and did not use any pain relieving medicines either for his prior symptoms.
In the emergency room, patient was in mild distress and had a blood pressure of 165/81, something new for him. All the rest of the vital signs were normal and both the cardiac and pulmonary examination did not reveal any abnormality either. The basic laboratory work up was normal except a lipid profile showing elevated cholesterol of 238 mg/dl. The patient had an electrocardiogram that showed some premature supraventricular complexes without any ischemic changes. Cardiac biomarkers including serial troponin-I were also normal. The chest pain subsided in the emergency room with intravenous morphine. The patient was admitted to the hospital in the telemetry unit. He was found to have some runs of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia while in the hospital. He underwent a cardiac exercise stress test and an echocardiogram which revealed that patient had a normal ejection fraction but a dilated left atrium along with apical wall motion abnormality.
Patient then underwent a cardiac catheterization. It did not show any obstruction in the coronary
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so good, doctor. I've been having chest pain for the past few days.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe the pain for me?
Patient: Yeah, it's a sharp pain on the left side of my chest. It started last night and got worse as the night went on.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. And was the pain precipitated or aggravated by anything in particular?
Patient: Yeah, it was stress at home that made it worse.
Doctor: I see. And did the pain radiate to any other parts of your body?
Patient: Yeah, it went all the way to my left shoulder.
Doctor: Okay. And was the pain relieved by rest?
Patient: No, it wasn't.
Doctor: Alright. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: Well, I used to smoke, but I quit 10 years ago. I have a five pack-year history of smoking. And I would drink alcohol occasionally.
Doctor: I see. And have you had any chest pains like this before?
Patient: Yeah, I have. I've been having mild left sided chest pains for the past few months. They would occur either with stress or exertion.
Doctor: I see. And did you seek any medical attention for those pains before?
Patient: No, I didn't. The pain would be transient and go away on its own after a few minutes.
Doctor: I see. And are you on any medications right now?
Patient: No, I'm not. And I didn't use any pain relieving medicines for my prior symptoms either.
Doctor: Alright. And when you came to the emergency room, what was your blood pressure?
Patient: It was 165/81.
Doctor: I see. And was that a new thing for you?
Patient: Yeah, it was.
Doctor: Alright. And what were the results of your cardiac and pulmonary examination?
Patient: They didn't reveal any abnormality.
Doctor: I see. And what about your basic laboratory work up?
Patient: It was normal, except for my lipid profile. My cholesterol was elevated, 238 mg/dl.
Doctor: I see. And what did your electrocardiogram show?
Patient: It showed some premature supraventricular complexes, but no ischemic changes.
Doctor: I see. And what about your cardiac biomarkers, including serial troponin-I?
Patient: They were normal.
Doctor: Alright. And I understand that the chest pain subsided in the emergency room with intravenous morphine.
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: Alright. And you were admitted to the telemetry unit in the hospital. I understand that you were found to have some runs of non-sustained ventricular tachycardia while in the hospital.
Patient: Yeah, that's right.
Doctor: Alright. And you underwent a cardiac exercise stress test and an echocardiogram. Can you tell me what they revealed?
Patient: Yeah, I had a normal ejection fraction, but a dilated left atrium along with apical wall motion abnormality.
Doctor: I see. And your cardiac catheterization, did it show any obstruction in the coronary?
Patient: No, it didn't.
Doctor: Alright. Well, based on all of these test results, I think we need to keep monitoring you and make sure everything is okay. I'll be in touch with you soon.
Patient: Alright, doctor. Thank you.
