data:
Staged bilateral total hip arthroplasties were performed on a 55-year-old man with a neglected untreated history of DDH, who gradually developed severe bilateral hip joint arthritis. The chief complains included bilateral hips and knee joints pain on walking associated with a progressive limitation in the range of hip motion and walking ability distance day after day. The history of the present problem went back to the age 45 with an incident of the low back pain repeated at the ages 50 and 52; each time relieved by conventional bed rest and other conservative measures. The progressive changes in lumbar spine (L2-L3) including discopathies and stenosis of the spinal canal were also contributed to his limitation of walking ability for last 10 years.
The patient was born as the last member of a large size family of a second degree consanguineous traditional marriage, with the maternal age 43, having 3 sisters and 4 brothers without hip disease. In the past medical history, the patient presented a history of the right nasolacrimal stenosis operated at the age of 3 and 8, right inguinal hernia operated for at 1 and 3. A suspected dentine dysplasia characterized by deciduous and permanent teeth with clinically normal appearing crowns, some hypermobility and spontaneous dental abscesses started in childhood and ended with the loss of all teeth at the age of 22 to 27. An unsuccessful closed reduction of the left hip joint at the age of 11 put in spica cast from the tip of the toe up to the chest level was performed and immobilized for 9 months. A history of night bedwetting, up to the age of 11, due to urinary reflux evolving in the left renal regression and hypoplasia, accidentally revealed upon a renal infection and diagnosed by renal angiography at the age of 22. A problem of ingrown toe nail started from the age of adolescence with multiple recurrence after a surgical correction was noticed. Two attacks of the left ear Menier’s disease reported to be experienced at the age of 33 and 44 years,
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Good morning doctor, I'm feeling okay.
Doctor: Can you tell me about your chief complains?
Patient: Yes, I have bilateral hips and knee joints pain on walking, and I have a progressive limitation in the range of hip motion and walking ability distance day after day.
Doctor: I see. And when did this start?
Patient: It started back when I was 45 with an incident of low back pain, and it happened again at the ages 50 and 52. But each time it was relieved by conventional bed rest and other conservative measures.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. And do you have any history of spinal problems?
Patient: Yes, I have progressive changes in my lumbar spine, including discopathies and stenosis of the spinal canal, which have contributed to my limitation of walking ability for the last 10 years.
Doctor: Okay, I see. And do you have any family history of hip disease?
Patient: No, I was born as the last member of a large size family of a second degree consanguineous traditional marriage, and my mother was 43 when I was born. I have 3 sisters and 4 brothers, and none of them have hip disease.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your past medical history?
Patient: Sure. I had a history of right nasolacrimal stenosis that was operated on twice at the ages of 3 and 8, and I also had a right inguinal hernia that was operated on twice at the ages of 1 and 3. I also had a suspected dentine dysplasia characterized by deciduous and permanent teeth with clinically normal appearing crowns, some hypermobility and spontaneous dental abscesses that started in childhood and ended with the loss of all my teeth at the ages of 22 to 27.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And what about your hip joint?
Patient: I had an unsuccessful closed reduction of my left hip joint when I was 11. I was put in a spica cast from the tip of my toe up to my chest level and was immobilized for 9 months.
Doctor: I see. And do you have any history of bedwetting?
Patient: Yes, I had a problem of night bedwetting up to the age of 11 due to urinary reflux, which eventually evolved into a left renal regression and hypoplasia. It was accidentally revealed upon a renal infection and was diagnosed by renal angiography at the age of 22.
Doctor: I see. And do you have any history of ingrown toe nail?
Patient: Yes, I have had a problem of ingrown toe nail since adolescence with multiple recurrences after a surgical correction.
Doctor: I see. And have you had any attacks of Menier's disease?
Patient: Yes, I have had two attacks of my left ear Menier's disease, which were reported to be experienced at the ages of 33 and 44.
Doctor: Okay, thank you for telling me about your medical history. Based on what you've told me, I think staged bilateral total hip arthroplasties would be the best course of treatment for your hip joint pain and progressive limitation in range of motion.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Great. After the arthroplasties, you will need to follow up with physical therapy to help you regain your range of motion and strength.
Patient: Okay, I'll make sure to do that.

data:
The patient is a male in his 60s with a past medical history significant for pulmonary sarcoidosis. He was referred to neurology clinic for progressive, bilateral, lower extremity numbness which he noted first in his feet. The patient indicated the pain and tingling in his feet worsened with prolonged standing and walking. He also endorsed lower back pain on follow-up visits. MRI of the thoracic cord demonstrated a longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis. The initial workup was unrevealing for an etiology and initial suspicions were that his condition was due to neurosarcoidosis. A lumbar puncture was performed and negative. Upon further review of the spinal imaging it was thought that there may be dilatation of the spinal epidural venous plexus, which would potentially indicate a dural arteriovenous fistula. The patient was then taken for a catheter angiogram for further evaluation.
During angiography, the left and right subclavian arteries were imaged to evaluate for spinal cord blood flow. An injection within the aorta was required to establish a road map for the left vertebral artery and the left vertebral artery origin from the aortic arch was found. An injection of the aortic arch origin of the vertebral artery revealed complete filling of all segments of the left vertebral artery. Retrograde filling of the left subclavian artery was seen indicating a potential dual origin from the left subclavian artery. A catheter was placed within the left subclavian and a second origin of the left vertebral artery was appreciated to originate and merge with the aortic V1 segment at the level of the C5 vertebrae (Figure ). Equal filling was seen from both the aortic and subclavian origin. No aneurysms or dissections were appreciated in either origin or at the confluence. When the right T7 spinal artery was injected, a dAVF was observed. The fistula originated from a distal branch of the spinal artery and combined with an anterior spinal vein with abnormal filling appreciated. The rest of the spinal arteries were interrogated and noted to be grossly normal without aneurysms, fistulas, or other vascular abnormalities.

data: A 54-year-old female, who was found to have incidental giant left ICA aneurysm on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan, during the workup for headaches (). There was no history of thunderclap headache or any associated visual or neurologic symptoms to suggest aneurysm rupture. Initial angiogram for evaluation of aneurysm, demonstrated a large left ICA para-ophthalmic aneurysm, measuring around 26×19 mm with a wide neck of 14 mm (). There was a patent anterior communicating artery with brisk cross filling of the left cerebral vasculature from the contralateral right side as well as patent left PCOM artery. Considering the complex anatomy, size of aneurysm and presence of good collaterals with patent anterior and PCOM artery, a plan was made in another hospital to treat the aneurysm with parent vessel occlusion rather than flow diverter stent. Subsequently, the aneurysm was treated in October 2016. Initially, a balloon occlusion test of the left ICA was performed which was negative for any neurological change during 20 minutes of balloon occlusion with blood pressure challenge as well. Subsequently, occlusion of the left ICA proximal to the aneurysm was performed using multiple coils (, ). There was no antegrade flow into the left ICA after occlusion with a patent flow into the left cerebral hemisphere through a patent anterior and PCOM arteries (, ). Angiogram of the left vertebral artery after occlusion of left ICA showed retrograde filling of the left ICA para-ophthalmic aneurysm (, ). This was considered to occlude overtime considering the competing antegrade intracranial flow. Patient remained asymptomatic after the treatment. Follow up angiogram after 6 months and 2 years demonstrated no antegrade flow in the left ICA, however there was persistent filling of the left ICA aneurysm in a retrograde fashion through the PCOM artery (). The aneurysm was followed up for another year and showed no evidence of occlusion with similar retrograde filling through the PCOM artery with no much change in its size. At this stage, considering the persistent filling of aneurysm, treatment was contemplated and the patient was transferred to our institution

data:
A 35-year-old white female who was an elite endurance athlete training for triathlons had a 3-year history of chronic left hip and groin pain which was subsequently investigated by MRI study. Her MRI of the hip and femur incidentally showed distention of the left common and external iliac veins with associated deep vein thrombosis.
At the time, she had no symptoms of leg pain or swelling and had no personal or family history of prior thrombotic events. She had a history of prolonged flights; however, none were taken immediately prior to her investigation. She was on oral contraceptives, which were subsequently discontinued, with no additional medications. She was a lifetime nonsmoker and had no symptoms to suggest concurrent pulmonary embolism. She had a prior hand surgery with no perioperative complications. Her examination was normal with no evidence of leg swelling or asymmetry and no evidence of postthrombotic syndrome.
She was started on anticoagulation and 3 weeks later had an ultrasound of her left lower limb that showed no evidence of deep vein thrombosis, which included the common femoral and external iliac veins. It was concluded that it was difficult to exclude a clot proximal to the iliac vein thus, she was continued on warfarin for 6 months. Following her anticoagulation, she underwent a MR angiogram and venogram. There was no evidence of deep vein thrombosis; however, there was significant narrowing of the upper aspect of the left common iliac vein just as it passed under the right common iliac artery prior to its joining with the right iliac vein. There was no associated dilation of the peripheral left iliac veins, and remaining veins were unremarkable for compression or malformation. These findings were highly suggestive of iliac vein compression. A thrombophilia screen was done following anticoagulation therapy, which showed the patient was heterozygous for Factor V Leiden mutation.
Soon afterward, the patient had a pelvic venogram illustrating stenosis of the left common iliac vein consistent with external compression with some collateral veins. Pressure measurements were done across the stenosis with a mean pressure gradient

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Have you had any tests done for this pain?

Doctor: Okay, did you have any symptoms of leg pain or swelling at the time of the MRI study?

Patient: No, I didn't have any symptoms of leg pain or swelling.

Doctor: Alright, do you have a personal or family history of prior thrombotic events?

Patient: No, I don't have any history of thrombotic events.

Doctor: Have you taken any prolonged flights recently?

Patient: No, I haven't taken any prolonged flights.

Doctor: Okay, were you on any oral contraceptives at the time of the MRI study?

Patient: Yes, I was on oral contraceptives but I discontinued them.

Doctor: Alright, were you taking any other medications at the time?

Patient: No, I wasn't taking any other medications.

Doctor: Are you a smoker?

Patient: No, I'm a lifetime nonsmoker.

Doctor: Alright, did you have any symptoms to suggest concurrent pulmonary embolism?

Patient: No, I didn't have any symptoms to suggest pulmonary embolism.

Doctor: Have you had any prior hand surgeries with any complications?

Patient: Yes, I had a prior hand surgery but I had no perioperative complications.

Doctor: Alright, during the examination, was there any evidence of leg swelling or asymmetry or postthrombotic syndrome?

Patient: No, there was no evidence of leg swelling or asymmetry and no evidence of postthrombotic syndrome.

Doctor: Okay, we started you on anticoagulation. Did you have an ultrasound of your left lower limb three weeks later?

Patient: Yes, I did.

Doctor: And what did it show?

Patient: It showed no evidence of deep vein thrombosis, including the common femoral and external iliac veins.

Doctor: Hmm, so it was difficult to exclude a clot proximal to the iliac vein. That's why we continued you on warfarin for six months.

Patient: Yes, I understand.

Doctor: Alright, you also underwent a MR angiogram and venogram. What did it show?

Patient: There was no evidence of deep vein thrombosis, but there was significant narrowing of the upper aspect of the left common iliac vein just as it passed under the right common iliac artery before it joined with the right iliac vein.

Doctor: Okay, and were there any associated dilation of the peripheral left iliac veins or any compression or malformation of the remaining veins?

Patient: No, there wasn't any dilation and the remaining veins were unremarkable for compression or malformation.

Doctor: Alright, so these findings were highly suggestive of iliac vein compression. A thrombophilia screen was done after anticoagulation therapy and it showed that you were heterozygous for Factor V Leiden mutation.

Patient: Yes, I was aware of that.

Doctor: Alright, and you also had a pelvic venogram which illustrated stenosis of the left common iliac vein consistent with external compression with some collateral veins. Pressure measurements were done across the stenosis with a mean pressure gradient.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

data:
A 51-year-old hypertensive Pakistani male patient was admitted in the cardiac intensive care unit in King Fahd University Hospital on 30 July 2017 complaining of chest and back pain for two weeks prior to the presentation; he took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but were not effective. Physical examination was done in the emergency department and revealed stable vital signs; the patient was conscious, moving all his limbs; there were warm palpable pulses of the upper arms.
The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down all the way to the level of renal arteries; there was enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with large aneurysmal dilatation (mural thrombus) and a compression of the true lumen (ascending aorta). Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. The aberrant right subclavian artery was noted crossing posterior to the trachea and arising as a last branch of the aortic arch distal to the left subclavian artery; also, the left vertebral artery was arising directly from the aortic arch. There was no other evidence of vascular dissection or occlusion below the level of the renal arteries (Figures and ).
The patient underwent general anesthesia for thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after his first day of admission; the procedure was done through the right femoral approach; an angiogram was performed intraoperatively (). Stent graft with a size of 34 mm × 15 cm was used and deployed into the descending thoracic aorta; the intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
The patient was postoperatively moving all his limbs, and the peripheral pulses were intact. He got discharged one day after the surgery and was doing well afterward. We evaluated patient's prognosis
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I am feeling much better now.
Doctor: I am glad to hear that. Can you tell me about the chest and back pain that brought you here?
Patient: I had been experiencing it for two weeks prior to my presentation.
Doctor: Did you take any medication for it?
Patient: Yes, I took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, but they were not effective.
Doctor: I see. During the physical examination, we found that your vital signs were stable. How were you feeling at that time?
Patient: I was conscious and moving all my limbs.
Doctor: That's great. The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down to the level of renal arteries. It also showed enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with a large aneurysmal dilatation and a compression of the true lumen. Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. 
Patient: Oh my, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it was. However, we underwent thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after your first day of admission. It was done through the right femoral approach, and a stent graft was used. The intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated.
Patient: I see. Did the procedure go well?
Doctor: Yes, it did. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
Patient: That's good news. How long do I need to stay here in the intensive care unit?
Doctor: You were discharged one day after the surgery and were doing well afterward. We have evaluated your prognosis and will instruct you on follow-up requirements. 
Patient: Thank you, doctor. What should I do next?
Doctor: We will give you instructions on postoperative care and schedule follow-up appointments to monitor your condition.

data:
A 19-year-old male had a history of road traffic accident 18 months back with severe head injury and pelvic fracture. He remained in the referring hospital for three months. After discharge he remained reasonably well except for occasional episodes of anterior chest pain and dyspnea on moderate exertion.
Recently he was admitted again through the emergency department with complain of severe chest pain along with shortness of breath. CT chest with intravenous contrast showed large aneurysm of the descending thoracic aorta distal to the origin of left subclavian artery causing compression on the origin of the left main bronchus, and on the right and left pulmonary arteries with no evidence of dissecting or contrast leak; however, the patient referred to the vascular surgical unit in our institute for further management.
After admission he complained of mild shortness of breath. His vital signs and his routine blood investigation were within normal limits. His chest radiograph showed normal bilateral lung fields.
He underwent endoluminal thoracic aortic stenting under general anesthesia. Postoperatively the patient started to complain of severe dyspnea and was desaturating. His immediate post-procedure routine chest X-ray revealed complete collapse of the left lung []. An urgent CT chest with intravenous contrast showed endovascular stent in place, but the aneurysmal sac was completely occluding the left main bronchus with complete collapse of the left lung but with adequate perfusion. The aneurysmal sac also had a mass compression on the adjacent right main pulmonary artery, which was compressed and stretched maximum at its proximal portion [].
Patient was stable hemodynamically and with relatively acceptable arterial blood gases.
He was monitored closely for possible emergency intervention with an endobronchial stent.
Although placement of an endobronchial stent in the left main bronchus can open the collapsed left lung, at the same time it may increase the pressure and can occlude the compressed right pulmonary artery supplying the only aerated right lung which could cause major morbidity, so, a conservative plan was adopted.
After 18 hours the apex of the left lung started to open up radiologically which
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, can you tell me your name please?

Patient: Hi, my name is [Patient's Name].

Doctor: Hi [Patient's Name], I understand that you have been admitted to the hospital with chest pain and shortness of breath. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?

Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing severe chest pain and shortness of breath for the past few days.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your medical history?

Patient: Sure, I had a road traffic accident 18 months back and suffered from a severe head injury and pelvic fracture.

Doctor: Okay. After the accident, did you experience any other symptoms besides the chest pain and shortness of breath?

Patient: Yes, I had occasional episodes of anterior chest pain and dyspnea on moderate exertion.

Doctor: Alright. And what happened recently that made you come to the hospital again?

Patient: I was admitted to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath.

Doctor: I see. We did a CT chest with intravenous contrast and it showed a large aneurysm of the descending thoracic aorta causing compression on the origin of the left main bronchus and on the right and left pulmonary arteries. The patient referred to the vascular surgical unit in our institute for further management.

Doctor: How were you feeling when you were admitted to the hospital?

Patient: I had mild shortness of breath.

Doctor: Alright. Your vital signs and routine blood investigation were within normal limits. And your chest radiograph showed normal bilateral lung fields.

Doctor: We performed an endoluminal thoracic aortic stenting under general anesthesia. But after the procedure, you started to complain of severe dyspnea and were desaturating.

Doctor: The immediate post-procedure chest X-ray revealed complete collapse of the left lung. An urgent CT chest with intravenous contrast showed the aneurysmal sac completely occluding the left main bronchus with complete collapse of the left lung but with adequate perfusion. The aneurysmal sac also had a mass compression on the adjacent right main pulmonary artery, which was compressed and stretched maximum at its proximal portion.

Doctor: You were stable hemodynamically and with relatively acceptable arterial blood gases. We monitored you closely for possible emergency intervention with an endobronchial stent.

Doctor: Although placement of an endobronchial stent in the left main bronchus can open the collapsed left lung, it may increase the pressure and can occlude the compressed right pulmonary artery supplying the only aerated right lung, which could cause major morbidity. So, we adopted a conservative plan.

Doctor: After 18 hours, the apex of the left lung started to open up radiologically.

Doctor: We will continue to monitor you closely and keep you updated on any further developments.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Is there anything else you would like to ask or discuss with me?

Patient: No, I think that's all for now. Thank you.

Doctor: You're welcome. We will keep you under close observation and take good care of you.

data: An 86-year old woman presented at the emergency department suffering from severe acute upper abdominal pain. Her past medical history included hypertension, diabetes mellitus, coronary heart disease, atrial fibrillation, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and twenty years before she had an omphalocele repair. The patient was in a close clinical and radiological follow up for monitoring a pancreatic serous cystadenoma diagnosed incidentally with a computed tomography (CT) scan 10 years earlier. The lesion was extensively studied with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), endoscopic ultrasound (EUS), fine needle aspiration (FNA), serology and blood test screening. At that time she was addressed for a routine year follow up scan which she attended regularly for six years. Patient did not attend her follow up time table for the last four years. Upon admission to the emergency department, chest and abdominal x-rays were performed and turned out inconclusive. Routine laboratory studies revealed marked leukocytosis, severe anemia, and blood glucose levels exceeding 500 mg/dl. Due to inconclusive diagnosis, an intravenous contrast CT scan was ordered and revealed a large amount of free peritoneal air and free fluid. (Figure , ) Moreover, a left upper quadrant 17 cm large mass originating from the stomach was revealed along with secondary liver lesions. An urgent laparotomy showed a prepyloric ulcer perforation and a large inoperable mass arising from the pancreatic body and largely invading the posterior wall of the stomach occupying the upper abdomen with multiple hepatic secondary lesions. A liver biopsy was taken, the stomach perforation was sutured closed and a washout was performed. The histopathologic findings from the biopsy material were consisted of small and medium size cystic lesions surrounded and divided by hyalloid collagenous matrix. The cysts were lined by cuboidal epithelial cells with clear cytoplasm and round nuclei without atypical or mitotic activity as demonstrated by pathology. The glycogen content was documented by PAS positive reaction. These findings were consistent with serous microcystic adenoma of the pancreas and the malignant nature of the tumor was confirmed by the presence of the extensive invasive large inoperable pancreatic mass with hepatic

data:
A 28-year-old male presented with a painless swelling in the volar aspect of right mid forearm of 10 years duration with complaints of increase in size of the swelling associated with pain for the past two years. He complained of pain and paresthesia in the median nerve distribution of the right hand. The swelling measured 6 cms in length and 5 cms in width. The swelling was mobile on the transverse axis and not on the longitudinal axis. There was no motor weakness. There was normal protective sensation present in the hand. Percussion over the nerve produced positive Tinel’s sign. There was no family history of neurofibromatosis and no associated clinical features. The ultrasound showed that the mass was subcutaneous although limited and homogeneous measuring 6 cm in diameter. The patient refused to undergo MRI examination due to financial constraints. A surgical workup and a preoperative anaesthetist assessment were obtained. With a clinical diagnosis of median nerve tumor the patient was planned for excision of the tumor. The patient was explained regarding the neurological deficit following surgery and that she may need a sural nerve graft. The patient was taken up for surgery in supraclavicular block with bupivacaine and Xylocaine under tourniquet control.
Adequate exposure of the nerve was done both proximal and distal to the tumour (). On exploration the tumour was found to be arising from the median nerve in the right mid forearm. It was a well encapsulated greyish tumour () placed in an eccentric position to the axis of the nerve (). The vascular pedicle in the proximal part of the tumour is identified first and the remaining tumour was gently resected using microsurgical techniques. The specimen was sent for histopathological examination. Histopathological examination of the masses revealed typical features of schwannoma with presence of spindle cells forming Verocay bodies and clearly identified Antony A and B areas (). At two months follow-up the patient was symptom free with mild paresthesia in his index and middle fingers. There was no motor deficit or pain and no recurrence of the
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you today?

Patient: I'm good, thanks.

Doctor: So, I understand you presented with a swelling in your right forearm. Can you tell me more about it?

Patient: Yes, I have a swelling in my right forearm for 10 years now. It started as a painless swelling, but for the past two years, it's been getting bigger and causing me pain.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. And do you have any other symptoms besides the swelling and pain?

Patient: Yes, I have paresthesia in my right hand, especially in the median nerve distribution.

Doctor: Okay. And can you describe the swelling for me?

Patient: It's about 6 cm long and 5 cm wide. It's mobile on the transverse axis, but not on the longitudinal axis.

Doctor: And is there any motor weakness in your hand?

Patient: No, there's no motor weakness.

Doctor: That's good. And is there any protective sensation present in your hand?

Patient: Yes, I have normal protective sensation.

Doctor: Okay. And when I tap over the nerve, do you feel any tingling or numbness?

Patient: Yes, it produces a positive Tinel's sign.

Doctor: I see. And is there any family history of neurofibromatosis?

Patient: No, there's no family history of neurofibromatosis.

Doctor: Alright. We did an ultrasound, and it showed that the mass is subcutaneous, limited, and homogeneous, measuring 6 cm in diameter. However, the patient refused to undergo MRI examination due to financial constraints.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: Alright. Based on the information we have, I have a clinical diagnosis of median nerve tumor. I'm planning to perform an excision of the tumor.

Patient: Okay, what does that mean?

Doctor: It means that I'll be removing the tumor from your forearm. But there's a chance that you may experience a neurological deficit following the surgery, and you may need a sural nerve graft.

Patient: I see.

Doctor: And we'll be performing the surgery under a supraclavicular block with bupivacaine and Xylocaine, under tourniquet control.

Patient: Alright.

Doctor: And during the surgery, we'll be exploring the nerve and removing the tumor. It's well encapsulated and placed in an eccentric position to the axis of the nerve. We'll be using microsurgical techniques to gently resect the tumor.

Patient: Okay, got it.

Doctor: And after the surgery, we'll send the specimen for histopathological examination. The examination revealed typical features of schwannoma, with the presence of spindle cells forming Verocay bodies and clearly identified Antony A and B areas.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: And at your two-month follow-up, you were symptom-free with mild paresthesia in your index and middle fingers. There was no motor deficit or pain, and no recurrence of the tumor.

Patient: That's great!

Doctor: Yes, it is. And I'll see you in another two months for a follow-up appointment.

Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.

data: A 29 years old male patient was taken to our emergency department within one hour of following motor vehicle accident. He complained of severe chest and back pain. On examination he was alert, conscious with pulse rate of 134 per minute, blood pressure of 86/64 mm/Hg, the extremities were cold and clammy. On auscultation, the heart sounds were audible without any adventitious sounds. The breath sounds were diminished in the left lower chest. A chest x-ray was done which revealed multiple rib fracture with mediastinal widening and left pleural effusion. In view of excruciating chest and back pain with features of hemorrhagic shock, a suspicion of aortic injury was made and hence an urgent emergency department CT scan was done after that the patient was shifted quickly to the emergency operation theater without waiting for the reports and the CT film. While shifting to the operation theater the film was obtained on the operation theater console which revealed a contained ruptured aortic rupture immediately below the level of isthmus (). An intervention cardiologist opinion was sought for endovascular stenting but in view of lacerated aorta involving more than 50% of its circumference at the site of injury, it was not possible and hence an urgent open surgical technique was advised. The patient was taken to operation theatre and intubated with single lung tube. He was positioned in right lateral position. A left posterolateral thoracotomy was done and the chest cavity was entered through the fifth intercostal space. A huge contained hematoma was noted. The patient was heparinized a plan to conduct surgery on left heart bypass on normothermia was decided. One of the 16Fr aortic cannula was inserted to the left superior pulmonary vein as outflow circuit and another 18Fr aortic cannula was inserted to the descending thoracic aorta just above the level of diaphragm as inflow circuit and the circuit was connected to the heart and lung machine. The bypass was initiated at flow rate of 1500 mL/min. A cross clamp was applied 2 cm below the origin of left subclavian artery
conversation:
Doctor: Hi there, what brings you to the emergency department today?

Patient: I was in a motor vehicle accident and I have severe chest and back pain.

Doctor: Okay, let me take a look at you. Can you tell me your pulse rate and blood pressure?

Patient: I don't know, I just know it hurts really bad.

Doctor: Alright, your pulse rate is 134 per minute and your blood pressure is 86/64 mm/Hg. Your extremities are cold and clammy. Can you tell me if you have any other symptoms?

Patient: Hmm, no, just the chest and back pain.

Doctor: Okay, I see. On auscultation, the heart sounds were audible without any adventitious sounds. The breath sounds were diminished in the left lower chest. We did a chest x-ray and it revealed multiple rib fractures with mediastinal widening and left pleural effusion.

Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: It means that you have some fractures in your ribs and there is a buildup of fluid in your chest. In view of your severe chest and back pain with features of hemorrhagic shock, we suspected an aortic injury and performed a CT scan.

Patient: Oh no, what did the scan show?

Doctor: The CT scan showed that you had a contained ruptured aortic rupture immediately below the level of isthmus. We sought an intervention cardiologist's opinion for endovascular stenting, but in view of the lacerated aorta involving more than 50% of its circumference at the site of injury, it was not possible. So, an urgent open surgical technique was advised.

Patient: What does that mean for me?

Doctor: It means that you need surgery to repair the aortic rupture. You were taken to the operation theater and intubated with a single lung tube. You were positioned in a right lateral position and a left posterolateral thoracotomy was performed. During the surgery, we found a huge contained hematoma.

Patient: What did you do next?

Doctor: We decided to conduct surgery on your left heart bypass on normothermia. We inserted one of the 16Fr aortic cannulas to the left superior pulmonary vein as an outflow circuit and another 18Fr aortic cannula to the descending thoracic aorta just above the level of the diaphragm as an inflow circuit. The circuit was connected to the heart and lung machine, and the bypass was initiated at a flow rate of 1500 mL/min. A cross clamp was applied 2 cm below the origin of the left subclavian artery.

[Patient's Family Joins]

Family Member: How is he doing now?

Doctor: I'm sorry, but despite our best efforts, the patient didn't make it through the surgery. We did everything we could, but the injury was too severe.

Family Member: (crying) Thank you for everything. Can we see him now?

Doctor: Of course. I'll take you to him now.

data:
A 51-year-old hypertensive Pakistani male patient was admitted in the cardiac intensive care unit in King Fahd University Hospital on 30 July 2017 complaining of chest and back pain for two weeks prior to the presentation; he took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but were not effective. Physical examination was done in the emergency department and revealed stable vital signs; the patient was conscious, moving all his limbs; there were warm palpable pulses of the upper arms.
The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down all the way to the level of renal arteries; there was enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with large aneurysmal dilatation (mural thrombus) and a compression of the true lumen (ascending aorta). Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. The aberrant right subclavian artery was noted crossing posterior to the trachea and arising as a last branch of the aortic arch distal to the left subclavian artery; also, the left vertebral artery was arising directly from the aortic arch. There was no other evidence of vascular dissection or occlusion below the level of the renal arteries (Figures and ).
The patient underwent general anesthesia for thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after his first day of admission; the procedure was done through the right femoral approach; an angiogram was performed intraoperatively (). Stent graft with a size of 34 mm × 15 cm was used and deployed into the descending thoracic aorta; the intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
The patient was postoperatively moving all his limbs, and the peripheral pulses were intact. He got discharged one day after the surgery and was doing well afterward. We evaluated patient's prognosis
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I am feeling much better now.
Doctor: I am glad to hear that. Can you tell me about the chest and back pain that brought you here?
Patient: I had been experiencing it for two weeks prior to my presentation.
Doctor: Did you take any medication for it?
Patient: Yes, I took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, but they were not effective.
Doctor: I see. During the physical examination, we found that your vital signs were stable. How were you feeling at that time?
Patient: I was conscious and moving all my limbs.
Doctor: That's great. The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down to the level of renal arteries. It also showed enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with a large aneurysmal dilatation and a compression of the true lumen. Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. 
Patient: Oh my, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it was. However, we underwent thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after your first day of admission. It was done through the right femoral approach, and a stent graft was used. The intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated.
Patient: I see. Did the procedure go well?
Doctor: Yes, it did. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
Patient: That's good news. How long do I need to stay here in the intensive care unit?
Doctor: You were discharged one day after the surgery and were doing well afterward. We have evaluated your prognosis and will instruct you on follow-up requirements. 
Patient: Thank you, doctor. What should I do next?
Doctor: We will give you instructions on postoperative care and schedule follow-up appointments to monitor your condition.

data:
A 44-year-old Caucasian female referred to the ER with acute abdominal pain. Past medical history revealed no family history of colon cancer and no history of smoke. At the admission, physical examination revealed pain and tenderness in the right lower quadrant with no signs of bowel obstruction, mimicking an acute appendicitis. Laboratory investigation has not shown important pathological signs. Ultrasonography examination of the abdomen showed a contracted gallbladder with normal bile ducts, no pathologies affecting the pancreas and neither free fluid, nor signs of acute appendicitis. In consideration of the clinical status of the patient and the persistent acute abdominal pain even with a negative ultrasound, a CT scan was performed to better comprehend the nature of the underling pathology. CT scan was performed four hours after the hospital admission, and demonstrated a thickened cecal wall with a small number of pathological nearby lymph nodes, confirming the absence of peritoneal free fluid. Given the absence of radiological signs of GI perforations and of other surgical and medical emergencies, we decided to perform a colonoscopy to better understand the etiology of the underling pathology. Colonoscopy was performed 24 hours after the hospital admission and after an adequate bowel preparation and revealed a massive, ulcerated, stenotic and necrotic lesion that involved the caecum and the right colon. Biopsies of the lesion were performed and the microscopic examination showed a cell proliferation composed by large, pleomorphic cellular elements with vesicular nuclei, hyperchromatic nucleoli and eosinophilic cytoplasm, mixed with necrotic tissue. These findings were consistent with the diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma ().
For these reasons, a laparoscopic right colectomy in an elective setting was performed, together with an accurate lymphadenectomy. Surgical exploration of the abdominal cavity confirmed the absence of peritoneal carcinosis and distant metastasis. Pathological examination of the surgical specimen revealed an ulcerated lesion of the right colon with a 6 cm diameter, composed of a whitish and compact tissue, with hard consistency and infiltrative margins that extended to the perivisceral adipose tissue. Microscopic examination discovered a poorly differentiated neoplastic epithelial tumor, rich in mitosis,
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

Patient: I'm not feeling well, doctor. I have been experiencing acute abdominal pain for the past few days.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your medical history?

Patient: Well, I don't have any family history of colon cancer and I have never smoked.

Doctor: Okay, thank you. Can you describe the pain you have been experiencing?

Patient: The pain is in my right lower quadrant and it's quite tender.

Doctor: I see. When you were admitted to the ER, did the physical examination show any signs of bowel obstruction?

Patient: No, there were no signs of bowel obstruction.

Doctor: Okay, thank you. An ultrasound was performed and it showed a contracted gallbladder with normal bile ducts, no pathologies affecting the pancreas and neither free fluid nor signs of acute appendicitis.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Doctor: However, considering the persistent pain and the negative ultrasound results, we decided to perform a CT scan to better understand the nature of the underlying pathology.

Patient: Okay, I see.

Doctor: The CT scan was performed four hours after your admission and it demonstrated a thickened cecal wall with a small number of pathological nearby lymph nodes, confirming the absence of peritoneal free fluid.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Doctor: Given the absence of radiological signs of GI perforations and other surgical and medical emergencies, we decided to perform a colonoscopy to better understand the etiology of the underlying pathology.

Patient: Okay, I understand.

Doctor: The colonoscopy was performed 24 hours after your admission and after an adequate bowel preparation and it revealed a massive, ulcerated, stenotic, and necrotic lesion that involved the caecum and the right colon.

Patient: Oh no.

Doctor: Biopsies of the lesion were performed and the microscopic examination showed a cell proliferation composed of large, pleomorphic cellular elements with vesicular nuclei, hyperchromatic nucleoli, and eosinophilic cytoplasm, mixed with necrotic tissue. These findings were consistent with the diagnosis of poorly differentiated carcinoma.

Patient: Oh my God.

Doctor: In light of these findings, a laparoscopic right colectomy in an elective setting was performed, together with an accurate lymphadenectomy.

Patient: What does that mean, doctor?

Doctor: It means that we performed a surgical procedure to remove the right colon and the surrounding lymph nodes.

Patient: I see.

Doctor: Surgical exploration of the abdominal cavity confirmed the absence of peritoneal carcinosis and distant metastasis.

Patient: That's good to hear.

Doctor: The pathological examination of the surgical specimen revealed an ulcerated lesion of the right colon with a 6 cm diameter, composed of a whitish and compact tissue, with hard consistency and infiltrative margins that extended to the perivisceral adipose tissue. Microscopic examination discovered a poorly differentiated neoplastic epithelial tumor, rich in mitosis.

Patient: What happens next, doctor?

Doctor: We will need to monitor your progress and schedule follow-up appointments to ensure that you are recovering well. We will also need to discuss further treatment options with you.

data:
A 17-year-old Malay girl was involved in a road traffic accident in which she sustained a closed right femur fracture. She was treated with intramedullary nailing of the right femur. She was well until two years after the initial trauma when she met with another road traffic accident. The patient fell off her motorcycle and was brought to our centre with severe right thigh pain. Clinically, the right thigh was deformed with no obvious open wound. There was no other associated injury and the neurovascular status was intact. A plain radiograph shown 30° varus angulation of the femoral nail in the AP view and 30° anterior angulation in the lateral view with the continuity of the nail intact (). The fracture site was noted to be not united with minimal callus formation. It was decided to remove the nail surgically. The surgery was done under regional (spinal) anaesthesia with the patient being placed in the left lateral decubitus position. A skin incision was made by a lateral approach at the fracture site under image intensifier guidance. The tissue was divided layer by layer until the fracture site and the fibrous tissue around it was cleared up.
The initial technique attempted was based on the principle of partially weakening the nail followed by manual straightening. The bent nail was partially resected using a jumbo cutter through the wound, then reduction was attempted using the bone holder forceps placed at the proximal and distal part of the fracture site and the strength was applied to straighten the bent nail. However, the correction failed. We then proceeded with the second technique of fully cutting the nail and then extracting it into two different pieces. The distal locking screw was removed, followed by removal of the proximal locking screw. Manual traction was applied as a distraction at the fracture site to fully visualise the apex of angulation of the bent nail. A Jumbo cutter was introduced up to the visible nail and it was sectioned by multiple bites into two parts as shown in . Continuous saline

data: A 22 year old male patient had sustained chest injury by a metal splinter under moderate velocity. He presented with an entry wound in the 9th intercostal space, anterior axillary line on the right side. He was hemodynamically stable and had no respiratory symptoms or signs and abdomen was normal. Two coordinates of X-ray chest revealed the presence of foreign body in the (R) hemithorax, we suspected that the foreign body could be in the thoracoabdominal cavity based on the mechanism of injury. CT scan confirmed our suspicion that a sharp foreign body was indeed in the (R) thoracic cavity, not close to major vessels. There was a minimal pneumothorax which was not evident clinically. This sharp foreign body mandated removal. We decided to try minimal access surgery but with full preparations for open thoracotomy in case of failure. He needed one lung ventilation as a prerequisite for thoracoscopy. Hence the procedure was done under general anesthesia and intubated with a double lumen tube. He was placed on the anterolateral right thoracotomy position. Single lung ventilation was instituted. In addition CO2 insufflation was given up to 5mm Hg, for safer initial trocar placement and better visualization of hemithorax. A 10mm camera port was placed in the (R) 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line. A 5 mm working port was placed in the same intercostal space. The foreign body was seen on the inferior surface of the lung and removed through the 10 mm port Figures and . The rest of the thoracic cavity and diaphragm were found to be normal. An intercostal tube was placed in the 10 mm port site. He had no adverse event intraoperatively and promptly recovered from anesthesia, with a well expanded lung that was confirmed clinically and with a bedside X ray. However, we still continued to ventilate him electively for 18 hours as our experience with one lung ventilation is limited. He was extubated and ICD removed the same day. He was discharged on the second postoperative day. He is followed up regularly and is
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning! How are you feeling today?
Patient: Good morning, Doctor. I'm feeling okay.
Doctor: Can you tell me what happened to your chest?
Patient: I had a chest injury from a metal splinter.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the injury?
Patient: Sure. I had an entry wound in the 9th intercostal space, anterior axillary line on the right side.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. And when you presented, were you experiencing any respiratory symptoms or signs?
Patient: No, I wasn't experiencing any respiratory symptoms or signs.
Doctor: That's good. And how was your abdomen?
Patient: My abdomen was normal.
Doctor: Okay. We did some X-ray coordinates and found the presence of a foreign body in your right hemithorax. Based on the mechanism of injury, we suspected that the foreign body could be in the thoracoabdominal cavity.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: And the CT scan confirmed our suspicion. There was a sharp foreign body in the right thoracic cavity, but it was not close to major vessels.
Patient: Is that a problem?
Doctor: No, it's not a problem. But we need to remove it. There was also a minimal pneumothorax, but it wasn't evident clinically.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We decided to try minimal access surgery, but with full preparations for open thoracotomy in case of failure. You needed one lung ventilation as a prerequisite for thoracoscopy.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: The procedure was done under general anesthesia and you were intubated with a double lumen tube. You were placed on the anterolateral right thoracotomy position. Single lung ventilation was instituted. In addition, CO2 insufflation was given up to 5mm Hg for safer initial trocar placement and better visualization of the hemithorax.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: A 10mm camera port was placed in the right 5th intercostal space in the anterior axillary line. A 5 mm working port was placed in the same intercostal space. The foreign body was seen on the inferior surface of the lung and removed through the 10 mm port. The rest of the thoracic cavity and diaphragm were found to be normal.
Patient: That's good to hear.
Doctor: Yes, it is. An intercostal tube was placed in the 10 mm port site. You had no adverse event intraoperatively and promptly recovered from anesthesia, with a well-expanded lung that was confirmed clinically and with a bedside X-ray.
Patient: That's great.
Doctor: However, we continued to ventilate you electively for 18 hours as our experience with one lung ventilation is limited.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: You were extubated and the ICD was removed the same day. You were discharged on the second postoperative day.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: And we'll be following up with you regularly. Is there anything else you would like to know or ask?
Patient: No, I think that's all for now. Thank you, Doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome! If you have any other questions in the future, don't hesitate to ask. Take care.

data: A 32-year-old man sustained injury to his right leg in a road traffic accident five years ago. He had mangled leg which resulted in a below knee amputation done at a local hospital. The stump had healed with secondary intention owing to insufficient soft tissue cover and infection []. He was fitted with prosthesis and was allowed ambulation. However, the loading area of the stump had repeated breakdown and the stump became extremely sensitive and painful. He was unable to wear the prosthesis and bear weight on the stump. The bone length was maintained at 12 cm below the tibial plateau and soft tissue cover was possible only at the expense of the shortening of the stump. Salvage of the stump was only possible with adequate soft tissue cover. Reconstruction of the stump was planned with anterolateral thigh flap from the opposite side. The scar tissue was excised completely till the bone. About 2 cm tibial end was projecting in the wound []. A 14 × 14cms flap along with vastus lateralis muscle was harvested with the patient in supine position. Subsequently the patient was made to lie prone for recipient vessel dissection in the popliteal fossa. Anastomosis was done end-to-end to popliteal vessels with minimal vessel diameter discrepancy []. The vastus lateralis muscle in the flap covered the bony stump and flap was insetted snugly to the defect without any redundancy. Duration of the operation was six hours. The postoperative period was uneventful, and skin grafted donor site healed satisfactorily. The patient was discharged on 16th post operative day. He was refitted with prosthesis 10 weeks after the surgery. He is a school teacher by profession and he is on the prosthesis for approximately 70 hours per week. He is symptom free at 20 months after the surgery and flap does not show any atrophy or redundancy []. He experienced remarkable improvement and can stand for 5 hours at a stretch without any pain. His pain free walking distance has increased from half a mile preoperatively to two miles post-operatively []. Although
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

Patient: I'm okay, doctor. How about you?

Doctor: I'm good, thanks for asking. Can you tell me about your injury?

Patient: Yes, I got injured in a road traffic accident five years ago. I had a below knee amputation done at a local hospital. 

Doctor: I see. And how has the stump been healing?

Patient: It healed with secondary intention owing to insufficient soft tissue cover and infection. 

Doctor: Hmm, I understand. Were you fitted with a prosthesis?

Patient: Yes, I was. But the loading area of the stump had repeated breakdown and it became extremely sensitive and painful. I was unable to wear the prosthesis and bear weight on the stump.

Doctor: I see. And what was the bone length maintained at?

Patient: The bone length was maintained at 12 cm below the tibial plateau and soft tissue cover was possible only at the expense of the shortening of the stump.

Doctor: Okay. And what was the plan for the stump?

Patient: Salvage of the stump was only possible with adequate soft tissue cover. So, reconstruction of the stump was planned with anterolateral thigh flap from the opposite side.

Doctor: I see. And what was done during the surgery?

Patient: The scar tissue was excised completely till the bone. About 2 cm tibial end was projecting in the wound. A 14 × 14cms flap along with vastus lateralis muscle was harvested with me in supine position. And then I was made to lie prone for recipient vessel dissection in the popliteal fossa. Anastomosis was done end-to-end to popliteal vessels with minimal vessel diameter discrepancy.

Doctor: Wow, that was a long operation. How long did it take?

Patient: The duration of the operation was six hours.

Doctor: And how was the postoperative period?

Patient: The postoperative period was uneventful, and the skin grafted donor site healed satisfactorily. 

Doctor: That's great to hear. When were you discharged?

Patient: I was discharged on the 16th postoperative day.

Doctor: And when were you refitted with the prosthesis?

Patient: I was refitted with the prosthesis 10 weeks after the surgery.

Doctor: And how has it been going?

Patient: It's been going great. I'm a school teacher by profession and I'm on the prosthesis for approximately 70 hours per week. I'm symptom-free at 20 months after the surgery and the flap does not show any atrophy or redundancy.

Doctor: That's great to hear. Have you experienced any improvement?

Patient: Yes, I have. I experienced remarkable improvement and I can stand for 5 hours at a stretch without any pain. My pain-free walking distance has increased from half a mile preoperatively to two miles post-operatively. 

Doctor: That's amazing. You've made a great recovery. Do you have any concerns?

Patient: No, I don't have any concerns.

Doctor: Okay, great. I'll see you again in a few months for a follow-up.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

data:
A 51-year-old hypertensive Pakistani male patient was admitted in the cardiac intensive care unit in King Fahd University Hospital on 30 July 2017 complaining of chest and back pain for two weeks prior to the presentation; he took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs but were not effective. Physical examination was done in the emergency department and revealed stable vital signs; the patient was conscious, moving all his limbs; there were warm palpable pulses of the upper arms.
The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down all the way to the level of renal arteries; there was enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with large aneurysmal dilatation (mural thrombus) and a compression of the true lumen (ascending aorta). Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. The aberrant right subclavian artery was noted crossing posterior to the trachea and arising as a last branch of the aortic arch distal to the left subclavian artery; also, the left vertebral artery was arising directly from the aortic arch. There was no other evidence of vascular dissection or occlusion below the level of the renal arteries (Figures and ).
The patient underwent general anesthesia for thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after his first day of admission; the procedure was done through the right femoral approach; an angiogram was performed intraoperatively (). Stent graft with a size of 34 mm × 15 cm was used and deployed into the descending thoracic aorta; the intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
The patient was postoperatively moving all his limbs, and the peripheral pulses were intact. He got discharged one day after the surgery and was doing well afterward. We evaluated patient's prognosis
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Hi, doctor. I am feeling much better now.
Doctor: I am glad to hear that. Can you tell me about the chest and back pain that brought you here?
Patient: I had been experiencing it for two weeks prior to my presentation.
Doctor: Did you take any medication for it?
Patient: Yes, I took nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, but they were not effective.
Doctor: I see. During the physical examination, we found that your vital signs were stable. How were you feeling at that time?
Patient: I was conscious and moving all my limbs.
Doctor: That's great. The CTA of the aorta revealed a large dissection flap from the origin of the left subclavian artery extending down to the level of renal arteries. It also showed enlargement of the false lumen at the proximal aorta with a large aneurysmal dilatation and a compression of the true lumen. Additionally, there was a large entry point seen 2 cm distal to the right subclavian artery. 
Patient: Oh my, that sounds serious.
Doctor: Yes, it was. However, we underwent thoracic endovascular repair (TEVAR) two days after your first day of admission. It was done through the right femoral approach, and a stent graft was used. The intimal entry tear was completely covered by the stent, and the false lumen was obliterated.
Patient: I see. Did the procedure go well?
Doctor: Yes, it did. A postdeployment angiogram revealed successful proximal occlusion of the entry point with no perfusion of the false lumen and good flow through both carotid and left vertebral arteries as well as patent right and left subclavian arteries.
Patient: That's good news. How long do I need to stay here in the intensive care unit?
Doctor: You were discharged one day after the surgery and were doing well afterward. We have evaluated your prognosis and will instruct you on follow-up requirements. 
Patient: Thank you, doctor. What should I do next?
Doctor: We will give you instructions on postoperative care and schedule follow-up appointments to monitor your condition.

data:
A 12-year-old female was referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Department by an orthodontist regarding an ectopic upper left canine and buccal alveolar expansion from the 22 and 24. On examination there was firm, bony expansion between these teeth with associated root displacement. The 22 and 24 were not mobile. The overlying mucosa was normal and the patient was asymptomatic.
Radiographic examination revealed an ectopic 23 which appeared to be within the maxillary sinus or a possible large cystic radiolucency surrounding the canine as well as an indistinct area of bony expansion between the 22 and 24 (). There was no evidence of root resorption of the 22 and 24. A cone beam computed tomography (CT) was carried out and showed expanded bone in the 23 region with normal trabecular pattern with intact buccal and palatal cortices, but some buccal cortical expansion. The 23 was located in the left zygomatic bone, with the crown facing buccally and causing dehiscence of the zygomatic bone. The roots were facing toward the left maxillary sinus with the dilacerated apex projecting into the sinus (). The cause of buccal alveolar expansion and migration of the 23 was unclear.
The patient had the 23 region explored under a general anesthetic, as well as a bone biopsy of the lesion and a left middle meatal antroscopy. The 23 was not visible during examination of the left maxillary sinus. The expanded buccal bone appeared firm but abnormal looking with slight bleeding (). A differential diagnosis of a fibroosseous lesion was made.
Histopathology results showed vital lamellar bone with uniform osteoblast layer with minimal evidence of resorption. The soft tissue component was a mixture of adipose and highly vascular fibrous tissue. Numerous blood vessels ranged widely in size, some having muscle wall and appeared to be displacing adipose tissue. These finding were compatible with a diagnosis of an IH.
On review, there was no further evidence of bony expansion or active hemorrhage from the lesion. Although the 23 was positioned in the zygomatic bone, there was no cystic evidence
conversation:
Doctor: Hi, I am Dr. X. How may I help you today?
Patient: Hi, I was referred to you by my orthodontist.
Doctor: Okay, what was the reason for the referral?
Patient: I have an ectopic upper left canine and some expansion in my jaw.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Actually, I don't have any symptoms.
Doctor: Alright, let's take a look. Can you open your mouth for me?
Patient: Sure.
Doctor: (Examines the patient) There is firm, bony expansion between your 22 and 24 teeth. And the overlying mucosa looks normal. The 22 and 24 are not mobile.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: I would like to perform some tests to get a better understanding of your condition. We will start with a radiographic examination.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: (After the radiographic examination) The radiographic examination showed an ectopic 23 tooth and a possible large cystic radiolucency surrounding the canine. There was no evidence of root resorption of the 22 and 24 teeth.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: To get a more detailed view, I would like to perform a cone beam computed tomography (CT).
Patient: Sure.
Doctor: (After the CT) The CT showed expanded bone in the 23 region with normal trabecular pattern and intact buccal and palatal cortices, but some buccal cortical expansion. The 23 was located in the zygomatic bone, with the crown facing buccally and causing dehiscence of the zygomatic bone. The roots were facing toward the left maxillary sinus with the dilacerated apex projecting into the sinus.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: To get a better understanding of your condition, I would like to explore the 23 region under a general anesthetic and perform a bone biopsy of the lesion and a left middle meatal antroscopy.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: (After the exploration) The 23 was not visible during examination of the left maxillary sinus. The expanded buccal bone appeared firm but abnormal looking with slight bleeding.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: The histopathology results showed vital lamellar bone with uniform osteoblast layer with minimal evidence of resorption. The soft tissue component was a mixture of adipose and highly vascular fibrous tissue. Numerous blood vessels ranged widely in size, some having muscle wall and appeared to be displacing adipose tissue. These findings were compatible with a diagnosis of an IH.
Patient: What is IH?
Doctor: It's a type of lesion. The exact cause of buccal alveolar expansion and migration of the 23 is still unclear. On review, there was no further evidence of bony expansion or active hemorrhage from the lesion. Although the 23 was positioned in the zygomatic bone, there was no cystic evidence.
Patient: Okay. What should I do next?
Doctor: I would like you to come back for a follow-up visit in a few months to monitor your condition. In the meantime, if you experience any symptoms, please don't hesitate to come back.
Patient: Alright, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome.

data:
A 7-year-old boy was referred to the Clinic of Pediatric Dentistry of our University. His mother reported that yellowish coloration of his teeth made him ashamed of smiling and damaged his relationship with other children. A detailed dental, medical, and social history was obtained from the patient. His mother reported that she and the other son were also affected by the same dental disease (), but their esthetic and functional rehabilitation was performed previously.
Clinical examination revealed a mixed dentition. The permanent maxillary central incisors and permanent maxillary and mandibular first molars were partially erupted. The patient exhibited poor oral hygiene with moderate to severe dental plaque accumulation and the gingival tissues around most of the permanent and primary teeth showed mild inflammation.
The patient presented short clinical crowns with a generalized yellow color in both primary and permanent teeth (Figures , , and ). The enamel surface was thin and rough, whereas the roots showed normal length and form. The pulp chambers were regular in size. Carious lesions were present in the primary maxillary right first and second molars and in the primary mandibular first and second molars. In the right side the occlusion was in Class I and in the left side it was cross bite. A deep overbite was observed with premature loss of vertical dimension. In a panoramic radiography, the thin enamel layer could not be distinguished from the underlying dentin ().
The treatment objectives were to improve the esthetics, eliminate the tooth sensitivity, prevent further loss of tooth structure, modify the child's attitude and behavior towards dental treatment, and improve his periodontal health. As part of the treatment plan, the treatment alternatives were explained to the child and his parents.
The initial treatment was early orthodontic treatment interceptive and minimal intervention. The primary maxillary right first and second molars were treated before orthodontic treatment (). The caries-preventive strategies consisted of oral hygiene instruction and dietary recommendation. The permanent maxillary central incisors were restored with composite resin to improve esthetics. The restoration improved the esthetic appearance of the
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, young man, I understand you have been referred to our Clinic of Pediatric Dentistry. Can you tell me what brought you here today?
Patient: Hi, yes, my mother brought me here because of the yellow coloration of my teeth.
Doctor: I see. And your mother reported that this yellowish coloration has damaged your relationship with other children and made you ashamed of smiling, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay, let me ask you some questions about your dental and medical history. Can you tell me if your mother or any other family members have the same dental disease?
Patient: Yes, my mother and my brother have the same problem, but they already received esthetic and functional rehabilitation.
Doctor: I understand. Now, let me take a look at your mouth. During the Clinical examination, I noticed that your permanent maxillary central incisors and permanent maxillary and mandibular first molars are partially erupted. Is that correct?
Patient: Hmm, yes.
Doctor: And I also found that you have poor oral hygiene with moderate to severe dental plaque accumulation and the gingival tissues around most of your permanent and primary teeth show mild inflammation. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright, I see that you presented short clinical crowns with a generalized yellow color in both your primary and permanent teeth. And the enamel surface is thin and rough, but the roots are normal in length and form. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what I have noticed.
Doctor: I also found carious lesions present in your primary maxillary right first and second molars and in your primary mandibular first and second molars. And in your right side, the occlusion is in Class I and in your left side it's cross bite. Is that accurate?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And I observed a deep overbite with premature loss of vertical dimension. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Alright, I have taken a panoramic radiography and I found that the thin enamel layer couldn't be distinguished from the underlying dentin. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what I have heard.
Doctor: Okay, so our treatment objectives are to improve the esthetics, eliminate the tooth sensitivity, prevent further loss of tooth structure, modify your attitude and behavior towards dental treatment, and improve your periodontal health. Is that okay with you?
Patient: Yes, I would love to have a better smile.
Doctor: Great, as part of the treatment plan, I have explained the treatment alternatives to you and your parents. And the initial treatment will be early orthodontic treatment interceptive and minimal intervention. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what I have been told.
Doctor: And before orthodontic treatment, we will treat your primary maxillary right first and second molars. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what I heard.
Doctor: And our caries-preventive strategies will consist of oral hygiene instruction and dietary recommendation. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: And to improve the esthetics, we will restore your permanent maxillary central incisors with composite resin. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's what I heard.
Doctor: Great, I'm glad to hear that. And I believe the restoration will improve the esthetic appearance of your teeth. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, I hope so.
Doctor: Okay, young man, that's all for today. Please follow the oral hygiene instruction and dietary recommendation, and come back for the next appointment.
Patient: Okay, thank you, doctor.

data:
A 28-year-old male patient was sitting next to the driver seat in a sports utility vehicle which met with road traffic accident. The sudden deceleration injury caused both the knees of the patient to hit against the dash board. The patient was taken to a level 3 trauma center and later shifted to our level 1 trauma center after 48 h of injury. On presentation, the patient was conscious, oriented and hemodynamically stable. The right thigh was deformed, painful, had abnormal mobility around thigh, and was more shortened compared to the left lower limb which was in an attitude of external rotation, there was contusion over the right gluteal region. The radiographs [] revealed a posterior dislocation of the right hip with a posterior acetabular wall fracture, an ipsilateral fracture of the shaft of the femur, reverse oblique trochanteric fracture on the left side, and a both bones fracture of the right forearm. Being a high-energy injury and in order to study the acetabular fracture morphology in detail, a noncontrast computed tomography (CT) scan with a 3D reconstruction of the pelvis was done which revealed acetabular fracture geometry and a minimally displaced femoral neck fracture on the left side [Figure –]. On a careful review of previous radiographs, a suspicious fracture line was seen on the left side, though it was not very clear.
The patient underwent open reduction and internal fixation of all his fractures in the same sitting having an irreducible dislocation on one side and a femoral neck fracture on the other about 50 h from his time of sustaining injury. First with the patient in left lateral position on the right side, open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) of the femoral shaft fracture with a locking plate and of the posterior wall acetabular fracture with a reconstruction plate and lag screws was done. A trochanteric osteotomy was also performed on the right side to aid in the fixation of the high posterosuperior acetabular wall fracture and the osteotomy subsequently fixed with three 3.5 mm cortical screws with was
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. Can you tell me what happened to you?

Patient: Good morning, doctor. I was in a road traffic accident. I was sitting next to the driver and my knees hit against the dash board.

Doctor: I see. Was the accident severe?

Patient: Yes, it was. I was taken to a level 3 trauma center and then shifted to your level 1 trauma center after 48 hours.

Doctor: Okay. And when you came to our hospital, how were you feeling?

Patient: I was conscious and oriented, but my right thigh was deformed and painful, and it had abnormal mobility around it, and it was more shortened compared to my left lower limb.

Doctor: Hmm, I understand. And what about your left lower limb?

Patient: It was in an attitude of external rotation. There was a contusion over my right gluteal region.

Doctor: Okay. What did the radiographs show?

Patient: They showed a posterior dislocation of my right hip with a posterior acetabular wall fracture, an ipsilateral fracture of the shaft of the femur, reverse oblique trochanteric fracture on the left side, and a both bones fracture of my right forearm.

Doctor: That's a lot of fractures. Did you have a computed tomography scan?

Patient: Yes, I did. It was a noncontrast CT scan with a 3D reconstruction of my pelvis. It showed acetabular fracture geometry and a minimally displaced femoral neck fracture on the left side.

Doctor: Okay. And what did the scan reveal about the left side?

Patient: On a careful review of previous radiographs, a suspicious fracture line was seen on the left side, though it was not very clear.

Doctor: I see. And what kind of treatment did you receive?

Patient: I underwent open reduction and internal fixation of all my fractures about 50 hours from my time of sustaining injury.

Doctor: That's a lot of work. Can you tell me more about the procedure?

Patient: First, with me in a left lateral position on the right side, they did open reduction and internal fixation of the femoral shaft fracture with a locking plate and of the posterior wall acetabular fracture with a reconstruction plate and lag screws.

Doctor: Okay. And what about the right side?

Patient: A trochanteric osteotomy was also performed on the right side to aid in the fixation of the high posterosuperior acetabular wall fracture. The osteotomy was subsequently fixed with three 3.5 mm cortical screws.

Doctor: I see. That's a lot of work, but it's good that you received proper treatment. How are you feeling now?

Patient: I'm still in pain, but I'm getting better.

Doctor: That's good to hear. I'll prescribe some pain medication for you. And you'll need to come back for follow-up appointments to monitor your recovery.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

Doctor: You're welcome. Take care.
