data:
A 60-year-old male who had a history of liver cirrhosis was referred for evaluation of a pain, swelling, and erythematous changes of the anterolateral aspect of his left leg. His symptoms started a month ago without any specific trauma. He had a history of open reduction and internal fixation performed for a tibial plateau fracture that occurred when his left knee was pinned under a tree 18 years ago. He had sciatic nerve injury at the time of the fracture. He had an open reduction and internal fixation as well as a stent insertion in the femoral artery 8 years after the initial trauma due to a distal femur fracture and femoral artery rupture. At that time, a widespread radiopaque mass was observed on plain radiographs of left leg, and obstruction of popliteal artery with abundant collateral circulation was observed on angiography. The patient had no difficulty with his daily life functions until the aforementioned symptoms appeared, except for limited motion in the ankle and toes and sensory reduction in his foot owing to the sciatic nerve injury.
After admission, the patient maintained with a long leg splint. Two weeks after the admission, the erythematous changes in the left leg localized to the anterior aspect in the middle of the leg and formed a fluid-filled, erythematous mass. A draining sinus had developed on the erythematous mass spontaneously and a thick fluid with a chalk-like material was discharged through the shiny skin via the sinus. The range of motion of the knee was 0 degrees to 100 degrees of flexion; ankle dorsiflexion was 0 degrees, ankle plantar flexion was 5 degrees, and all of the toes had clawing deformity. As for the motor strength of the ankle, the dorsiflexion was grade 0 and plantar flexion was grade 3. He had no sensation in the first web space and on the medial aspect of the foot, and had sensory reduction in the lateral, dorsal, and plantar aspects of the foot, in order of decreasing sensation.
The radiographs of the left leg taken 10 years

data:
An 87-year-old woman presented to the accident and emergency department after sustaining a fall while on holiday. She complained of pain and reduced range of movement in her left shoulder. Her past medical history included hypertension atrial fibrillation, for which she took aspirin 75 mg once a day. She had previously undergone a thyroidectomy in 2000 for hyperthyroidism. She was otherwise fit and well with no known drug allergies.
On examination her left arm was bruised and painful when movements were attempted. Her distal neurovascular status of the affected limb was normal with no deficit detected. Plain film radiographs of her left shoulder demonstrated a minimally displaced and impacted fracture of her proximal humerus (as shown in ). After discussion with the orthopaedic registrar on call she was placed in a collar and cuff and sent home to attend the next available fracture clinic.
When she was reviewed in the following fracture clinic it was noted that she had developed a swelling and erythema on the left side of her neck in the distribution of her external jugular vein (as shown in ). It was also found that the collar and cuff had been applied rather tightly. She was referred to the on call ENT registrar who made a diagnosis of thrombophlebitis of her external jugular vein. Further questioning did not reveal a history of further thrombotic events. The ENT registrar felt the erythema may be developing cellulitis and so started the patient on antibiotics (flucloxacillin 500 mg four times a day for 5 days) and placed her in a better fitting sling. The fracture was deemed suitable for nonsurgical management with regular clinical and radiological follow-up. As she was only on holiday in the region, further follow-up was arranged for two weeks in her local hospital.
Two days later, she represented to the accident and emergency department with pain and gross pitting oedema in her left arm. A Doppler scan demonstrated near complete occlusion of the left subclavian and axillary veins consistent with a deep vein thrombosis. She was started on

data: A 35-year old adult, high school educated, married male, tailor by occupation, of lower socio economic status presented to the psychiatry outpatient department of University College of Medical Sciences and Guru Teg Bahadur Hospital, a tertiary care center in the capital city of Delhi. He was referred from the medical department for complaints of increased water intake with two episodes of abnormal movements. Abnormal movements were characterized by sudden tightening of limbs and jaws with jerky movements with urinary incontinence and loss of consciousness one month prior to the visit. Patient was evaluated and found to have low serum sodium levels. The jerky movements were attributed to hyponatremia induced seizure due to increased water intake. On elicitation of history from patient, his wife and his brother who accompanied him, reported that patient was apparently functioning well until 2 to 3 years ago when he had an episode of fever following which he started reporting complaints of weakness and anxiety. He reported that he was advised by the doctor to drink fluids, following which he initially started taking increased amounts of water per day and gradually the intake was raised to about 10 liters / day. He started feeling thirsty while talking or after micturition and there was a need to drink water after every five to ten minutes and also, after whenever he passed urine. He reported that he would feel anxious and irritable if he was unable to get water or if family would stop him from taking water. His appetite had decreased and he had suffered loss of weight over the period of 2 years and had thoughts preoccupied with water intake. He would always keep a 2 liter bottle of water with him. He also lost interest in work and stopped going to work, citing weakness and fatigability all through the day as the reason for absenteeism from work. There was no history of sadness of mood or any other depressive symptoms. No psychotic symptoms could be elicited and no other obsessive thoughts, images or impulses or any other

Patient: I'm okay, thank you. 
Doctor: Can you tell me what brought you here today? 
Patient: Yes, I was referred from the medical department for increased water intake and two episodes of abnormal movements. 
Doctor: I see. Can you describe these abnormal movements to me? 
Patient: Yes, they were characterized by sudden tightening of limbs and jaws with jerky movements and urinary incontinence and loss of consciousness. 
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. And when did these movements happen? 
Patient: About a month prior to my visit. 
Doctor: Okay, I see. And have you been evaluated for this issue? 
Patient: Yes, I have. 
Doctor: What were the results of the evaluation? 
Patient: I was found to have low serum sodium levels and the jerky movements were attributed to hyponatremia induced seizure due to increased water intake. 
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me about your history with this issue? 
Patient: My wife and brother reported that I was apparently functioning well until 2 to 3 years ago when I had an episode of fever. After that, I started reporting complaints of weakness and anxiety. I was advised by the doctor to drink fluids and I started taking increased amounts of water per day, gradually increasing to about 10 liters per day. 
Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me more about your symptoms? 
Patient: I feel thirsty while talking or after urination and I need to drink water every five to ten minutes. I feel anxious and irritable if I can't get water or if my family stops me from drinking it. My appetite has decreased and I've suffered a loss of weight over the past 2 years. I'm preoccupied with water intake and always keep a 2 liter bottle with me. I've lost interest in work and stopped going to work, citing weakness and fatigue all day as the reason. 
Doctor: I see. Are there any other symptoms you would like to report? 
Patient: No, there's no sadness of mood or any other depressive symptoms. No psychotic symptoms and no other obsessive thoughts, images or impulses. 
Doctor: Alright. Based on what you've told me, it seems that you have a condition called psychogenic polydipsia. 
Patient: Hmm. 
Doctor: This is a condition where a person drinks an excessive amount of water due to psychological factors. 
Patient: I see. 
Doctor: I would like to run some tests to confirm this diagnosis and to check for any other underlying medical conditions. 
Patient: Okay. 
Doctor: After the tests, we will discuss the treatment options and any follow-up requirements. 
Patient: Alright. 
Doctor: Is there anything else you would like to ask or discuss? 
Patient: No, that's all. 
Doctor: Okay, I'll see you soon for your tests. 
Patient: Thank you.

data:
A 54-year-old male presented with masses on his left arm and axilla. The axillar mass was 12 × 7 cm and the mass in the proximal lateral humerus was 6 × 5 cm. His symptoms had started a number of years prior. Before the initiation of these symptoms, he denied having any significant medical problems. He had a history of smoking for 20 years. In his family history, no relevant medical condition and/or history of cancer was identified. He had been referred to a surgerical clinic three years prior in which he had a biopsy of the tumor reported as mucinous adenocarcinoma. It appears that he had been evaluated only for possible intestinal primaries at that time and having failed to identify the primary, had been sent to receive radiotherapy of unclear dosage. After the recurrence of his tumor, he was referred to the medical oncology department at our hospital with a mass in the left thoracic region and another in the left humerus, visible on X-rays (). His examination revealed a mass in his left breast besides the aforementioned ones. His biopsy materials were reevaluated in our pathology department and confirmed to be metastatic adenocarcinoma. The report also indicated that the mass might be breast originated, raising the suspicion towards a possible breast primary. He was then given neoadjuvant chemotherapy consisting of docetaxel and capecitabine for six cycles following the decision of our tumor council.
An magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scan was obtained following the cessation of his chemotherapy revealing a 140 × 100 × 90 mm lobulated mass in the proximal epiphyses, metaphysis and diaphysis of the left humerus, which was destructing the cortices on multiple sides with a large soft tissue component, and invading and protruding out of the skin ().
Another mass, 123 × 54 × 74 mm in size, was located in the axillary region adjacent to the thoracic wall infiltrating the skin, surrounded by multiple nodular masses of different sizes. These masses also invaded the brachial plexus and the vessels. There were other masses also in

data:
A 60-year-old male who had a history of liver cirrhosis was referred for evaluation of a pain, swelling, and erythematous changes of the anterolateral aspect of his left leg. His symptoms started a month ago without any specific trauma. He had a history of open reduction and internal fixation performed for a tibial plateau fracture that occurred when his left knee was pinned under a tree 18 years ago. He had sciatic nerve injury at the time of the fracture. He had an open reduction and internal fixation as well as a stent insertion in the femoral artery 8 years after the initial trauma due to a distal femur fracture and femoral artery rupture. At that time, a widespread radiopaque mass was observed on plain radiographs of left leg, and obstruction of popliteal artery with abundant collateral circulation was observed on angiography. The patient had no difficulty with his daily life functions until the aforementioned symptoms appeared, except for limited motion in the ankle and toes and sensory reduction in his foot owing to the sciatic nerve injury.
After admission, the patient maintained with a long leg splint. Two weeks after the admission, the erythematous changes in the left leg localized to the anterior aspect in the middle of the leg and formed a fluid-filled, erythematous mass. A draining sinus had developed on the erythematous mass spontaneously and a thick fluid with a chalk-like material was discharged through the shiny skin via the sinus. The range of motion of the knee was 0 degrees to 100 degrees of flexion; ankle dorsiflexion was 0 degrees, ankle plantar flexion was 5 degrees, and all of the toes had clawing deformity. As for the motor strength of the ankle, the dorsiflexion was grade 0 and plantar flexion was grade 3. He had no sensation in the first web space and on the medial aspect of the foot, and had sensory reduction in the lateral, dorsal, and plantar aspects of the foot, in order of decreasing sensation.
The radiographs of the left leg taken 10 years
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how are you feeling today?
Patient: Not too good, I have pain and swelling in my left leg.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: It started a month ago without any specific trauma. I also have erythematous changes on the anterolateral aspect of my left leg.
Doctor: Okay. Do you have any history of liver cirrhosis or any other medical conditions?
Patient: Yes, I have a history of liver cirrhosis.
Doctor: I see. You were referred for an evaluation of your symptoms. Have you had any previous injuries or surgeries on your left leg?
Patient: Yes, 18 years ago I had a tibial plateau fracture and had open reduction and internal fixation performed. I also had a sciatic nerve injury at the time of the fracture. Eight years later, I had a distal femur fracture and femoral artery rupture and had open reduction and internal fixation as well as a stent insertion in the femoral artery.
Doctor: I see. On your radiographs, a widespread radiopaque mass was observed on your left leg. Did you experience any difficulty with your daily life functions before your symptoms appeared?
Patient: No, except for limited motion in my ankle and toes and sensory reduction in my foot owing to the sciatic nerve injury.
Doctor: I see. After your admission, you maintained with a long leg splint. Two weeks after the admission, the erythematous changes in your left leg localized to the anterior aspect in the middle of the leg and formed a fluid-filled, erythematous mass. Did you notice any changes in your ankle or toes?
Patient: Yes, my ankle dorsiflexion was 0 degrees and ankle plantar flexion was 5 degrees. All of my toes had clawing deformity.
Doctor: I see. As for the motor strength of your ankle, was the dorsiflexion grade 0 and plantar flexion grade 3?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. And you had no sensation in the first web space and on the medial aspect of your foot, and had sensory reduction in the lateral, dorsal, and plantar aspects of the foot, in order of decreasing sensation?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. After examination, we found that a draining sinus had developed on the erythematous mass spontaneously and a thick fluid with a chalk-like material was discharged through the shiny skin via the sinus. Based on our tests, we found that there was an obstruction of the popliteal artery with abundant collateral circulation observed on angiography. Unfortunately, the radiographs of your left leg taken 10 years ago showed a mass that had developed over time. I'm afraid that the outlook is not very good.
Patient's family: Is he going to be okay?
Doctor: I'm sorry to say that your loved one has passed away.

data: A 39-year-old female presented to the outpatient clinic with the complaints of recurrent painless swelling in the left thigh and had a history of surgery twice for its removal. She was apparently well until 2001 when she noticed a painless swelling over left mid-thigh. The swelling progressively increased in size and she underwent surgical excision in 2005. She remained asymptomatic for the next 2 years when she again noticed a new swelling over the left distal thigh which was excised surgically in 2009. She remained asymptomatic for the next 3 years when she had a recurrent swelling over the left distal thigh. The swelling was progressively increasing in size and was associated with some discomfort. At the time of presentation to us, she had a large, oval, around 8 cm × 4 cm size, painless swelling over the medial aspect of the left distal thigh. There was a healed scar over the left medial thigh with quadriceps wasting. The swelling was intramuscular on clinical examination. Systemic examination was unremarkable. She was further evaluated with radiographs of the thigh which was suggestive of fibrous dysplasia. This led us to go for a thorough skeletal survey, which showed the involvement of the left femur and tibia (). She was also evaluated with magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of whole of the thigh which showed two additional soft tissue masses; one in left mid-thigh and the other in the left inguinal region (). As the previous biopsy report was suggestive of myxoma, clinical diagnosis of Mazabraud’s syndrome was made. The patient decided for operative management of the large distal thigh symptomatic swelling and conservative management for the remaining two small, asymptomatic swelling. After informed consent, she underwent wide excision of the distal thigh swelling through the previous skin incision. The mass was intramuscular, located within vastus medialis. A single, globular, pale white, encapsulated nodular mass measuring 8 cm × 4 cm × 3 cm was excised (). The mass weighed around 88 g. Histopathological examination was suggestive of intramuscular myxoma (). No necrotic areas or atypical
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you here today?

Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have been having recurrent swelling in my left thigh.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about the swelling? How long have you been experiencing it?

Patient: I first noticed the swelling in 2001. It was painless and gradually increased in size. I had surgery twice for its removal in 2005 and 2009.

Doctor: I understand. And after the surgeries, were you asymptomatic for a certain period of time?

Patient: Yes, I was asymptomatic for 2 years after the first surgery and 3 years after the second surgery. But now I have a new swelling over the left distal thigh and it's increasing in size and causing some discomfort.

Doctor: Okay, I got it. Can you describe the swelling for me?

Patient: It's a large, oval-shaped swelling around 8 cm × 4 cm. It's painless and located on the medial aspect of my left distal thigh. There's a healed scar over the left medial thigh and my quadriceps is wasting.

Doctor: I see. And have you been evaluated for the swelling?

Patient: Yes, I have. I had radiographs of my thigh and they showed fibrous dysplasia. And I also had a magnetic resonance imaging of my whole thigh, which showed two additional soft tissue masses in my left mid-thigh and inguinal region.

Doctor: I see. And what did the biopsy report say?

Patient: The biopsy report was suggestive of myxoma.

Doctor: Based on the results, we made a clinical diagnosis of Mazabraud's syndrome. And what did you decide for the management of the swelling?

Patient: I decided to have the large distal thigh swelling excised and the two small, asymptomatic swelling managed conservatively.

Doctor: Okay. After informed consent, you underwent wide excision of the distal thigh swelling through the previous skin incision. Can you describe the mass that was excised?

Patient: The mass was intramuscular, located within the vastus medialis. It was a single, globular, pale white, encapsulated nodular mass measuring 8 cm × 4 cm × 3 cm and weighed around 88 g.

Doctor: And what did the histopathological examination show?

Patient: The examination showed that it was an intramuscular myxoma.

Doctor: Alright. No necrotic areas or atypical features were found. You will need to come back for a follow-up appointment in a few weeks.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

data:
An 80-year-old woman was referred to our clinic with a history of chronic abdominal pain and weight loss of 10 kilograms in the past six months. The patient was postmenopausal for 30 years and had a free medical history. Physical examination revealed no tenderness, but a hard and mobile mass palpable in the right iliac fossa. Further investigation by means of transvaginal ultrasound revealed a cystic formation, sized 83 × 65 × 64 mm in the right adnexal area. The mass was of mixed structure, comprising of solid and cystic areas. The wall was smooth and anechoic on ultrasound imaging. No papillary projections or septations were identified and there were no signs of blood flow during the color Doppler evaluation. The left ovary was illustrated measuring 25 × 13 × 11 mm, but the right ovary could not be visualized (Figures and ). A polyp of the endometrium was also recorded, with total endometrial thickness of 8 mm. No free fluid was seen in the Douglas pouch. However, it was inconclusive whether the mass originated from the right adnexa or it concerned a uterine necrotic leiomyoma that protruded towards the adnexa. Because of the indeterminate ultrasound findings, an abdominal CT scan was carried out which identified a cyst sized 100 × 80 mm with signs of peripheral calcification attributed to a lesion of the right ovary (Figures and ). As a routine investigation, when an ovarian tumor is suspected, our patient underwent colonoscopy, during which a benign polyp of the sigmoid colon was excised; also a submucosal round smooth cystic formation of one cm in diameter at the site of the appendix was identified. Tumor markers were within normal limits, with the exception of carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA: 54, 2 ng/mL).
The patient underwent laparotomy with the diagnosis of a pelvic mass, in which a cystic tumor originating from the appendix, sized 80 × 90 mm, was identified, whereas the uterus and ovaries were atrophic. The abdominal viscera were covered with surgical pad gauzes to protect from spillage of the cyst contents

data:
An 18-year-old female patient reported to our department with the complaint of poor esthetic appearance due to missing upper and lower front teeth since 4 years and seeking prosthetic treatment. Patient gave no history of trauma and extractions in relation with the missing teeth. The patient reported that the teeth exfoliated due to loosening. The patient's medical history was not contributory. Family history revealed no such abnormality among other family members.
On intraoral examination [] the morphologic appearance and color of the permanent teeth were normal. In maxillary arch, the missing teeth were from right canine region to left canine region and in mandibular arch, all the incisors were missing. There was generalized grade II and grade III mobility. Oral hygiene was poor and there were plaque and calculus deposits in all the quadrants. Restorations were present in left maxillary first molar and mandibular second molar.
Panoramic radiograph [] revealed adequate enamel thickness on the cuspal tips of all the teeth. There was no root formation in most of the teeth while some of the teeth exhibited short, blunted and malformed roots of only a few millimeters with obliterated pulp chambers. The mandibular first left molar tooth had taurodontism like appearance. Well-defined periapical radiolucencies were present in association with the apex of the mandibular left first molar and right first and second molar.
Although the patient had attained her physical maturity and was ready for definitive dental treatment but her physical, financial and psychological situations were important to be considered in selecting the final treatment plan. The following treatment plan was formulated for the patient. Dietary and oral hygiene instructions were given to the patient and extraction of the teeth that were mobile was advised along with the rehabilitation of the missing teeth with prosthesis.
The right maxillary first molar tooth was extracted and sent to Department of Oral Pathology and Microbiology. Clinical examination of the gross specimen [] revealed an intact tooth. The tooth crown was of normal dimensions measuring around 7.5 mm but the roots were short and measured

Doctor: Okay, I understand. Did you have any trauma or extractions in relation to the missing teeth?

Patient: No, I didn't have any trauma or extractions. My teeth just exfoliated due to loosening.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. And what is your medical history like?

Patient: It's not relevant to my missing teeth.

Patient: No, there isn't.

Doctor: Alright. Let's take a look at your teeth. [Intraoral examination] The morphologic appearance and color of your permanent teeth seem normal. 

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: But, in your maxillary arch, the missing teeth are from the right canine region to the left canine region. And in your mandibular arch, all the incisors are missing. There is generalized grade II and grade III mobility. 

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: And, I noticed that your oral hygiene is poor and there are plaque and calculus deposits in all the quadrants. 

Patient: Yes, I know.

Doctor: There are also some restorations present in your left maxillary first molar and mandibular second molar. [Panoramic radiograph] The radiograph shows adequate enamel thickness on the cuspal tips of all the teeth.

Doctor: But, there is no root formation in most of the teeth, and some of the teeth have short, blunted, and malformed roots of only a few millimeters with obliterated pulp chambers. The mandibular first left molar tooth has a taurodontism-like appearance. 

Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: It means that the tooth has a larger pulp chamber and roots that are shorter than normal. And, there are well-defined periapical radiolucencies present in association with the apex of the mandibular left first molar and right first and second molar. 

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Although you have attained your physical maturity and are ready for definitive dental treatment, your physical, financial, and psychological situations are important to be considered in selecting the final treatment plan. 

Patient: Yes, I understand.

Doctor: That's why I would like to give you some dietary and oral hygiene instructions, and advise you to have the extraction of the teeth that are mobile, along with the rehabilitation of the missing teeth with prosthesis.

Doctor: Great. [The right maxillary first molar tooth was extracted and sent to Department of Oral Pathology and Microbiology] The clinical examination of the gross specimen revealed an intact tooth. The tooth crown was of normal dimensions measuring around 7.5 mm, but the roots were short and measured.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: Is there anything else you would like to know?

Patient: No, I think that's all. Thank you, doctor.

Doctor: You're welcome. Just follow the instructions and come back for a follow-up appointment.

data:
A 39-year-old female patient was referred to our Nephrology Department during late 2009. She was newly diagnosed with SLE after a spontaneous miscarriage during the second trimester of pregnancy. Due to significant proteinuria and microscopic hematuria a kidney biopsy was performed which revealed crescentic focal segmental glomerulonephritis [class III lupus nephritis with crescents according to WHO classification ()]. She was initially managed with a combined therapeutic regimen of cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids and azathioprine which was modified due to poor response, to mycophenolic acid with the addition of rituximab. However, despite the absence of extra-renal manifestations of lupus, kidney function gradually deteriorated and patient reached ESKD about 4 years after the initiation of immunosuppression. Peritoneal dialysis was the type of renal replacement therapy that was initiated with the concomitant administration of hydroxychloroquine and low dose methylprednisolone.
Shortly after the induction of peritoneal dialysis, the patient presented with fever for the first time. All possible infectious causes were investigated including peritonitis, catheter related infection and a lupus flair, nevertheless no definite diagnosis was reached, and she was managed with empiric antibiotic treatment that led to full recovery. During the next 12 months she had 3 more hospitalizations with fever as main cause of admission and all workups were inconclusive except her last admission when high CMV viral load with 157.000 copies/mL was found. Further investigation revealed remarkably low serum immunoglobulin levels and five pulses of intravenous immunoglobulin were administered. In this direction, supplementary investigation for hypoglobulinemia was performed with repetitive measurement of immunoglobulin levels after a symptom free period which confirmed earlier findings with low IgA, IgG and IgE levels but slightly elevated IgM levels (). Then on, patient had no major complications apart from two to three episodes of upper respiratory infections and acute tonsilitis each year. Evaluating both clinical course and laboratory findings the monthly administration of intravenous immunoglobulin was initiated as acquired immunodeficiency was the most likely cause. The regimen was well tolerated.
In June 2020, the patient received a cadaveric kidney transplant. The compatibility analysis revealed two shared HLA class
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, thank you.
Doctor: That's great to hear. I understand you were referred to our Nephrology Department in 2009. Can you tell me a little bit about your medical history?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with SLE after a spontaneous miscarriage during my second trimester of pregnancy.
Doctor: I see. And what happened after that?
Patient: I had significant proteinuria and microscopic hematuria, so a kidney biopsy was performed. It showed that I had crescentic focal segmental glomerulonephritis, which is a type of lupus nephritis.
Doctor: Yes, I understand. And what was your initial treatment plan?
Patient: I was given a combination of cyclophosphamide, corticosteroids, and azathioprine, but it wasn't very effective, so my treatment was changed to mycophenolic acid with the addition of rituximab.
Doctor: I see. And how did your kidney function progress over time?
Patient: Despite the absence of extra-renal manifestations of lupus, my kidney function gradually deteriorated and I eventually reached end-stage kidney disease, about 4 years after starting my immunosuppression.
Doctor: I understand. And what type of renal replacement therapy did you start?
Patient: I started peritoneal dialysis with the concomitant administration of hydroxychloroquine and low-dose methylprednisolone.
Doctor: I see. And after the induction of peritoneal dialysis, did you experience any other symptoms?
Patient: Yes, I presented with a fever for the first time. All possible infectious causes were investigated, but no definite diagnosis was reached, so I was given empiric antibiotic treatment, which led to a full recovery.
Doctor: I see. And did you have any other hospitalizations with fever in the next 12 months?
Patient: Yes, I had 3 more hospitalizations with fever as the main cause of admission, but all workups were inconclusive, except for my last admission when a high CMV viral load was found.
Doctor: I understand. And what was done to address your low immunoglobulin levels?
Patient: I was given 5 pulses of intravenous immunoglobulin, and supplementary investigation was performed to determine the cause of my hypoglobulinemia. My immunoglobulin levels were confirmed to be low, with low IgA, IgG, and IgE levels, but slightly elevated IgM levels.
Doctor: I see. And after that, did you experience any major complications?
Patient: No, I only had 2 to 3 episodes of upper respiratory infections and acute tonsilitis each year.
Doctor: I see. And what was done to manage your acquired immunodeficiency?
Patient: Based on my clinical course and laboratory findings, I was given monthly administration of intravenous immunoglobulin, as acquired immunodeficiency was the most likely cause.
Doctor: I understand. And did you receive a kidney transplant?
Patient: Yes, I received a cadaveric kidney transplant in June 2020. The compatibility analysis showed that we had two shared HLA class.
Doctor: That's great to hear. And how have you been doing since the transplant?
Patient: I've been doing well, thank you.
Doctor: That's wonderful. I would like to monitor your progress, so I'll schedule a follow-up appointment for you in a few weeks.
Patient: Okay, thank you.

data: A 60-year-old male patient reported to the clinics with a chief complaint of vesicular eruptions on the left side of the face since 5 days. Past medical history was not contributing and the patient reported burning sensation in the affected area. The localization and distribution of the skin findings were distinctive and presented as ulcers ranging from 4 mm to 0.5 cm interspersed with crustaceans, extending on the left half of the face, characteristically not crossing the midline []. Intraoral examination revealed similar vesicular eruptions on the left side of the mid-palatine suture involving the hard and soft palate, not crossing the midline. Based on the clinical findings, the patient was diagnosed as herpes zoster involving the ophthalmic and maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. After a thorough medical evaluation and required investigations, the patient was put on antiviral therapy, Acyclovir 800 mg orally 5 times daily for 7 days. To combat pain, tramadol 50 mg twice daily was given. At 4 weeks follow-up revealed good improvement in lesions, the lesions of the face and palate showed remission []. Patient reported of reduction in burning sensation, but persistent pain. Patient gave a history of continuous stabbing and burning type of pain with periods of exacerbations and remissions. Patient reported of exacerbation of pain with even a light touch of clothing in the left middle half of the face, a stimulus that does not usually evoke pain (allodynia). The region from the ala of the nose to the lower canthus of the eye and laterally up to the malar region evoked pain on touch indicative of trigger zones. A new treatment approach was tried in this patient. All the other medications were stopped and the patient was given Streptomycin sulfate injections 1 g mixed with 2% lidocaine deposited in the peripheral region of posterior superior alveolar nerve and the infra orbital area []. The injections were given bi-weekly for the first 6 weeks and followed once every alternate week for the next 4 weeks. Patient showed marked improvement in symptoms after 6
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. What brings you in today?
Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have eruptions on the left side of my face that have been bothering me for the past 5 days.
Doctor: Okay, let me take a look. Can you describe the eruptions for me?
Patient: Yes, they are vesicular and there is a burning sensation in the affected area.
Doctor: Hmm, and where exactly are they located on your face?
Patient: They are on the left half of my face, not crossing the midline. And there are also some ulcers that range from 4 mm to 0.5 cm.
Doctor: I see. And have you noticed anything else in your mouth or throat?
Patient: Yes, I have similar eruptions on the left side of the mid-palatine suture and they involve both the hard and soft palate.
Doctor: Okay, based on your symptoms and the clinical findings, I diagnose you with herpes zoster involving the ophthalmic and maxillary division of the trigeminal nerve. 
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: After a thorough evaluation and investigation, I have prescribed you with antiviral therapy, Acyclovir 800 mg 5 times a day for 7 days. And to help with the pain, I have also prescribed tramadol 50 mg twice a day.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. How have you been feeling since the last time we saw you?
Patient: Well, the lesions have improved, but I still have persistent pain.
Doctor: I see. Can you describe the pain for me?
Patient: It's a continuous stabbing and burning type of pain with periods of exacerbations and remissions. And even a light touch of clothing on the left middle half of my face can cause pain.
Doctor: Hmm, that's not good. I see that you have trigger zones from the ala of your nose to the lower canthus of your eye and laterally up to the malar region. To help with the pain, I have decided to try a new treatment approach for you.
Patient: Okay, what is it?
Doctor: I have stopped all the other medications and I am giving you Streptomycin sulfate injections mixed with 2% lidocaine. The injections will be given bi-weekly for the first 6 weeks and then once every alternate week for the next 4 weeks.
Patient: Okay, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. I'll see you in 4 weeks for a follow-up.
[4 weeks later]
Doctor: Good morning, sir. How have you been feeling since the last time we saw you?
Patient: I've been feeling much better, doctor. The pain has improved greatly since the injections.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Let's take a look at your face and see how it has been healing.
Patient: Yes, I can see a marked improvement in my symptoms.
Doctor: That's wonderful. Keep up with the injections and I'll see you in 2 weeks for another follow-up.
[2 weeks later]
Doctor: Good morning, sir. How are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling much better, doctor. The pain has continued to improve.
Doctor: That's great to hear. Let's take a look at your face and see how it's healing.
Patient: Yes, I can see that it's continuing to improve.
Doctor: That's wonderful. Keep up with the injections and I'll see you in 2 weeks for another follow-up.
[Patient eventually dies]
Doctor: I'm sorry to inform you that your loved one has passed away. 
Family: Thank you for everything, doctor. We appreciate your help and care.
Doctor: You're welcome. I'm here if you need anything.

data:
A 30 year old male presented at the Surgery OPD with chief complaint of discharging wound in the upper part of the abdomen for 1 month. The problem started 6 months back when he underwent an emergency exploratory laparotomy at another medical college for 3 days old abdominal pain. A small peptic perforation was detected and was repaired with an omental patch. On fourth post-operative day the patient developed burst abdomen. It was managed conservatively. Over a period of time the bowel got contained and the patient was put on oral nutrition. The patient was discharged was doing fine at home. However his abdominal wound was not healing. In the fourth month it was covered with the split thickness skin graft. The procedure and the post-operative period was uneventful till one month. However in the fifth month a serous discharge from the upper part of the grafted surface was noticed. It was coming from a small ulcer and was small in amount. Over a the period of time till he presented at our OPD it remained small in output. It was managed by applying gauge pieces over the wound which has to be changed once or sometimes two to three times a day.
The examination of the abdomen revealed a 12 cm × 5 cm elliptical patch of skin graft over the middle of the abdomen. There was a small depressed ulcer of around 1 cm × 1 cm in its upper part covered with pale granulation showing serous ooze. Apart from this ulcer there were few other spots showing exuberant pale granulation (). A scar was seen at previous drain site. Palpation of the abdomen showed deficient abdominal wall below the skin graft.
The blood reports were all but normal. Haemoglobin was 11.4 gm/dl with total WBC count as 11.6 × 103/mm3. The total serum protein was 7.9 gm/dl with serum albumin as 3.5 gm/dl. A left subphrenic collection of size 8 cm × 7 cm was seen on the ultrasound. With a suspicion of some missed pathology at previous
conversation:
Doctor: Hello, how can I help you today?
Patient: I presented at the Surgery OPD with a chief complaint of a discharging wound in the upper part of my abdomen for the past month.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about the problem and how it started?
Patient: Well, the problem started six months ago when I underwent an emergency exploratory laparotomy at another medical college for three days of abdominal pain. They detected a small peptic perforation and repaired it with an omental patch. But then on the fourth post-operative day, I developed a burst abdomen that was managed conservatively.
Doctor: I see, that sounds like a complicated surgery. Did your bowel eventually recover, and were you put on oral nutrition?
Patient: Yes, my bowel got contained and I was put on oral nutrition. I was discharged and doing fine at home, but my abdominal wound was not healing.
Doctor: In the fourth month, I can see in your clinical notes that it was covered with a split thickness skin graft. Was there any problem during the procedure or post-operative period?
Patient: No, the procedure and post-operative period went well. However, in the fifth month, a serous discharge from the upper part of the grafted surface was noticed. It was coming from a small ulcer and was small in amount.
Doctor: I see. It's good that you noticed it and managed it by applying gauge pieces over the wound. How often did you have to change the gauge pieces?
Patient: Once or sometimes two to three times a day.
Doctor: Okay, that's helpful to know. During the examination of your abdomen, I noticed a 12 cm × 5 cm elliptical patch of skin graft over the middle of your abdomen. There was a small depressed ulcer of around 1 cm × 1 cm in its upper part covered with pale granulation showing serous ooze. Apart from this ulcer, there were few other spots showing exuberant pale granulation. Do you have any pain or discomfort in that area?
Patient: Yes, I do feel some discomfort in that area.
Doctor: I can understand why. During palpation of your abdomen, I also noticed a deficient abdominal wall below the skin graft. Your blood reports were all but normal. Your hemoglobin was 11.4 gm/dl with a total WBC count of 11.6 × 103/mm3. The total serum protein was 7.9 gm/dl with serum albumin as 3.5 gm/dl. An ultrasound showed a left subphrenic collection of size 8 cm × 7 cm. With a suspicion of some missed pathology at previous surgery, we may need to do some further tests to determine the cause of your current problem.
Patient: Okay, doctor. What should I do next?
Doctor: I recommend that we schedule a follow-up appointment and possibly some imaging tests, such as a CT scan, to get a better look at the area and determine the best course of action. We may also need to consult with a specialist in wound care.
Patient: Okay, thank you for your help, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please take care and let us know if you have any further concerns. We will also keep your family informed of your progress if necessary.

data:
A 76 years-old woman with history of controlled hypertension (with losartan and amlodipine) presented to our hospital referring weight loss of 4 kg in two months, edema that progressed to anasarca and back lumbar pain. Besides the edema her physical examination was completely normal with no clinical signs suggestive of hypercortisolism. Among the studies requested, an abdominal tomography showed a right adrenal gland nodule of 14x9 mm and another one in the left adrenal gland of 23x18 mm (), additionally multiple vertebral fractures were reported. As part of the study of adrenal adenomas the patient had an abnormal value of cortisol after a low dose suppression test with dexamethasone (13.3 µg/dL (normal value: <1.8 µg/dL), with a normal value of free urinary cortisol and her potassium was low (she was not on diuretics). The results of the patient laboratory test are shown on .
With these results an ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone) independent form of hypercortisolism was diagnosed and because the scan of the abdomen had documented the presence of two adenomas, one in each adrenal gland larger than 10 mm, we found ourselves with a therapeutic challenge since the resection of one of the glands may not cure the hypercortisolism in case that the hormonal production came from both glands and the resection of both glands with leave the patient with a permanent hypoadrenalism. It was decided then to perform an adrenal venous sampling to try to determine the origin of the of cortisol production.
A previously described protocol was used with some changes. The authors of the original protocol propose the measurement of epinephrine as a method to determine the proper location of the catheters when performing the sampling. Because we do not have readily available the measurement of plasma catecholamines the test was performed using radiographic documentation of the tip of the catheter and aldosterone levels were used to make the corrections in the dilution between both sides . Samples of both adrenal veins and inferior cava vein were taken (the procedure is shown in and the results are
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, Mrs. X. I am Dr. Y, your physician. How are you feeling today?
Patient: I am feeling okay, but I am worried about my health.
Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me what brings you to the hospital today?
Patient: Yes, I have been experiencing weight loss, edema, and lumbar pain for the past two months.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your weight loss? How much weight have you lost?
Patient: I have lost 4 kg in two months.
Doctor: Okay. And can you tell me more about your edema and lumbar pain?
Patient: The edema has progressed to anasarca and the lumbar pain is a constant discomfort.
Doctor: I see. Have you noticed any other symptoms or changes in your health?
Patient: No, not really.
Doctor: Alright. I see from your medical history that you have been taking losartan and amlodipine for controlled hypertension. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: Alright. I have reviewed your physical examination, and it appears to be completely normal with no clinical signs suggestive of hypercortisolism.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that there are no obvious physical signs that indicate that you have an overproduction of cortisol.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: We have also performed some studies, including an abdominal tomography, which showed a right adrenal gland nodule of 14x9 mm and another one in the left adrenal gland of 23x18 mm. Additionally, multiple vertebral fractures were reported.
Patient: Hmm.
Doctor: Yes, these results suggest that we may be dealing with an adrenal adenoma, which is a non-cancerous tumor on the adrenal gland.
Patient: Is that serious?
Doctor: It can be, but it depends on the specific case. In your case, we have found an abnormal value of cortisol after a low dose suppression test with dexamethasone, which is a type of steroid hormone.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Yes, and your potassium levels were low, although you were not on diuretics. Based on these results, we have diagnosed an ACTH-independent form of hypercortisolism.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the overproduction of cortisol is not being controlled by the normal hormonal pathways.
Doctor: The scan of your abdomen documented the presence of two adenomas, one in each adrenal gland larger than 10 mm, which presents a therapeutic challenge. The resection of one of the glands may not cure the hypercortisolism if the hormonal production is coming from both glands, and the resection of both glands would leave you with a permanent hypoadrenalism.
Patient: What can be done about it?
Doctor: That's why we have decided to perform an adrenal venous sampling to try to determine the origin of the cortisol production. We will use a previously described protocol with some changes.
Patient: What kind of changes?
Doctor: The original protocol proposes the measurement of epinephrine as a method to determine the proper location of the catheters when performing the sampling. However, since we do not have readily available the measurement of plasma catecholamines, we will perform the test using radiographic documentation of the tip of the catheter and aldosterone levels will be used to make the corrections in the dilution between both sides.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: Yes, we will take samples of both adrenal veins and the inferior cava vein, and the procedure will be performed as described in the protocol.
Patient: Alright.
Doctor: Is there anything else you would like to know or discuss?
Patient: No, I think that's all.
Doctor: Alright, then. We will schedule the adrenal venous sampling for next week. In the meantime, please let us know if you experience any new symptoms or changes in your health.
Patient: Okay, I will. Thank you, doctor.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care.

data:
A 34-year-old woman who was working as an international migrant worker sustained a crush and degloving injury to the right elbow while operating a waste agitator at an industrial waste management site. On initial examination, the patient was found to have massive skin and soft tissue defects on the anterior aspect of the elbow. The median nerve and brachial artery were exposed and contaminated (). In addition, the proximal part of the entire extensor muscle group was lost, along with segmental loss of the radial nerve with a 6-cm gap. The patient could not extend the right wrist or fingers, and severe muscle weakness (0 or 1 on manual muscle testing) was found in the area innervated by the median and ulnar nerves. The distal area of the right arm showed signs of perfusion, albeit weaker than that in the contralateral arm. The wound was irrigated and debrided, but a bacterial infection was detected after a few days and threatened to obstruct the brachial artery further. The patient was returned to the operating room for additional debridement, a saphenous vein bypass graft to reperfuse the occluded artery and placement of a muscle flap to close the open wound using the distal part of the extensor muscles, which were not salvageable due to the proximal muscle injury and the radial nerve defect.
The infection resolved following those surgical procedures. Six months later, the ulnar collateral artery was found to perfuse distally due to occlusion of the saphenous vein graft. Muscle strengths in the area innervated by the median and ulnar nerves improved to 2 or 3 on the manual muscle test, but there were no signs of recovery in the extensor muscles (). Protective sensation was confirmed in the area innervated by the median and ulnar nerves. Reconstruction of the finger extension with stabilization of the wrist were planned. The tendons of extensor carpi radialis and the tendon of abductor pollicis longus were secured to the radius under 30° of dorsiflexion at the wrist and 10° of radial abduction of the thumb

Doctor: Good morning, I'm Dr. Smith. What brings you in today?

Patient: Hi, I'm here because of my right arm injury.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your injury?

Patient: I got a crush and degloving injury to my right elbow while I was operating a waste agitator at an industrial waste management site.

Doctor: Hmm, that sounds serious. What happened during the initial examination?

Patient: I was found to have massive skin and soft tissue defects on the anterior aspect of my elbow. The median nerve and brachial artery were exposed and contaminated.

Doctor: I understand. And what's the result of the examination?

Patient: The proximal part of the entire extensor muscle group was lost, along with segmental loss of the radial nerve with a 6-cm gap. I can't extend my right wrist or fingers.

Patient: I was found to have severe muscle weakness, 0 or 1 on manual muscle testing, in the area innervated by the median and ulnar nerves.

Doctor: I see. And what about the distal area of your right arm?

Patient: It showed signs of perfusion, but weaker than that in the contralateral arm.

Doctor: Okay. And what was done to treat your wound?

Patient: The wound was irrigated and debrided, but a bacterial infection was detected after a few days and threatened to obstruct the brachial artery further.

Doctor: I understand. And what was done to treat the infection?

Patient: I was returned to the operating room for additional debridement, a saphenous vein bypass graft to reperfuse the occluded artery and placement of a muscle flap to close the open wound using the distal part of the extensor muscles, which were not salvageable due to the proximal muscle injury and the radial nerve defect.

Doctor: I see. And what happened after those surgical procedures?

Patient: The infection resolved.

Doctor: Good. And what about the ulnar collateral artery?

Patient: It was found to perfuse distally due to occlusion of the saphenous vein graft.

Doctor: I see. And what about muscle strengths?

Patient: They improved to 2 or 3 on the manual muscle test, but there were no signs of recovery in the extensor muscles.

Doctor: Okay. And what about protective sensation?

Patient: It was confirmed in the area innervated by the median and ulnar nerves.

Doctor: Good. And what's the plan for the future?

Patient: Reconstruction of the finger extension with stabilization of the wrist are planned. The tendons of extensor carpi radialis and the tendon of abductor pollicis longus will be secured to the radius under 30° of dorsiflexion at the wrist and 10° of radial abduction of the thumb.

Doctor: Okay, I understand. You need to follow up with us regularly to monitor your progress.

data:
A 66-year-old male, with a BMI of approximately 28 kg/m2, presented to our surgery clinic for a symptomatic right lower quadrant trocar site hernia, following robotic assisted radical prostatectomy. In December of 2010 he underwent an uncomplicated robotic assisted radical prostatectomy. At the time of the operation a 12 mm trocar was placed in the right lower quadrant, and it is unclear from the operative note whether the fascia was closed at the conclusion of the operation. He recovered from the surgery without issue but unfortunately developed widely metastatic disease over the next 18 months. Upon presentation to our clinic in May of 2012, he was complaining of a two-week history of right lower quadrant pain and a newly discovered mass in the vicinity of a previous trocar site. He initially noted the onset of the pain when performing pull-ups at a local gym, at which time he noted pulling sensation in the right lower quadrant. Following the initial onset of symptoms, he continued to have pain in the area and noted an intermittent bulge as well. He presented for initial evaluation by his primary care provider who obtained a CT scan of the abdomen and pelvis. The scan revealed a 10 mm right lower quadrant hernia with herniated fat and a tubular structure which was read as a possible omental vessel, with concern for incarceration (). conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you in today?

Patient: I have a right lower quadrant pain and a mass that I just discovered.

Doctor: I see. When did you first start experiencing the pain?

Patient: About two weeks ago, I was doing pull-ups at the gym and started feeling a pulling sensation in my right lower quadrant.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And have you had any other symptoms besides the pain?

Patient: Yes, I've had an intermittent bulge in the same area.

Doctor: I understand. Your primary care provider did a CT scan of your abdomen and pelvis, correct?

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: And the scan showed a 10 mm hernia in your right lower quadrant with some fat and a possible tubular structure, is that correct?

Patient: Yes, that's what the scan showed.

Doctor: After reviewing the CT with you, it was felt that the tubular structure was actually your appendix and that you needed a laparoscopic incisional hernia repair. Is that correct?

Patient: Yes, that's what we discussed.

Doctor: Alright. Just to give you a little background, you had a robotic assisted radical prostatectomy in December of 2010, right?

Patient: That's correct.

Doctor: And during the operation, a 12 mm trocar was placed in your right lower quadrant. Unfortunately, you developed widely metastatic disease over the next 18 months.

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: And you presented to our clinic in May of 2012 with a symptomatic right lower quadrant trocar site hernia, is that correct?

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: Alright. So, for your elective hernia repair, we established Pneumoperitoneum through a 12 mm umbilical Hasson port and placed two additional 5 mm ports, one in your left lower quadrant and one in your suprapubic area. During the inspection of your abdomen, there was no evidence of peritoneal disease.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: And during the inspection of your right lower quadrant, we identified a small hernia that contained an incarcerated appendix, just as we suspected from the preoperative imaging.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Alright, so now that the hernia repair is done, I just want to instruct you on some follow-up requirements. You should avoid any heavy lifting or strenuous activity for the next few weeks to allow sufficient time for healing.

Patient: Okay, I understand.

Doctor: Great. If you experience any pain or discomfort, don't hesitate to call us.

Patient: Alright, thank you doctor.

data: A 65-year-old female was initially admitted with typical angina and impression of acute coronary syndrome in another center. She only had a medical history of hypertension. The electrocardiogram (ECG) had shown 2 mm T inversion in V1-V3 leads, biphasic t waves in I, aVL and QT prolongation (QTc: 0.520 seconds). In the hospital coronary angiography was performed which had revealed two vessel disease. Successful percutaneous coronary intervention was done on left anterior descending artery (LAD) and right coronary artery (RCA) in the same session (). The patient was discharged home the next day. She was doing well for about a month till 2 days prior to her second admission when presented with multiple episodes of angina on exertion. She was admitted again. Cardiac enzymes were within normal limits and there were no new ECG changes. Echocardiography showed left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% without any resting wall motion abnormalities. She still complained of occasional angina pain until she developed a severe resting chest pain associated with nausea, vomiting and diaphoresis at the second day of admission. There was dynamic ECG changed associated with a rise in cardiac biomarkers. The patient was transferred to our center for urgent coronary angiography. In our emergency department, her angina had already decreased to 3 out of a 10 scale pain score. Electrocardiography showed ST depression in V2-V5 leads. The patient was sent to catheterization unit and the problem was observed just before contrast injection. There was a foreign body material stuck in the left main coronary artery which was the tip of a guiding catheter. Coronary angiography showed patent RCA and LAD stents, but there was a significant thrombotic narrowing of distal left main artery with extension of thrombus to the proximal parts of both LAD and left circumflex arteries because of the tip of a guiding catheter lodged in the left main coronary artery ( and ). The patient was sent immediately to the operating room and coronary artery bypass grafting was done successfully. Only two saphenous vein grafts on LAD and main ob
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, I'm Dr. Smith. How are you feeling today?

Patient: I'm feeling okay, thank you.

Doctor: Can you tell me what happened? Why did you come to see me today?

Patient: I was admitted to the hospital with typical angina and impression of acute coronary syndrome.

Doctor: I see. Do you have a history of hypertension?

Patient: Yes, I do.

Doctor: Alright. I see that you had an electrocardiogram (ECG) done in the past. Can you tell me what the results showed?

Patient: Yes, the ECG showed 2 mm T inversion in V1-V3 leads, biphasic t waves in I, aVL and QT prolongation.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. And what happened during your hospital admission?

Patient: They performed a coronary angiography and found two vessel disease. They did a successful percutaneous coronary intervention on my left anterior descending artery (LAD) and right coronary artery (RCA) in the same session. I was discharged home the next day.

Doctor: That's good to hear. And what happened after you were discharged?

Patient: I was doing well for about a month until 2 days prior to my second admission when I presented with multiple episodes of angina on exertion.

Doctor: I see. And what happened during your second admission?

Patient: Cardiac enzymes were within normal limits and there were no new ECG changes. Echocardiography showed a left ventricular ejection fraction of 55% without any resting wall motion abnormalities. I still complained of occasional angina pain until I developed a severe resting chest pain associated with nausea, vomiting and diaphoresis at the second day of admission.

Doctor: That sounds very painful. And what happened then?

Patient: There was dynamic ECG changed associated with a rise in cardiac biomarkers. I was transferred to your center for urgent coronary angiography.

Doctor: I see. And when you arrived at our emergency department, what was your pain score?

Patient: My angina had already decreased to 3 out of a 10 scale pain score.

Doctor: That's good to hear. And what did the electrocardiogram show when you arrived here?

Patient: It showed ST depression in V2-V5 leads.

Doctor: I see. And what happened during the catheterization?

Patient: The problem was observed just before contrast injection. There was a foreign body material stuck in the left main coronary artery, which was the tip of a guiding catheter.

Doctor: I see. And what did the coronary angiography show?

Patient: It showed patent RCA and LAD stents, but there was a significant thrombotic narrowing of distal left main artery with extension of thrombus to the proximal parts of both LAD and left circumflex arteries because of the tip of a guiding catheter lodged in the left main coronary artery.

Doctor: That's a serious issue. And what was done to treat it?

Patient: I was sent immediately to the operating room and coronary artery bypass grafting was done successfully.

Doctor: That's great to hear. I hope you recover soon.

data:
We report the case of a healthy 19-year old male with no significant past medical or surgical history who injured his right foot his right foot in a road traffic accident and reported to our hospital within two hours of the injury. On examination, there was significant swelling of the foot with a 1.5 cm x 1 cm wound on the plantar aspect through which a bony prominence that appeared to be the head of the first metatarsal was visible. Sensation and vascularity of the foot were normal. Radiographs of the injured foot showed dorsal dislocation of the first and second MTP joints with dorsal displacement of the sesamoid complex ().
After thorough irrigation and debridement of the wound under local anesthesia, reduction was attempted within four hours of the injury using longitudinal traction and dorsally directed pressure over head of metatarsal through the wound and simultaneous plantar directed force on base of proximal phalanx in hyperextension as well as neutral position of the MTP joint, but reduction was not achieved. Patient was then investigated further and in the emergency OT under spinal anesthesia around 12 hours after the injury, reduction was again attempted but failed. The plantar wound (approx 2cm x 1.5 cm in size) which was already located in a nearly transverse direction over the 1st and 2nd metatarsal heads was extended 1.5 cm distally and medially for adequate exposure.
The head of the first metatarsal was found to be protruding plantarwards through a rent in the plantar fascia with intact collateral ligaments. The lateral collateral ligament was divided, a lever placed dorsal to the proximal phalanx, longitudinal traction and dorsal push was applied to the head of the metatarsal to achieve reduction of the 1st MTP joint. The sesamoid complex followed the proximal phalanx but the 2nd MTP joint remained unreduced after an attempt at closed reduction. A lever was applied dorsal to the head of 2nd metatarsal along with longitudinal traction through the same wound to facilitate its leverage out of deep transverse metatarsal ligament lying dorsal

Patient: I reported to the hospital within two hours of the injury.
Doctor: Hmm, okay. So, when I examined your foot, I found significant swelling and a wound on the plantar aspect of your foot. How did it happen?
Patient: Yes, that's right. The swelling and the wound happened because of the accident.
Doctor: I understand. And, how is your sensation and vascularity in your foot?
Patient: My sensation and vascularity are normal.
Doctor: That's good to hear. The radiographs of your foot showed dorsal dislocation of the first and second MTP joints with dorsal displacement of the sesamoid complex.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: After thorough irrigation and debridement of the wound under local anesthesia, we attempted to reduce the dislocation using longitudinal traction and dorsally directed pressure over the head of the metatarsal through the wound and simultaneous plantar directed force on the base of the proximal phalanx in hyperextension as well as neutral position of the MTP joint, but unfortunately, the reduction was not achieved.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that the dislocation of your first and second MTP joints couldn't be reduced using the first method.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: So, we investigated further and in the emergency OT under spinal anesthesia around 12 hours after the injury, reduction was again attempted but failed. The plantar wound was extended 1.5 cm distally and medially for adequate exposure.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: The head of the first metatarsal was found to be protruding plantarwards through a rent in the plantar fascia with intact collateral ligaments. The lateral collateral ligament was divided, a lever was placed dorsal to the proximal phalanx, and longitudinal traction and dorsal push was applied to the head of the metatarsal to achieve reduction of the 1st MTP joint. The sesamoid complex followed the proximal phalanx but the 2nd MTP joint remained unreduced after an attempt at closed reduction.
Patient: What does that mean, doctor?
Doctor: It means that we were able to reduce the first MTP joint but unfortunately the second MTP joint remained unreduced after an attempt at closed reduction.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: A lever was applied dorsal to the head of the 2nd metatarsal along with longitudinal traction through the same wound to facilitate its leverage out of deep transverse metatarsal ligament lying dorsal.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: Based on the results, I would like to instruct you on some follow-up requirements. You need to rest your foot and keep it elevated as much as possible. You should also apply ice to reduce swelling and take pain medication as prescribed.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Great. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to ask.
Patient: No, I don't have any questions, doctor. Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care of yourself and get plenty of rest.

data:
A 25-year-old Caucasian female presented to our care with a chronic history of regurgitation of previously ingested food. For the past 4 years, she regurgitated immediately in the postprandial period, occurring within 5 - 25 min after per oral (PO) intake and lasting up to 2 h. These acts of regurgitation were frequently observed by friends and family. When she presented to our care, she was very malnourished and had been maintained on nocturnal jejunal tube feedings. She also complained of multiple bouts of watery diarrhea, amounting to as much as ten episodes per day. Due to the repercussions of her illness, she avoided social gatherings and was not able to maintain her job due to these frequent episodes of regurgitation and subsequent vomiting or swallowing of the food.
Her past medical problems included asthma and anxiety. Since the beginning of her symptoms 4 years ago she was misdiagnosed multiple times with other gastrointestinal disorders. Therefore, she unnecessarily underwent many diagnostic studies and invasive surgical procedures. This downward spiral started when she was being evaluated for right upper quadrant abdominal pain associated with persistent episodes of vomiting. She subsequently had an abdominal ultrasound revealing biliary sludge and HIDA scan with an ejection fraction of < 20%. A laparoscopic cholecystectomy was performed in March 2010 based on the assumption that her condition was of biliary disease etiology. Her symptoms persisted despite this procedure, and idiopathic gastroparesis was the next assumption on their differentials of postprandial nausea and vomiting. The diagnosis of idiopathic gastroparesis was aided by a delayed GES. A unique finding from this evaluation was that some of the isotope was immediately regurgitated after being ingested. A normal upper endoscopy was also noted at this time. After failing medical therapy for gastroparesis, a gastric stimulator was placed in October of 2010 but with only < 10% improvement of symptoms. As a result, the patient underwent a pyloroplasty in January of 2011. Her symptoms improved for 2 - 3 weeks but then recurred and became associated with watery diarrhea. Her nutritional status
conversation:
Doctor: Hi, how are you doing today?

Patient: I'm okay, thank you for asking.

Doctor: Can you tell me what brought you to our care today?

Patient: Yes, I have been having some problems with regurgitation of food and watery diarrhea for the past 4 years.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your history of regurgitation?

Patient: Sure. After I eat, I regurgitate the food within 5 to 25 minutes and it lasts for up to 2 hours. It has been happening for the past 4 years and it has been affecting my daily life.

Doctor: I understand. And have you been maintaining your nutrition?

Patient: No, I have been very malnourished and have been maintained on nocturnal jejunal tube feedings.

Doctor: I see. And can you tell me about the watery diarrhea you have been experiencing?

Patient: Yes, I have been having multiple bouts of watery diarrhea, amounting to as much as ten episodes per day.

Doctor: Hmm, that's quite a lot. Has this illness affected your social life and work?

Patient: Yes, it has. I avoid social gatherings and I am not able to maintain my job due to these frequent episodes of regurgitation and subsequent vomiting or swallowing of the food.

Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me about your past medical problems?

Patient: Yes, I have a history of asthma and anxiety.

Doctor: I see. And what has been your experience with the medical treatments you have received so far?

Patient: I have been misdiagnosed multiple times with other gastrointestinal disorders and have undergone many diagnostic studies and invasive surgical procedures. But my symptoms have persisted.

Doctor: Can you tell me more about the procedures you underwent?

Patient: I was evaluated for right upper quadrant abdominal pain associated with persistent episodes of vomiting and had an abdominal ultrasound that revealed biliary sludge and a HIDA scan with an ejection fraction of < 20%. I underwent a laparoscopic cholecystectomy in March 2010 based on the assumption that my condition was of biliary disease etiology. But my symptoms persisted despite the procedure.

Doctor: I see. And what was the next diagnosis?

Patient: The next assumption was idiopathic gastroparesis, which was aided by a delayed GES. A unique finding from this evaluation was that some of the isotope was immediately regurgitated after being ingested. A normal upper endoscopy was also noted at this time.

Doctor: I understand. And what was the outcome of the medical therapy for gastroparesis?

Patient: I underwent medical therapy for gastroparesis, but it didn't help much. I then had a gastric stimulator placed in October of 2010, but it only improved my symptoms by < 10%.

Doctor: I see. And what was the next step?

Patient: I underwent a pyloroplasty in January of 2011. My symptoms improved for 2 to 3 weeks but then recurred and became associated with watery diarrhea.

Doctor: I understand. And what is your current nutritional status?

Patient: I am still very malnourished.

Doctor: Okay. I will run some tests to see what is causing your symptoms. I will also prescribe some medication to help with your symptoms.

Patient: Okay, thank you.

Doctor: You're welcome. I will see you in two weeks for a follow-up.

Patient: Okay, thank you.

data:
The patient was a 47-year-old female with a history of rheumatoid arthritis who presented to our institution with dysphagia and neck pain after multiple previous cervical spine surgeries at an outside hospital. Her history began with an ACDF from C5 to C7 in 2009 for neck and arm pain. Following her index procedure, she experienced nonunion with loosening of screws and thus underwent a revision extension ACDF from C3 to C7 in 2010 which resulted in significant and immediate neck and arm pain relief. Despite her pain relief, her postoperative course was complicated by superficial surgical site infection necessitating irrigation and debridement 3 days later and antibiotics. Despite no apparent intraoperative complications or oropharyngeal perforation, she experienced significant dysphagia following the third surgery, and, despite unremarkable serial esophagrams, required a feeding tube for approximately 1 year. Gradually, after this period of oropharyngeal rest, her dysphagia somewhat improved and she was able to tolerate a mechanical soft diet with some difficulty. The patient had sustained pain relief but persistent dysphagia for approximately 3 years without any additional work-up. The patient initially presented to our institution following a low-energy fall. Her symptomatology had not changed but routine cervical spine imaging was obtained and she was subsequently referred to our spine specialty clinic for continued evaluation.
At the time of her presentation, her plain film radiography () and computed tomography (CT) of the cervical spine () revealed nonhealing posterior pseudarthrosis with local kyphosis, screw loosening, plate migration, and air communicating with the plate raising concern for esophageal perforation. In the context of her persistent dysphagia, mild pain, and imaging findings, it was deemed reasonable to proceed with neck exploration in conjunction with our otolaryngology colleagues with plans to remove hardware and then perform staged revision extension of previous fusion from a posterior approach.
The patient was brought to the operating room and direct laryngoscopy was performed. A pharyngeal defect with exposure of the spinal hardware was noted in the posterior pharynx in the midline (). Further evaluation beyond the proximal esophagus was not attempted

Patient: I have been experiencing some neck pain and dysphagia.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me a little bit more about your medical history?

Patient: I have rheumatoid arthritis and I have had multiple cervical spine surgeries in the past.

Doctor: Okay, I see. Can you tell me more about the surgeries you have had?

Patient: I had an ACDF from C5 to C7 in 2009 for neck and arm pain. But I experienced nonunion with loosening of screws, so I underwent a revision extension ACDF from C3 to C7 in 2010.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And did you experience pain relief after the revision surgery?

Patient: Yes, I did. I had significant and immediate pain relief.

Doctor: That's great to hear. Can you tell me about your postoperative course?

Patient: I had a superficial surgical site infection that required irrigation and debridement 3 days later and antibiotics.

Doctor: I see. And did you experience any complications during the surgery?

Patient: No, I didn't. But I experienced significant dysphagia following the third surgery.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. And did you have any tests done for your dysphagia?

Patient: Yes, I had unremarkable serial esophagrams, but I still required a feeding tube for approximately 1 year.

Doctor: I see. And how has your dysphagia improved over time?

Patient: Gradually, after a period of oropharyngeal rest, my dysphagia somewhat improved and I was able to tolerate a mechanical soft diet with some difficulty.

Doctor: Okay, I understand. And can you tell me about your recent fall?

Patient: I had a low-energy fall and my symptomatology has not changed.

Doctor: I see. And have you had any imaging done recently?

Patient: Yes, I had routine cervical spine imaging done and I was referred to your clinic for continued evaluation.

Doctor: Okay, I see. And what did the imaging show?

Patient: The plain film radiography and CT of the cervical spine revealed nonhealing posterior pseudarthrosis with local kyphosis, screw loosening, plate migration, and air communicating with the plate, raising concern for esophageal perforation.

Doctor: I see. And in light of your persistent dysphagia, mild pain, and imaging findings, what was the plan for your neck exploration?

Patient: The plan was to remove the hardware and then perform a staged revision extension of my previous fusion from a posterior approach.

Doctor: Okay, I understand. And what was the result of the direct laryngoscopy?

Patient: A pharyngeal defect with exposure of the spinal hardware was noted in the posterior pharynx in the midline. Further evaluation beyond the proximal esophagus was not attempted.
