data:
A 26-year-old man presented with melena and underwent upper gastrointestinal endoscopy and abdominal CT.
Endoscopy showed a large submucosal tumor in the gastric body with concomitant bleeding from a large central ulceration containing fluid and residual contrast material from a previous barium study (). Endoscopic ultrasound similarly showed a large submucosal mass (). A first endoscopic biopsy result was non-specific and showed acute and chronic inflammation with ulceration. The second biopsy revealed ulceration and tissue granulation with foreign body giant cells suggestive of a barium granuloma.
An abdominal CT scan demonstrated about 5.5 × 3.2 cm sized, well-defined and large exophytically growing mass arising from the posterior aspect of the lesser curvature side in the gastric body. The mass showed a large ulceration at the gastric luminal side and a cavity in the central portion communicating with the gastric lumen. The bulk of the tumor was seen in an extragastric location with extensions into the gastrohepatic ligament and lesser sac. There was no evidence of direct invasion of the adjacent organs or peritoneal spread. No metastatic lesions or lymphadenopathy was seen in the abdomen or pelvis. The mass showed relative hypoattenuation on the precontrast images () and increased heterogeneous enhancement in the portal phase () and prolonged enhancement in the equilibrium phase images (). The radiologic findings were distinct from those of epithelial tumors and the possibility of a malignant gastrointestinal stromal tumor of the stomach was considered on CT. The mass was removed under general anesthesia by laparoscopic wedge resection of the stomach. During laparotomy there was a round and well demarcated mass arising from the lesser curvature side of the gastric body, and there were prominent vessels around the mass with no detected ascites and no adhesion to the adjacent structures. On gross pathology, the specimen consisted of a portion of the stomach measuring 8.5 × 5 cm with an attached ovoid and lobulated rubbery to firm solid mass measuring 5.4 × 5.2 × 4 cm. The mucosa of the stomach was retracted by underlying the attached mass. Section

data:
A 56-year-old male patient, whose plasmacytoma was enucleated 3 years ago from the medial side of the left mandible, was referred to our clinic due to his complaints of persistent orocutaneous fistula (Figures –). Past medical history revealed that the patient was operated three times to close the orocutaneous fistula by local flaps; however, none of these operations were successful. CT images of the patient demonstrated that the medial side of the left mandible was missing and there was a 3 × 2 cm diameter defect located between the left side of the mouth floor and the basis of the left mandible neighboring the left submandibular gland. The main reason of the failed attempts to close the fistula was considered to be the ineffective management of dead space surrounding the fistula. Consequently, it was decided to use the submandibular gland as a pedicled flap to fill the defect and support the oral and the cutaneous flaps.
Under general anesthesia, the fistula was excised initially and the oral and the cutaneous healthy soft tissues were prepared. At the extraoral site, the incision was extended to the posterior and anterior directions, following the previous incision lines. In the subplatysmal plane, the superficial layer of the neck fascia was dissected to reach the base of the mandible. After the dissection of the fascia, the submandibular gland and the base of the mandible were exposed, the soft tissues surrounding the submandibular gland were dissected, and the gland was mobilized by protecting the arteriovenous supply and the duct. At the oral site, the margins of the wound were released by blunt dissection and were closed by mattress sutures via 5/0 polypropylene. Following the mobilization of the gland, a soft tissue tunnel was prepared between the submandibular space and the defect area and the submandibular gland was rotated by passing the gland through the soft tissue tunnel by preserving the pedicle (). The rotated gland was sutured to the recipient site with 3/0 reabsorbable polyglaction sutures for the stabilization. At the cutaneous site, the flap was closed

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your medical history?
Patient: Sure. I had a plasmacytoma removed from the medial side of my left mandible 3 years ago.
Doctor: Okay. And were you referred to our clinic for this issue?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: I see. CT images have demonstrated that there is a defect located between the left side of the mouth floor and the basis of the left mandible neighboring the left submandibular gland. None of the previous operations were successful in closing the fistula.
Patient: Yes, that's right. 
Doctor: The main reason for this is believed to be the ineffective management of dead space surrounding the fistula. Consequently, we have decided to use the submandibular gland as a pedicled flap to fill the defect and support the oral and the cutaneous flaps.
Patient: Okay, what does that mean exactly?
Doctor: Under general anesthesia, we will excise the fistula initially and prepare the healthy soft tissues. At the extraoral site, we will extend the incision to the posterior and anterior directions, following the previous incision lines. In the subplatysmal plane, we will dissect the superficial layer of the neck fascia to reach the base of the mandible. After the dissection of the fascia, the submandibular gland and the base of the mandible will be exposed, and the soft tissues surrounding the submandibular gland will be dissected. The gland will then be mobilized by protecting the arteriovenous supply and the duct. 
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Then, at the oral site, the margins of the wound will be released by blunt dissection and will be closed by mattress sutures via 5/0 polypropylene. Following the mobilization of the gland, a soft tissue tunnel will be prepared between the submandibular space and the defect area, and the submandibular gland will be rotated by passing the gland through the soft tissue tunnel by preserving the pedicle. The rotated gland will be sutured to the recipient site with 3/0 reabsorbable polyglaction sutures for stabilization. At the cutaneous site, the flap will be closed.
Patient: Okay, that sounds like a lot.
Doctor: It is a complex procedure, but we believe it will be effective in closing the fistula. After the procedure, we will give you instructions on follow-up care.
Patient: Okay, thank you for explaining everything to me.
Doctor: You're welcome. We'll do our best to ensure a successful outcome for you.

data:
A 60-year-old male patient reported to the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery with a chief complaint of pain and discharge in the upper left back region of the jaw since one and half years. According to the patient one year prior to our consultation, he got the maxillary molars extracted from a local dentist due to pain and mobility of the teeth in that area. Upon consultation patient revealed that the pain continued to exist even after the extraction.
The extra oral examination was within normal limits with no evidence of lymphadenopathy. The patient is a known hypertensive and is on medication since three years for the same. The patient had smoking habit, which he quit only a couple of years ago. Intraoral examination revealed a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders involving the left posterior portion of hard palate and was also seen involving the soft palate on the same side. The swelling was seen extending from mesial aspect of first premolar to 1 cm posterior to tuberosity on left side, involving the palatal area but not crossing the midline []. An oro-antral communication was seen with purulent discharge. The remainder of the intraoral examination was within normal limits.
The swelling was nontender. The inspectory findings were confirmed on palpation. CT scan revealed complete obliteration of the left maxillary sinus []. The clinical differential diagnosis included a benign or malignant neoplasm of minor salivary glands, a neoplasm of maxillary sinus.
An incisional biopsy of palate and sinus lining was performed. Histopathological examination revealed fibrous stroma with areas of hyalinization. Islands of uniform cells arranged in cord-like pattern with hyperchromatic nuclei were seen enclosing round to oval pseudocystic spaces in the stroma. Few of these spaces showed eosinophilic coagulum []. The tumor cells are also seen arranged in the form of solid islands [] and ductal pattern []. The present case showed all the three histological types. There was no evidence of perineural invasion even on serial sectioning. Focal areas showed small cords and longitudinal tubules of isomorphic cells set
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. How can I help you today?

Patient: Good morning, doctor. I have been experiencing pain and discharge in my upper left jaw for the past one and a half years.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?

Patient: Sure. The pain started after I got my maxillary molars extracted from a local dentist due to pain and mobility of the teeth in that area.

Doctor: I understand. And has the pain continued even after the extraction?

Patient: Yes, it has.

Doctor: Okay. Let me take a look. Can you open your mouth for me?

Patient: Sure.

Doctor: Alright. I am conducting an extra oral examination now and everything seems to be within normal limits. I don't see any evidence of lymphadenopathy.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: I also see that you are a known hypertensive and have been on medication for the same for the past three years.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: And I understand that you used to have a smoking habit, which you quit only a couple of years ago?

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: Alright, let me conduct an intraoral examination now. I can see a solitary erythematous swelling with diffuse borders involving the left posterior portion of hard palate and also involving the soft palate on the same side. The swelling extends from the mesial aspect of the first premolar to 1 cm posterior to the tuberosity on the left side, involving the palatal area but not crossing the midline.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: And I can see an oro-antral communication with purulent discharge. The remainder of the intraoral examination is within normal limits.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: The swelling is nontender. I have confirmed the inspectory findings on palpation.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: I have ordered a CT scan, and it revealed complete obliteration of the left maxillary sinus.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: The clinical differential diagnosis includes a benign or malignant neoplasm of minor salivary glands or a neoplasm of the maxillary sinus.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: I have performed an incisional biopsy of the palate and sinus lining. The histopathological examination revealed fibrous stroma with areas of hyalinization. Islands of uniform cells arranged in cord-like pattern with hyperchromatic nuclei were seen enclosing round to oval pseudocystic spaces in the stroma. 

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: And the tumor cells were also seen arranged in the form of solid islands and ductal pattern. The present case showed all the three histological types. There was no evidence of perineural invasion even on serial sectioning.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: Based on the results, we will need to monitor your condition closely. I will schedule a follow-up appointment for you in two weeks.

Patient: Alright, doctor. Thank you.

data:
A 60-year-old Caucasian female patient presented with a painless swelling in the soft palate, breathing and swallowing difficulties, and suffocation feeling. Clinical examination revealed that the lesion was located mostly in the right side, extending from the limit between the hard and soft palate and continuing to the oropharynx. The lesion had smooth surface, hard consistency, and irregular shape (). Cervical tomography was requested (Figures and ). Based on clinical and imaging aspects, a hypothesis of benign X malignant salivary gland tumor was formulated. An incisional biopsy was performed under local anesthesia to establish the definitive diagnosis. However, the histopathological examination of the fragment revealed normal mucosa (). The professionals decided to perform a second conventional biopsy giving attention to collecting material from a greater depth. Once again, the histopathological analysis revealed normal mucosa ().
The otorhinolaryngologist team was consulted and the decision was made to perform a CNB. The localization of the lesion was identified during the intraoral exam with no need of imaging guidance (). In CNB a needle is activated by an automatic spring system equipped with outer cannula and inner stylet. Under local anesthesia using 1% lidocaine the biopsy area was chosen with palpation of the lump and the tip of the needle was positioned adjacently to the lesion. The handpiece was activated, moving quickly 20 mm back and forth, cutting a sample measuring 17 mm in length. Only one core of tissue was obtained and carefully removed from the biopsy needle. The quality of the specimen was assessed by visual inspection and, with care not to damage the thin tissue, it was put into 10% formalin for fixation. The biopsy site was compressed for five minutes to avoid bleeding and the patient was observed for more 30 minutes and later discharged as no signs or symptoms as bleeding or pain were noted. The histopathological analysis of the sample revealed pleomorphic adenoma (Figures and ).
The patient was referred to the head and neck service for complete resection of the tumor. The specimen was sent to the

Doctor: Hello, how are you today?

Patient: I'm okay, thank you.

Doctor: Can you tell me what brought you here today?

Patient: Yes, I have a swelling in my soft palate that's been causing me some breathing and swallowing difficulties. I also feel like I'm suffocating sometimes.

Doctor: Hmm, I see. Can you describe the swelling for me?

Patient: It's mostly on the right side and extends from the limit between the hard and soft palate to the oropharynx. It has a smooth surface, is hard to the touch, and has an irregular shape.

Doctor: Okay, I understand. We performed a cervical tomography and based on the results and your clinical examination, we think it could be a benign or malignant salivary gland tumor.

Patient: Oh no.

Doctor: Don't worry, we performed an incisional biopsy under local anesthesia to establish the definitive diagnosis. However, the histopathological examination of the fragment revealed normal mucosa.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: We decided to perform a second conventional biopsy, making sure to collect material from a greater depth. The histopathological analysis again revealed normal mucosa.

Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: We consulted with the otorhinolaryngologist team and decided to perform a CNB. During the intraoral exam, we were able to identify the exact location of the lesion without the need for any imaging guidance.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We used a needle activated by an automatic spring system equipped with an outer cannula and inner stylet. Under local anesthesia using 1% lidocaine, we chose the biopsy area by palpating the lump and positioned the tip of the needle adjacently to the lesion.

Patient: Hmm.

Doctor: The handpiece was activated and quickly moved back and forth, cutting a sample measuring 17 mm in length. We only obtained one core of tissue and carefully removed it from the biopsy needle. The quality of the specimen was assessed by visual inspection and put into 10% formalin for fixation, taking care not to damage the thin tissue.

Patient: Alright.

Doctor: We compressed the biopsy site for five minutes to avoid bleeding and observed you for 30 minutes. You were later discharged as there were no signs or symptoms of bleeding or pain.

Patient: That's good to hear.

Doctor: The histopathological analysis of the sample revealed pleomorphic adenoma.

Patient: What does that mean?

Doctor: It means that you have a benign tumor. We have referred you to the head and neck service for complete resection of the tumor. The specimen was sent to the lab for further analysis.

Patient: Alright, thank you.

Doctor: You're welcome. Please make sure to follow up with the head and neck service as soon as possible.

data:
A 67 year old male patient was admitted to the emergency room with dizziness and gait ataxia that had suddenly developed two days previously. The patient was receiving pharmacological treatment for hypertension and diabetes and there was no relevant family history. Other than the dizziness and gait ataxia, the patient complaining of headache, hearing loss and aural pressure in the left ear, and aural discharge but these did not accompany otalgia or tinnitus. The patient displayed a clear state of consciousness in neurological examination, his papillary reflex was normal, and nystagmus was not observed. The patient fell toward left even with his eyes open in the Romberg test and displayed dysmetria on the left side in the cerebellar function finger to nose test. Brain CT taken in the emergency room displayed the formation of a common wall, including the wall that enhanced the contrast in a circle of 5×5 cm toward the left cerebellum and a manifestation in which it pressed the brain stem and the fourth ventricle (). With the suspicion of brain abscess in the left cerebellum, the patient was admitted to the neurosurgical ward and received antibiotic treatment. Two days after he was admitted to hospital, his state of consciousness suddenly altered to drowsy and craniotomy and drainage of abscess was performed in response. As a result of requesting department of otorhinolaryngology for phy-sical examination in order to assess the causative diseases after surgery, it was found that the external auditory canal was narrow and aural discharge and granulation tissue were observed in the left ear. The right ear was normal. Tympanic mem-brane retraction and the aural discharge that accompanies keratin were also observed ().
On temporal bone CT taken with the suspicion of left otitis media cholesteatomatica, an overall destruction of the cochlea and vestibular organ in the left ear caused by cholesteatoma was indicated (). Air conduction hearing and bone conduction hearing of 36 dB respectively was presented for the right ear and hearing loss was found in the left ear when performing pure tone audiometry.
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, sir. How are you feeling today?

Patient: Not too good, doctor. I've been feeling dizzy and unsteady on my feet for the past two days.

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?

Patient: Yes, I've been experiencing headache, hearing loss and aural pressure in my left ear, and aural discharge. But I don't have any pain or ringing in my ear.

Doctor: Hmm, okay. I understand. I see from your record that you were admitted to the emergency room with dizziness and gait ataxia. Can you tell me more about that?

Patient: Yes, it suddenly developed two days ago and I was brought to the emergency room. I'm receiving treatment for hypertension and diabetes.

Doctor: I see. And is there any relevant family history?

Patient: No, there isn't.

Doctor: Alright. Let me take a look at your neurological examination. Your state of consciousness is clear and your papillary reflex is normal, correct?

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: And nystagmus was not observed, correct?

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: Okay. In the Romberg test, you fell towards the left even with your eyes open, and in the cerebellar function finger to nose test, you displayed dysmetria on the left side, is that correct?

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: I see. A Brain CT was taken in the emergency room and it showed the formation of a common wall, including the wall that enhanced the contrast in a circle of 5×5 cm towards the left cerebellum and a manifestation in which it pressed the brain stem and the fourth ventricle.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Doctor: With the suspicion of brain abscess in the left cerebellum, you were admitted to the neurosurgical ward and received antibiotic treatment.

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: And two days after, your state of consciousness suddenly altered to drowsy and craniotomy and drainage of abscess was performed in response.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: After the surgery, we requested the department of otorhinolaryngology for physical examination in order to assess the causative diseases and it was found that the external auditory canal was narrow and aural discharge and granulation tissue were observed in the left ear. The right ear was normal.

Patient: Yes, that's right.

Doctor: Tympanic membrane retraction and the aural discharge that accompanies keratin were also observed in the left ear.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: A temporal bone CT was taken with the suspicion of left otitis media cholesteatomatica and it indicated an overall destruction of the cochlea and vestibular organ in the left ear caused by cholesteatoma.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Doctor: In the pure tone audiometry, air conduction hearing and bone conduction hearing of 36 dB were presented for the right ear and hearing loss was found in the left ear.

Patient: Yes, that's correct.

Doctor: Alright, sir. I'll need to keep you here for a little while longer for further treatment and monitoring. I'll also need to schedule a follow-up appointment with you in a few weeks.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

data:
A 44-year-old woman was admitted to our outpatient clinic presenting with dysuria and intermittent hematuria for 2 years. She had a medical history of insertion of an IUD inserted 9 years ago. Three months after the insertion of IUD, she fell pregnant unexpectedly. It was her third pregnancy when she was 35 years old and previously she had two children who were 9 and 10 years old at that time. At the visit for pregnancy, the string of the device had not been detected by her gynecologist and it was assumed that IUD had been expelled spontaneously. She had continued her pregnancy and had a normal vaginal delivery without complication. Forty days after delivery, a second IUD had been inserted for contraception. After insertion of the second IUD she had no complaint in the following six years. The second IUD was removed 2 years before her presentation by her gynecologist because of the persistent urinary symptoms which was of newly onset. Physical examination at that time did not show any remarkable finding. Urinalysis was indicative of pyuria and hematuria and urine culture was negative. Abdominal ultrasonography revealed an echogenic intravesical lesion measuring about 27 mm with distal acoustic shadow suggestive of a foreign body or calculus. Plain radiography of the pelvis was not informative enough to show details of a foreign body.
Because of a lost IUD history and abnormal localized hyperechogenic lesion which was suggestive of a foreign body, we had planned a medical consultation to obstetric and gynecology department. Gynecologic examination reported that there were no visible strings of an IUD and cervix was closed. Transvaginal ultrasonography had revealed that more than half of the echogenic foreign body seemed to be in the bladder and a small part of it in the uterovesical space (). For confirmation and definitive diagnosis, cystoscopic evaluation was performed under local anesthesia and revealed a partially embedded intravesical IUD on the posterior bladder wall, complicated with a stone formation (Figures and ). So the patient underwent endoscopic surgery and the stone around the IU

data:
We present a case of a 42-year-old female who was found to have an incidental renal mass, which, on histological examination of the excised specimen, was revealed to be a clear cell papillary carcinoma, a relatively uncommon variant of renal cell carcinoma. The patient is a 42-year-old female who presented to her local medical officer with a two-week history of neck pain and radicular like pains extending into her right arm. A CT scan of her cervical spine revealed multilevel intervertebral disc and facet joint degenerative change resulting in neural exit foraminal narrowing. She was noted to have raised inflammatory markers (WCC 27.5, neutrophils 24.8, and CRP 319) and S. aureus was isolated on a blood culture. She was commenced on IV antibiotics; however her symptoms failed to improve and she subsequently developed significant lower back pain for which a CT of her lumbar spine was arranged. This revealed no convincing evidence of a lumbar spine infective process; however a 47 × 31 mm solid upper pole mass with an irregular periphery and internal calcification was identified in the left kidney, suspicious for a renal cell carcinoma.
The renal mass was further characterized with a triple phase abdominal CT scan and this confirmed a 4 × 4.9 × 4.5 cm heterogenous mass in the upper pole of the left kidney. There was no evidence of left renal vein involvement nor was any radiologically significant lymphadenopathy seen. Her films were reviewed and the decision was made to biopsy the left renal mass to establish whether the lesion was neoplastic or inflammatory. A core biopsy of the left kidney was reported as a Fuhrman grade 1, clear cell renal cell carcinoma (). She was then booked for an elective laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy. She underwent this procedure without complication and had an uneventful postoperative course subsequently being discharged home on day four.
Macroscopic examination of the surgical specimen revealed a tumor in the mid portion of the kidney located superior to the renal hilum measuring 48 mm × 40 mm × 46 mm

Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Sure, I have been having neck pain and radicular like pains extending into my right arm.
Doctor: Hmm, I understand. Have you had any tests done to see what is causing your pain?
Patient: Yes, I had a CT scan of my cervical spine and it showed multilevel intervertebral disc and facet joint degenerative change resulting in neural exit foraminal narrowing.
Doctor: Okay, that explains the neck pain. How about the back pain?
Patient: I developed significant lower back pain and had a CT of my lumbar spine, but it didn't show any convincing evidence of an infective process.
Doctor: I see. Did the CT scan show anything else?
Patient: Yes, it showed a 47 × 31 mm solid upper pole mass with an irregular periphery and internal calcification in my left kidney, which is suspicious for a renal cell carcinoma.
Doctor: Alright, that's concerning. We'll need to do some more tests to confirm. Can you tell me about your blood test results?
Patient: Yes, I had raised inflammatory markers and S. aureus was isolated on a blood culture.
Doctor: I see. Were you treated with antibiotics for the infection?
Patient: Yes, I was started on IV antibiotics, but my symptoms didn't improve.
Doctor: Okay, we'll need to do a triple phase abdominal CT scan to further characterize the renal mass.
Patient: Alright.
[A few days later]
Doctor: Hi, I have the results of your abdominal CT scan.
Patient: Okay, what did it show?
Doctor: It confirmed a 4 × 4.9 × 4.5 cm heterogenous mass in the upper pole of your left kidney. There was no evidence of left renal vein involvement nor was any radiologically significant lymphadenopathy seen.
Patient: Okay, so what's the next step?
Doctor: We'll need to biopsy the left renal mass to establish whether the lesion is neoplastic or inflammatory.
Patient: Alright, how will the biopsy be done?
Doctor: We'll do a core biopsy of the left kidney.
[A few days later]
Doctor: Hi, I have the results of your biopsy.
Patient: Okay, what did it show?
Doctor: It was reported as a Fuhrman grade 1, clear cell renal cell carcinoma.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that you have a clear cell papillary carcinoma, a relatively uncommon variant of renal cell carcinoma.
Patient: Okay, so what's the treatment for this?
Doctor: We'll need to remove the tumor with a laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy.
Patient: Alright, when will that be done?
Doctor: We'll book you for an elective laparoscopic left radical nephrectomy.
[A few days later]
Doctor: Hi, how are you feeling after the procedure?
Patient: I feel okay, just a little sore.
Doctor: That's to be expected. The macroscopic examination of the surgical specimen revealed a tumor in the mid portion of the kidney located superior to the renal hilum measuring 48 mm × 40 mm × 46 mm.
Patient: What does that mean?
Doctor: It means that the tumor was removed successfully and there were no complications during the procedure.
Patient: Great, when can I go home?
Doctor: You can go home today. You had an uneventful postoperative course and were discharged home on day four.
Patient: Thank you, doctor.

data:
A 45-year-old male with end stage renal disease due to chronic glomerulonephritis started automated PD in February 2015 and presented 7 months later with nausea and cloudy PD effluent. The peritoneal effluent white cell count was 996 cells/mL, with a polymorphonuclear cell fraction of 56%. The peritoneal fluid was sent for microbiological investigations and he was given IP vancomycin 2 g and ceftazidime 1.5 g as per the hospital empiric protocol. The culture grew coagulase-negative staphylococcus resistant to beta lactams but sensitive to vancomycin. The IP ceftazidime was discontinued after 2 doses and he continued IP vancomycin every 4 days for a total of 3 weeks. The vancomycin dose was adjusted according to serum vancomycin level and the level remained greater than 25 mg/L throughout the treatment with the highest level being 35 mg/L. His levels were kept deliberately high as he was due for a live donor kidney transplant the following month and the treating team wanted to minimize the risk of relapsed peritonitis.
One day after completing the course of vancomycin, the patient presented with general malaise and a skin rash which had begun on the abdomen and progressed to involve the entire trunk and proximal limbs. He reported intense pruritus and pain. He was hypotensive with mean arterial blood pressure of 50 mm Hg, heart rate 115, and temperature T 39.1°C. There was a diffuse blanchable papular rash involving the trunk and proximal limbs without blistering or sloughing. There was no mucous membrane involvement and no lymphadenopathy. He was admitted to the intensive care unit for hypotension requiring vasopressors and was initially treated for possible sepsis with intravenous saline and broad spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin. Initial laboratory investigations are shown in . All imaging was normal, and blood and urine cultures revealed no growth. After admission day 2 he had a skin biopsy performed which revealed a moderate mixed perivascular infiltrate, composed mostly of lymphocytes with a few neutrophils and scattered eosinophils (). There was a moderate amount of both vacuolar and a slightly lichenoid interface dermatitis, and
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, Mr. [Patient's Name]. How are you feeling today?
Patient: Not so good, doctor. I have been feeling quite sick lately.
Doctor: I see. Can you tell me more about your symptoms?
Patient: Well, I have been feeling nauseous and my peritoneal fluid has been cloudy.
Doctor: I see. And when did you start feeling this way?
Patient: It started about 7 months after I started automated PD in February 2015.
Doctor: Alright. And have you had any tests done?
Patient: Yes, I have. The peritoneal effluent white cell count was 996 cells/mL, with a polymorphonuclear cell fraction of 56%.
Doctor: Hmm, I see. And what was the result of the microbiological investigation on the peritoneal fluid?
Patient: The culture grew coagulase-negative staphylococcus resistant to beta lactams but sensitive to vancomycin.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. And what was the treatment that was given to you?
Patient: I was given IP vancomycin 2 g and ceftazidime 1.5 g as per the hospital empiric protocol.
Doctor: And how did you respond to the treatment?
Patient: The ceftazidime was discontinued after 2 doses and I continued IP vancomycin every 4 days for a total of 3 weeks.
Doctor: And was the vancomycin dose adjusted according to your serum vancomycin level?
Patient: Yes, it was. The level remained greater than 25 mg/L throughout the treatment with the highest level being 35 mg/L.
Doctor: I see. And why was the level kept deliberately high?
Patient: Because I was due for a live donor kidney transplant the following month and the treating team wanted to minimize the risk of relapsed peritonitis.
Doctor: I understand. And how have you been feeling since the treatment?
Patient: One day after completing the course of vancomycin, I presented with general malaise and a skin rash which had begun on the abdomen and progressed to involve the entire trunk and proximal limbs. I reported intense pruritus and pain.
Doctor: I see. And how was your blood pressure, heart rate, and temperature at that time?
Patient: I was hypotensive with mean arterial blood pressure of 50 mm Hg, heart rate 115, and temperature T 39.1°C.
Doctor: Alright. And what was the appearance of the skin rash?
Patient: There was a diffuse blanchable papular rash involving the trunk and proximal limbs without blistering or sloughing. There was no mucous membrane involvement and no lymphadenopathy.
Doctor: I see. And what was the next step taken for your condition?
Patient: I was admitted to the intensive care unit for hypotension requiring vasopressors and was initially treated for possible sepsis with intravenous saline and broad spectrum antibiotics including vancomycin.
Doctor: And what did the initial laboratory investigations show?
Patient: All imaging was normal, and blood and urine cultures revealed no growth.
Doctor: I see. And after admission, what happened next?
Patient: After admission day 2, I had a skin biopsy performed which revealed a moderate mixed perivascular infiltrate, composed mostly of lymphocytes with a few neutrophils and scattered eosinophils.
Doctor: I see. And what was the result of the skin biopsy?
Patient: There was a moderate amount of both vacuolar and a slightly lichenoid interface dermatitis.
Doctor: Alright. I will need to consult with some of my colleagues and get back to you with more information. In the meantime, please let me know if you have any further symptoms or concerns.
Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

data:
A 70-year-old female was referred to breast re-implantation of the right side due to iatrogenic rupture and explantation during thoracic surgery. The patient had a medical history of cancer in the right breast in 1984 with subsequent treatment including unilateral mastectomy, radiochemotherapy and secondary reconstruction with a subpectoral silicone implant. In 2015 the patient was diagnosed with leiomyosarcoma in the right thigh and bilateral pulmonary metastases. The patient underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) wedge resection of the right lung and during this procedure iatrogenic perforation of the silicone implant and injury to the thoracic wall occurred. The thoracic cavity was closed and the perforated breast implant removed without diagnosis of the defect.
In stabile condition, the patient expressed a strong desire for breast re-implantation and during this procedure the defect of the thoracic wall and parietal pleura was observed. As the defect was minor, simple closure of soft tissue over the defect would be appropriate in patients not planned for breast reconstruction, however the patient in this case had expressed an extremely strong desire for breast reconstruction. In case of direct closure communication would persist between the lung and the capsular space and therefore it was necessary to close the defect with a thin layer of material allowing both secure closure of the defect and re-implantation. The highly vascularised capsule is known to be appropriate for creation of flaps and grafts, and has previously been used in management of issues in relation to breast implants []. The capsule tissue was an appropriate choice for creation of a pedicled flap in this case because the tissue presented a minimally invasive treatment option for the patient compared to closure with a muscle flap or addition of non-autologus tissue such ADM, increasing infection risk. The anterior part of the capsule in relation to the pectoral muscle was dissected free from the upper pole to the inframammary fold resulting in a medially and centrally vascularised flap. The flap was rotated with the agglutinating side facing downwards to cover the pleural defect and sutured shut. The
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?
Patient: I'm feeling okay, thank you.
Doctor: I understand you were referred to us for re-implantation of your right breast. Can you tell me a little bit about your history?
Patient: Yes, I had a rupture and explantation during thoracic surgery.
Doctor: I see. And do you have a history of cancer?
Patient: Yes, I was diagnosed with cancer in my right breast in 1984 and I had a mastectomy and radiochemotherapy as treatment. I also had a secondary reconstruction with a silicone implant.
Doctor: Okay, I understand. And in 2015, you were diagnosed with leiomyosarcoma and bilateral pulmonary metastases, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: And you underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right. I had a VATS wedge resection of my right lung.
Doctor: And during that procedure, there was a perforation of your silicone implant and injury to your thoracic wall, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I see. And the perforated breast implant was removed without a diagnosis of the defect, is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: I understand you are in a stable condition and you have expressed a strong desire for breast re-implantation. Is that correct?
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Okay. During the procedure, we observed a minor defect in your thoracic wall and parietal pleura. In most cases, simple closure of soft tissue over the defect would be appropriate, but since you have expressed an extremely strong desire for breast reconstruction, we needed to use a different approach.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: We closed the defect with a thin layer of material that allowed secure closure of the defect and re-implantation. The highly vascularized capsule tissue was an appropriate choice for creation of a pedicled flap. This was a minimally invasive treatment option for you compared to closure with a muscle flap or addition of non-autologus tissue, which would have increased the risk of infection.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: The anterior part of the capsule in relation to the pectoral muscle was dissected free and the flap was rotated and sutured shut.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Is there anything you would like to ask or anything that is unclear to you?
Patient: No, I think you explained everything clearly. Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Just to summarize, we performed a re-implantation of your right breast after a minor defect was observed in your thoracic wall and parietal pleura. The highly vascularized capsule tissue was used to create a pedicled flap and the anterior part of the capsule was dissected and sutured shut.
Patient: Yes, that's right.
Doctor: Great. I would like to see you back in two weeks for a follow-up appointment. Is that okay with you?
Patient: Yes, that's fine.
Doctor: Great. If you have any questions or concerns in the meantime, please don't hesitate to call us.
Patient: Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Have a good day.
Patient: You too.

data:
This is a healthy appearing 77 year old man with bladder cancer. He presented in April 2016 with an episode of gross hematuria. He lives in Central America and was seen by a urologist there.
His past medical history is uneventful. He has adult onset type 2 diabetes and takes metformin. He was never a cigarette smoker. The only surgery he had was a right inguinal hernia repair. He is not overweight.
In April 2016 he had two papillary tumors which appeared to be Ta. He underwent a transurethral resection and the pathology was low grade Ta. His first surveillance cystoscopy was negative. In October 2016 he had four LG Ta tumors which were resected. This was followed by 6 weeks of intravesical chemotherapy using mitomycin C.
The patient was tumor free until August 2018 at which time he was found to have multifocal bladder cancer. A transurethral resection revealed high grade Ta urothelial cancer. There was also focal carcinoma in situ. Lamina propria and muscularis propria were present and were free of cancer. He received one dose of intravesical MMC postoperatively. He elected to have a consultation here in South Florida.
He presented with nocturia×4 and some daytime frequency. Prior to the recent TUR BT he had nocturia×2 and no daytime voiding complaints.
I saw the patient in September 2018. I reviewed the recent bladder tissue (–) and proceeded with office flexible cystoscopy. The bladder had several areas of necrosis consistent with MMC effect on the previous resected urothelium (). In addition there were areas of persistent or new tumor which appeared to be high grade Ta ().
There are two quite different alternatives in my view. One might proceed with a TUR BT and remove all visible tumor. If the pathology is, as expected, high grade Ta with or without CIS one might proceed with a bladder preservation approach which would consist of a course of intravesical BCG. This might be reasonable as he has not had a bladder cancer which invaded the lamina propria or muscularis propria. Given

Doctor: I see. And what did you do after that?

Patient: I received one dose of intravesical MMC postoperatively. Then I elected to have a consultation here in South Florida.

Doctor: There are two quite different alternatives in my view. One might proceed with a TUR BT and remove all visible tumor. If the pathology is, as expected, high grade Ta with or without CIS, one might proceed with a bladder preservation approach which would consist of a course of intravesical BCG. This might be reasonable as you have not had a bladder cancer which invaded the lamina propria or muscularis propria.

Patient: So what do you recommend?

Doctor: I recommend the bladder preservation approach with a course of intravesical BCG. But let's discuss this further and make a final decision together.

data: A 38-year-old Indian male was referred to the Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery Clinic, Boston University Goldman School of Dental Medicine for the evaluation and management of progressive trismus. Patient presented with main complaint of inability to chew food and limited mouth opening. He reported that this has been going on with him for the last few years but became more concern for him just recently. His medical history was significant for hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and benign prostatic hyperplasia which all are controlled by medications. Patient reported that he has been chewing pan of Indian tobacco for the last 15 years. Clinical exam showed no lymphadenopathy, swelling, or asymmetry. Limited mouth opening at 15 mm and cranial nerves exam is unremarkable except for alter sensation in the buccal branch of V 3 bilaterally (). Intraoral exam showed poor oral hygiene, multiple carious teeth. Palpable severe fibrous bands in buccal mucosa from just inside the commeasure of the mouth up to the pterygomandibular raphe were felt bilaterally. Soft palate, tongue and floor of mouth were not involved. The fibrosis has resulted in pale-appearing mucosa. An incisional biopsy was taken for histopathological evaluation which confirmed the diagnosis of submucous fibrosis infiltrating the muscular layer (), after discussion of the clinical findings and treatment options with the patient. The patient was taken to the operating room where he was placed on the surgical table hooked to the anesthesia, cardiac monitors, and pulse oximeter. Next patient was induced via intravenous general anesthesia and intubated with no complications. Local anesthesia was infiltrated in the intended surgical areas. Using a transoral approach a blade number 15 was utilized for the surgical excision of the fibrous bands and protecting underlying vital structures. Surgical dissection was carried out to the level of the buccinator muscle. After controlling bleeding the wound edges were prepared for the graft placement. Next attention was made toward the right thigh from which a 7 × 7 cm full thickness skin graft was harvested (); using sharp dissection, was done to the level of the subcutaneous fat.
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, how are you feeling today?

Patient: Good morning, I'm feeling okay, doctor.

Doctor: I understand you were referred to our clinic for evaluation and management of your progressive trismus. Can you tell me more about your main complaint?

Patient: Yes, doctor. I have trouble chewing my food and my mouth won't open very wide.

Doctor: I see. And when did this start?

Patient: It's been going on for a few years, but it's gotten worse recently.

Doctor: I understand. Can you tell me about your medical history?

Patient: I have hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, and benign prostatic hyperplasia, but they're all controlled by medications.

Doctor: Okay. And have you been chewing pan of Indian tobacco for the last 15 years?

Patient: Yes, doctor.

Doctor: Okay. During our examination, we didn't find any lymphadenopathy, swelling, or asymmetry. But we did find limited mouth opening at 15 mm. And you reported altered sensation in the buccal branch of V 3 bilaterally.

Patient: Yes, doctor.

Doctor: Our intraoral exam showed poor oral hygiene and multiple carious teeth. And we felt severe fibrous bands in your buccal mucosa. Your soft palate, tongue, and floor of mouth were not involved. This fibrosis has resulted in pale-appearing mucosa.

Patient: Hmm, okay.

Doctor: We took an incisional biopsy for histopathological evaluation and it confirmed the diagnosis of submucous fibrosis infiltrating the muscular layer.

Patient: What does that mean, doctor?

Doctor: It means that there is fibrous tissue that has infiltrated the muscle layer in your mouth. We discussed the clinical findings and treatment options with you and decided to proceed with surgical excision.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We took you to the operating room and hooked you up to the anesthesia, cardiac monitors, and pulse oximeter. You were induced via intravenous general anesthesia and intubated with no complications. We infiltrated local anesthesia in the intended surgical areas.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We used a transoral approach and a blade number 15 for the surgical excision of the fibrous bands and protecting underlying vital structures. We carried out surgical dissection to the level of the buccinator muscle. After controlling the bleeding, we prepared the wound edges for graft placement.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: We harvested a 7 × 7 cm full thickness skin graft from your right thigh using sharp dissection down to the level of the subcutaneous fat.

Patient: Okay.

Doctor: You'll need to follow up with us in a few weeks to make sure the wound is healing properly. And you should avoid chewing tobacco to prevent this from happening again.

Patient: Okay, doctor. Thank you.

data:
A 75-year-old female patient reported to our maxillofacial surgical services with the chief complaint of intra-oral painless growth since one and half year. She also had a complaint of difficulty in closing the mouth since past 2-3 months.
The patient was relatively asymptomatic one and half year back, then the patient started noticing small painless growth inside the oral cavity in the right mandibular alveolar region, and growth gradually started increasing in size. Few months later she also started having fetid odor from the oral cavity. Because of large size of the growth the patient started having difficult in closing the mouth completely and inability to chew the food. The patient had a history of exfoliation of mandibular teeth and few maxillary teeth due to extensive mobility. During the dental education camp held in patient's village, the patient turned up for consultation. The patient was then referred to outpatient department of maxillofacial surgery at Sardar Patel Institute of Dental and Medical Sciences, Lucknow. Past history and medical history did not reveal any relevant information. She was taking no medication and had no history of known drug allergy. Her general physical examination revealed no abnormality other than those related to the chief complaint except for moderate visual and hearing impairment.
On examination growth was slightly visible when the patient protruded the tongue. The patient was unable to close the mouth completely due to size of the lesion []. On intra-oral examination smooth surfaced, and lobulated growth of approximately 5 × 4 × 2 cm in size was present covering the alveolar ridge from the midline to molar region on completely edentulous alveolar ridge. Growth was pedunculated and was freely movable over peduncle which was present on the alveolar ridge of the premolar region. Surface of growth was smooth and showing normal color in certain areas whereas superior surface of the growth in certain area was covered by yellowish plaque like material. Growth was partially divided into two large lobules covering both buccal and lingual vestibules []. Mild indentation of maxillary teeth was
conversation:
Doctor: Good morning, what brings you to our surgical services today?

Patient: Good morning doctor, I have been having a growth in my mouth for over a year now and it's causing me difficulty in closing my mouth completely.

Doctor: I see, can you tell me more about your chief complaint?

Patient: Yes doctor, I started noticing a small painless growth inside my oral cavity in the right mandibular alveolar region about a year and a half ago. It gradually increased in size and now it's causing me difficulty in closing my mouth and chewing food.

Doctor: Hmm, I understand. Have you had any other symptoms besides the growth in your mouth?

Patient: Yes doctor, I have been having a fetid odor from my oral cavity for a few months now.

Doctor: Okay, can you tell me about your medical history?

Patient: I have a history of exfoliation of my mandibular teeth and a few maxillary teeth due to extensive mobility.

Doctor: I see. How did you come to know about our surgical services?

Patient: I turned up for consultation at a dental education camp held in my village and was referred to your outpatient department of maxillofacial surgery.

Doctor: Okay, I see. Have you taken any medication or have you had any known drug allergy in the past?

Patient: No doctor, I haven't taken any medication and I don't have any history of known drug allergy.

Doctor: Alright, let's do a physical examination. Can you tell me if you have any visual or hearing impairment?

Patient: Yes doctor, I have moderate visual and hearing impairment.

Doctor: Alright, let's start the examination. Can you open your mouth for me?

Patient: Yes doctor.

Doctor: (Examines the patient's mouth) I see a slightly visible growth when you protrude your tongue. Is it causing you any pain?

Patient: No doctor, it's not causing me any pain.

Doctor: Alright, let's do an oral examination. (Examines the patient's mouth) I see a smooth surfaced, lobulated growth of approximately 5 × 4 × 2 cm in size covering the alveolar ridge from the midline to the molar region on a completely edentulous alveolar ridge. The growth is pedunculated and freely movable over the peduncle which is present on the alveolar ridge of the premolar region. The surface of the growth is smooth and showing normal color in certain areas, whereas the superior surface of the growth in certain areas is covered by yellowish plaque-like material. There is a mild indentation of your maxillary teeth.

Doctor: Based on the examination, I would like to perform a biopsy to determine the exact cause of the growth.

Patient: Okay doctor.

Doctor: I will also prescribe some antibiotics to help with the fetid odor. Please come back in a week for the results of the biopsy and to see if the antibiotics are helping.

Patient: Alright doctor, thank you.

data: A 6-month-old baby boy presented at the Vascular Surgery clinic with a 2-month history of swelling noticed by his parents on the hypothenar eminence of the left hand (). The swelling was gradually increasing in size. The parents gave no history of any unusual crying of the baby, which concludes that it was painless. On our examination, the swelling was around 4×2 cm in size. It was pulsatile on palpation, and there were no motor deficits in the left hand. This swelling was localized in the left hand hypothenar eminence, and both the radial and ulnar pulses were palpable with a good capillary refill. On taking a detailed history, the mother explained that the baby had the habit of hitting his left hand mainly on the table while having food and on other objects. With the clinical history and examination, an aneurysmal swelling was confirmed, most likely arising from the ulnar artery or the palmar arch because of its location. He came in with an arterial duplex, which confirmed only an aneurysmal sac. There was no detailed anatomical description because of the compromised examination due to the age of the child. No other investigations were carried out to confirm the diagnosis because of financial limitations and the very young age of the child, and we opted for surgical excision directly. Intraoperatively, it was an aneurysmal swelling involving the ulnar artery from below the wrist and at the distal forearm involving the superficial palmar arch distally and taking the digital blood supply of the little finger and the ring finger with it (). This aneurysm was excised and repaired with an interposition reverse cephalic vein graft from the forearm of the same side (). A segment of the Y-shaped cephalic vein with a tributary was taken from the distal forearm of the same side. The proximal end of the reverse cephalic vein was anastomosed to the distal end of the ulnar artery, and the two distal ends of the reverse cephalic vein in a Y-shape fashion were anastomosed, one at the superficial

Doctor: Hello, how are you today?
Patient: I'm good, thank you.
Doctor: Can you tell me what brings you here today?
Patient: My 6-month-old baby boy presented at the Vascular Surgery clinic with a 2-month history of swelling noticed by his parents on the hypothenar eminence of the left hand.
Doctor: I see. And was the swelling increasing in size?
Patient: Yes, it was gradually increasing in size.
Doctor: Did the baby have any unusual crying or pain?
Patient: No, the parents gave no history of any unusual crying of the baby, which concludes that it was painless.
Doctor: Alright. And during the examination, was the swelling pulsatile on palpation?
Patient: Yes, it was pulsatile on palpation.
Doctor: And were there any motor deficits in the left hand?
Patient: No, there were no motor deficits in the left hand.
Doctor: I see. The mother explained that the baby had the habit of hitting his left hand mainly on the table while having food and on other objects, correct?
Patient: Yes, that's correct.
Doctor: With the clinical history and examination, an aneurysmal swelling was confirmed, most likely arising from the ulnar artery or the palmar arch because of its location.
Patient: Hmm, okay.
Doctor: There was an arterial duplex, which confirmed only an aneurysmal sac. However, there was no detailed anatomical description because of the compromised examination due to the age of the child.
Patient: I understand.
Doctor: No other investigations were carried out to confirm the diagnosis because of financial limitations and the very young age of the child, and we opted for surgical excision directly.
Patient: Okay.
Doctor: Intraoperatively, it was an aneurysmal swelling involving the ulnar artery from below the wrist and at the distal forearm involving the superficial palmar arch distally and taking the digital blood supply of the little finger and the ring finger with it.
Patient: Hmm, yes.
Doctor: The aneurysm was excised and repaired with an interposition reverse cephalic vein graft from the forearm of the same side.
Patient: I see.
Doctor: A segment of the Y-shaped cephalic vein with a tributary was taken from the distal forearm of the same side. The proximal end of the reverse cephalic vein was anastomosed to the distal end of the ulnar artery, and the two distal ends of the reverse cephalic vein in a Y-shape fashion were anastomosed, one at the superficial.
Patient: Okay, I understand.
Doctor: Is there anything else you want to ask about the procedure or the diagnosis?
Patient: No, that's all. Thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Please let me know if you have any concerns or questions in the future.
Patient: I will, thank you.
Doctor: You're welcome. Take care.
